content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
 The Witcher: Enhanced Edition review The witcher is a role-playing game based on The witcher novel series written by polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. The witcher is set in a medival fantasy world where you play as the famous witcher, Geralt of Rivia. Witchers are mutated monster slayers, with super human abilities, they're immune to diseases, they're sterile, they can drink potions that would kill a normal man and they can use magicial witcher signs. Becoming a witcher is a painful process, as they have to go through rituals to gain their mutations and relentless physical and magical training. Witchers are trained at witcher schools, one such as Kaer morhen, this is where Geralt was trained. They carry two swords with them, a steel and silver sword. Silver for monsters and magical creatures, steel for non-magical creatures and the occasional human. They also carry a witcher medallion, it is sensitive to magic, it vibrates when its near magic and magical beings. All young witchers who has passed the Trial of the Grasses are given a witcher medallion. Now that you know a little about witchers and the witcher universe let's talk about the game. Story, dialogue, sound and music The wicther starts with Geralt running for his life through the forests outside of Kaer morhen, while the other witchers try to chase him down. Geralt falls to the ground, when he wakes up again they find out that Geralt has gotten serious case of amnesia. The only thing he remembers is fighting techniques. after recovering at Kaer morhen, the witchers are attacked by a bandit group known as the Salamandra. Their leader known as Azar Javed and his bitc- I mean his assistant only known as the professor, aim to steal the witcher mutations, they kill the witcher known as Leo and run away with the mutations. Now Geralt aim to hunt down the Salamandra and kill their leader. On his way he meets characters like Shani, Triss Merigold, Dandelion, Zoltan Chivay and Berengar. He also meets a boy named Alvin who has magical powers he can not control. It's a good written story. The Dialouge is nice, the voice acting is decent, just sometimes it feels like you're talking to a wall. But mostly it's ok. The sound quality is not that good, however the music is amazing. The witcher is one of those games that does choices right, for example in chapter I i helped a witch, this witch later appeared in the final chapter to give me potions to aid me in the final battle. If you know you made a bad decision, you will feel terrible inside. There is alot of different choices to make in this game. Gameplay The combat is hard getting used to, you use your steel sword for humans and your silver swords for monsters, you also get some other minor weapons you can use but i mostly avoided them as i saw them as useless. You can pick from three different fighting modes, fast attacks, strong attacks and group attacks, you switch fighting mode when fighting certain enemies, this is good because you get different ways to fight and it keeps the combat interesting. But it's all very clunky, sometimes Geralt won't move in combat or he won't attack or he can't use magical signs. Through the game you can unlock five different witcher signs, Igni, Aard, Quen, Yrden and Axii, these signs can be used to knock down enemies, set them on fire or slow them, these are just a few examples. Then there is the alchemy, this system allows you to brew potions, oils and bombs, which can be used in combat. The character building that this game has is amazing, here you can choose if you want to be better with a silver sword, or a steel sword, or if you want to be better with the witcher signs. You get different points each time you level up that you can use in this system. Some of the stuff you can get is really cool, and as you upgrade for example your silver sword or steel sword skill, Geralt will start doing crazy flips in the air while fighting. Cons and pros Pros: Good written story Excellent character building Good characters Decent dialogue system Great soundtrack Great combat when you learn it Great potion system Amazing experienceCons: Combat can often be clunky and lead to frustration Poor sound quality The game endsI'll give the story an 10/10, and the gameplay an 8/10.Despite its many flaws, it still manages to be one of my favorite role-playing games of all time.The Witcher - Cinematic Teaser


YouTube™ Video: The Witcher - Cinematic Teaser 

			Views: 74,088		

			Created by Academy Award-nominated director Tomasz Baginski and his Platige Image studio, this video shows off a small portion of The Witcher's intro cinematic, in which Geralt has to spend a night...

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
 Pros   Great Story           - The Witcher had a strong story and interesting plot. Easily the most attractive feature to the game. It's one of those stories you think about a lot throughout the day, like a good book you want to just jump right back into as soon as you have the time.  Wealth of Content            - The game easily has 75+ hours worth of content. Tons of interesting side quests. Side goals like Romance Cards, Poker games, or Gear Collecting. There is even an adventure editor to make your own stories or play someone else's creation.  The little things / Ambiance             - The Witcher had so many little things that made the game an enjoyable experience. Whether it was the peaceful music that tied into the artfully crafted landscapes or the NPC dynamics (I.e: The towns people running for cover when it rained or conversing about recent things that happened in the area) you can tell the developers put in plenty of personal touch to make the game special. Cons  Character Models             - The character models in this game are god awful. Most Npc and Key Characters have absolutely no facial expressions. It would completely take you out of the immersion. Its extremely hard to feel attached or anything of the sort when someone who is supposed to be emotional has the mightiest poker face I've ever seen.       A lot of models would have little off things that would take away from the seriousness of the game, for example, King Foltest ( A Key Character) would have his elbows bent way too far, which made him look disturbing and unnatural, causing you to lose attention from whatever he was speaking about.       Another thing is that they would reuse or recycle models for npcs, even key characters. It's very strange to see someone important being used later in the game as a normal NPC filler. (I.e The Vivaldi Banker Dwarf; Its disappointing to see him walk around a battlefield as you run up expecting some reasons why he was there, only to find out He is some random NPC with 2 lines of dialogue. This happens a lot during the game)  Animations / Cutscenes              - The animations are extremely poor. They all feel like they are in slow motion when they aren't supposed to be. Again it all feels unnatural and horrid looking. When it wasn't extremely slow action scenes it was abruptly placed concept art style narrations. These narrations would sometimes not make sense because they were placed oddly and almost make it so it would cut off NPC dialog.   Combat               - The combat in the game, which makes up a lot of the game, is a bit clunky. None of the action of the combat is fluid. You'd stop often out of place to start your next combo. It isn't as bad as some other things in the game, but not good either. Final Verdict: 6.5/10  Personal Opinion:  I would be lying if I said I didn't enjoy this game. Sadly there were many things holding this game back from being so much more. The developers could have easily put in a bit more effort to make things look less lazy to bring this game to a 8/10 or 8.5/10. I'm not sure how some of these things made it past them. Reguardless I had fun while playing it. The story was amazing and made me keep coming back for more. If you have the time and are intrested the story of the witcher, this is no doubt a fun game to play through. If not, you can read up most of the plot  here	[witcher.wikia.com] and move on to The Witcher 2.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												[Spoiler Free]The Witcher, a game that uses tacit methods to express it's deep mature themes, and in the process of doing so, implementing order and consistency. The design of the game is fresh and exotic, it feels natural though because it's designed with the perspective of a western audience even though the game is foreign. So let's begin:Aesthetics: 7.80/10The Witcher introduces it's pallete quite unctuously in a way that really builds up expectation however it remains constant and bland, yet dark and truculent therefore it might bore players initially and won't pique their interest for a good portion of the game, it's not colorful by any means although it is atmospheric. The animations are nice but the game lacks a lot of vital sound effects de-effectively reducing the drama in action cutscenes. The music contributes a lot to the score, as it accompanies the game quite effectively, it's good music and catchy, although I do wish there was more melodic variety.Story/Characters: 9.50/10The story and characters are by far the best feature the game has to offer, at times I felt like abandoning the game due to it's repetiveness in cliche' mechanics but the story grabbed me by the brain and held on to me like a clingy newborn pup. It piqued by intellect and engaged me to learn more about the universe and it's precocious story, the characters were friendly and interesting, especially Geralt, which I fell in love with progressively (no homo) as the story unfolded. The game touches some enticing (mature?) themes, (racial prejudice, slavery, drug abuse, politics) and respects your intelligence, never treating you like an idiot.Mechanics/Gameplay: 6.20/10Sadly, the gameplay is tedious, fun, but tedious and annoying. There is a lot of micro managing that is quite loathsome and a boring combat system. The potion creation system however is completely satisfying to use, I do like the concept of gathering rare materials to create a new spell and gathering formulas to create new ones. Some potions felt useless and annoying to make as if they were made for another game, but that's besides the point. The game also has a spell system that is insanely over-powered and that completely overshadows the silver/steel sword system. At one point in time, I never even used my swords, I just spammed igni and gg.Final Verdict: 8.60/10What can I say? I stayed for the story and the characters with the universe grabbing me from the balls to stay. The world is engaging and alive and it really embraces the notion of intellectual players, although the gameplay might be bland, this game is a masterful craft and allows room for bigger and better things.TL;DR: Buy it for the story, leave feeling smart.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
A Grain of TruthWhen you hear stories passed down of a game called The Witcher, tales of a classic RPG from a bygone era, perhaps in one of them contains a "grain of truth."  On the release of the final game in this trilogy (5/19/15), I decided to finally sit down and write about my tale to you.  A tale of one gamer's journey into the world of The Witcher 1, a uniquely, captivating Fantasy cRPG from 2007.  What was I was doing at the time, so long ago?  Shooting Reapers dead and becoming a Warden;  that is until a friend told me about a little known game to me that I might enjoy which went something like, "So I know you like classic games, you should check this out!  Its an RPG game about a Monster Hunter named Geralt of Rivia and its awesome!"  Could it be true, was it "awesome"?Well lets take a gander...I feel like I'm in a Medieval Simulator... but there are elves and magic?The first Witcher game came as a bit of a surprise back in 2007 with other big-name titles coming out around the same time period.  It was released, by now, well known Polish developer group CD Projekt that thought there just wasn't enough, good grim-dark Medieval Fantasy games based on a series of novels, that first became popular in Poland, and that needed to be corrected immediately!As many may know by now (or not), the game is based on the excellent book series by Adrezej Sapkowski in which you play as Geralt of Rivia, a monster hunter for hire, known as a "Witchers" or "Wiedźmin" - whom are basically Medieval Warrior Monks, from an alternate 1200s Scandinavian-like land, cool right? - "but what do the books have to do with the game" you ask? I'll get to that at the end, but firstly what to expect out of this review:  My honest take on the game (The Enhanced Version) and what you can expect, either as someone brand new to this series or those more accustomed to the later games.The Basics An engaging, mystery story-line, that'll make you want to know more about "Who is Geralt?" and the world of the Witcher Interesting side-quests, besides the Monster Hunting variety Choices that actually matter in sometimes subtle and also big ways (multiple variations on Game Ending) Outstanding soundtrack by Paweł Błaszczak & Adam Skorupa that absolutely FITS the stark Medieval setting perfectly (seriously "River of Life" brought a tear to my eye!) and the action music will get you in the mood for combat! Classic take on RPG-tropes with some familiar elements to level (Strength, Dexterity, Stamina, Intelligence) with a uniquely in-universe twist by leveling the types of Magic Witchers use and leveling combat styles (Strong, Fast, Group) Unique Combat / Semi-Active Combo Sword mini-game/system (best way to describe it) One all encompassing menu that lets you easily switch from your items, character screen, journal, and so on The coolest Alchemy mechanics I've seen in a video game (You can experiment and make potions in a way that seems semi-realistic, even making unknown ones if you mix the right ingredients!)Some DetractorsSaving is your Friend, DO IT!  The game does still have crashing issues (I was able to resolve this with a "4GB" patch - but you will have to search that on your own)The camera during dialogue can sometimes go off-center and suddenly you'll be speaking to someone's chest (Why is Geralt staring at Dandelion's Bardly chest?)The game may not get along with Steam Overlay (You may need to turn it off in your Steam settings)While there are many strengths such as the story, there are some things to consider... Combat can be deeply entertaining or overwhelming or potentially frustrating.  As you may have heard from word of mouth or other reviews, the combat is not to everyone's liking.  You are either going to like it or not;  imagine a game like KOTOR or Elder Scrolls where you are standing in place hitting the enemy, but now in addition you'll complete combos for increasingly more insane damage and acrobatics, by clicking your mouse when prompted;  additionally you have magic to use;  you have two types of swords for use on certain targets ; PLUS "Combat Stances" that determine your likelihood to hit whatever type of target you are facing (a "fast" or "slow/strong" opponent) - In truth, the combination of all these were overwhelming at first, but fascinating to me at the same time as there is really not much else like it in other games.  Over time I mastered the combat with practice so it can require patience.  I recommend watching videos or playing a friend's copy as there is no demo. This isn't a "make your own character kind" of RPG;  you are Geralt of Rivia whom has his own history already laid out in the previous novels, but you can choose your stats and how you build him into a Medieval Monster Hunting Badass, and you can choose how to approach parts of the storyline While the story generally tells you where to go and who to speak to next;  there are other parts not so obvious and require you to really think and explore as traditional, classic RPG's tend to do;  There are some excellent guides[www.gamefaqs.com] out there though and there's certainly nothing wrong with that if you feel overwhelmed on any part of the game. The graphics are based on the Bioware Aurora engine and was very nice for its day in 2007 comparatively with other big-name titles from that time - Certainly a dated look compared to games NOW, so if you absolutely must play bleeding-edge technology, this game is probably not for you.  On the other hand, if you do play older titles or often find yourself buying classic games on Steam or GOG, then this game may become that unknown gem as it did for me. SummaryFor a game based on an established series of novels and comics, with its own set of characters and setting, this is one of the best book-to-video game Third Person RPG's I have ever seen.  In that way, it is definitely unique and manages to bring to life the world of the Witcher.  While the game isn't without its own set of flaws, the great story writing, pleasant music, and unique style have certainly made it a classic... as the tale goes.Other Information FAQ - Potential SpoilersHow is this game different from the second or third game in the series?  The combat in the first game is one of the main differences here compared to the rest of the trilogy - it is very much "classic" based and stat-driven (dexterity determining if you get hit or not for instance as you stand in place) compared to the much for "active" action-style gameplay of the other titles.  In addition, in the Witcher 1, Geralt is mainly the one narrating his journal; the Alchemy in Witcher 1 was a bit deeper and seemingly for complex, since it lets you experiment more.So you keep mentioning these books, do I need to read those to understand the game?  No, not necessarily - the game provides enough reading into the various characters and background information.  You will however know much, much more by reading them and gain a clearer understanding of the fictional world that Geralt resides in and his relation to the characters.  The Witcher Saga is one of only a few favorite Medieval Fantasy series for me that I did not start reading until after playing the first game - its right up there with Tolkien or Game of Thrones.  I highly recommend them if you enjoy reading.  Basically it goes like this - The Witcher Saga books are like The Original Trilogy of Star Wars, while the games are the "Extended Universe" that are a continuation of the story.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I'm writing this in 2015, so the chances are if you haven't played "The Witcher" yet then you’re probably only going to be visiting this game because you’ve played a sequel and you’re interested to see what the original was like.This game is a superb story based RPG. It’s got intrigue, it’s got monsters and it’s got my favourite ever soundtrack for a game. You also get a TON of free stuff with the game, including a PDF guide and the previously mentioned soundtrack. There is a catch though, well 2 catches: the first is that it doesn’t look very good and the second is that the combat is terrible. Both of these things have been true since the game was released in 2006.If you are able to get through the tutorial and the first chapter of this game, which is no easy feat considering how horrendous the combat feels and how wooden some of the voice acting is – you’ll be able to get through the entire game, and you will love it. The Witcher asks an awful, awful lot from people who come to play it – but once you’ve committed for those first 3 hours, you’ll find youself caught up in the game world and the story more than anything else. There’s a real sense of momentum once things get going and this game really is best enjoyed in 5 or 6 binge sessions over the period of 2 weeks to a month – it’ll take about 30 hours to play through in total.If you read this and think that the time commitment required to play is too much, or you don’t think the mechanics are good enough for you, then fair enough. Just remember though, you’re missing out on this fairly intense game that has some really cool choices in it. Choices that you won’t find in any other game.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												This is the game that originated the meme Glorious PC Gaming Master Race[knowyourmeme.com]About ten years old, it aged quite well: the graphics still look good (of course, it's dated, but still good-looking); the combat gameplay is more challenging than the hacky Oblivion (released a year earlier); the story is decent and mature, albeit somewhat inconsistent with what The Witcher would become in the sequels. The writing can be quite silly at times, with many on-the-nose nods to the books, but the devs went on to poke fun at themselves for that kind of stuff in TW3. Still, the choices you make here actually matter: reactivity is a serious matter, which is the defining factor of a good RPG. One could also say it is open-world-ish, there's quite a bit to explore, quite a few NPCs to talk to.All in all, a fine first instalment for a series that would later redefine the fantasy genre.Note: I know many of you disagree about the combat, but compared to the mechanical and rhythmless combat of The Elder Scrolls: Oblivion (and even Skyrim, except for archery), the combat here does have a brilliant simplicity and paced sophistication to it. Once you get the hang of it, it becomes quite fun, especially in group attacks. All that said, if they had implemented a turn-based combat system like a classic isometric RPG, it would have been much better.Update: This review was based on the vanilla version. I'm now in the middle of a second playthrough with the Rise of the White Wolf plus some other mods, and I'm quite impressed.

'If I'm to choose between one evil and another, I'd rather not choose at all.'Geralt of Rivia___________________________________________________________________________________The amazing start of a great series. I already loved the books and I also love the game despite some flaws and rough edges. At first I just wanted to rush through it to get to 'Witcher 2', but in the end I still did all the sidequests, explored the maps, read all the journal entries and listened to the different dialogues. 'The Witcher' entertained me for nearly 40 hours until I was able to see the end in 'Normal Mode' and regarding the cheap price of 1,59€ during sales this money has been spent more than well.___________________________________________________________________________________Positive aspects of the game: + There is an interesting story with moral choices that leads to different parts of the story and outcomes.+ Many hidden secrets, sidequests and things to discover make exploring the maps feel worthwile.+ A great cast of characters.+ A very good length.Neutral aspects (o):o The graphics are quite 'good' regarding it's... a) ...the first game of a studio b) ...very longc) ...and nearly 8 years old (However some persons seem to be turned off by these mediocre graphics and the bulky systems. I think it's not that bad).o The voice acting changes between good and 'meh' (at least in the german version).Negative aspects (-):- The fighting system is a bit rough at the edges and even after 40 hours it was more annoying than entertaining, especially the feedback is nearly non-existant.- Many character models repeat themself over and over again.- Some animations seem awkward, right out of a puppet theater.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
A Fine RPG Whose Strengths Outweigh Its WeaknessesDate of Review: October 12, 2015 Nearly eight years ago, a Polish game design studio named CD Projekt RED released a new CRPG based off the book series by Andrzej Sapkowski. It was the studio's first released game. This game is The Witcher.After having The Witcher in my games library for a long time and seeing the strong reception its sequels have gotten, I decided not long ago to finally play it through, start to finish, as part of a greater plan to run through the entire Witcher trilogy. I'm glad I did. The Witcher is not without noticeable flaws, but is a decent game in my opinion.Very Different from Its SuccessorsI want to note early in this review that The Witcher is powered by a very heavily modified Aurora Engine - the same engine that powered Bioware and Obsidian's Neverwinter Nights games. CD Projekt has come a long way since 2007 and the more recent REDengine is a far cry from the aging Aurora. If someone comes from the second or third game to see where the series started, they might be in for some big surprises, as the interface and combat are very different from the sequels. It may take some time to get used to!Combat, Alchemy, and Item UseCombat in The Witcher has a great deal of depth to it, but its mechanics may not appeal to everyone, so I will explore it in detail.The Witcher's combat is fundamentally based on maintaining a mouse clicking rhythm in order to chain up attacks on a selected opponent. Each mouse click does not correspond to an individual swing but rather initiates an attack animation that may have multiple swings in it. Clicking at the right moments continues the chain and makes Geralt initiate increasingly elaborate and damaging attacks. Clicking at the wrong time or too rapidly will disrupt and reset the chain. Dodging and parrying are basically automatic. Although you can direct Geralt to spin past enemies or jump over them by double tapping a movement key, these maneuvers are generally more useful for getting into a better fighting position than actually evading an attack.The real complexity of The Witcher's combat comes from the various systems laid on top of the basic attack chaining, including choosing the correct weapon to fight your foes, choosing the right combat stances, using magic, and using alchemy. Geralt has silver and steel swords with different purposes and three different combat styles to chose from at any time: a strong style for fighting large opponents, a fast style for agile foes, and a group style for eliminating crowds of enemies in arcs all around him. Proper use of magic permits Geralt to stun opponents, set them on fire, or immobilize them with pain. It can even let him execute spectacular and brutal instant kill attacks in combination with his swordplay.The alchemy system is interesting and serves as one of the main reasons to loot opponents. Monsters almost never carry new weapons, but their organs can be used to make useful potions and bombs. Potions can last for several in-game hours, as do grindstones used to sharpen Geralt's swords, or oils created to temper his weapons versus specific foes. There is strong incentive to prepare heavily for combat long before entering it and to know your enemies' weaknesses in advance of fighting them. At its best, combat in The Witcher combines strategy and tactics with extremely satisfying results.Environments, Sound, Story, and ConsequencesThe Witcher is a game with beautiful environments and the modified Aurora engine actually does a good job of rendering both urban and wilderness maps. Overall the game world feels well crafted with praiseworthy attention to detail. I will note that I did see a few graphical oddities, but they ceased once I forced V-sync with my graphics card. In terms of sound, the game has some very well done music tracks that give a lot of life to the game world.As one probably expects, the best part of The Witcher is the story and how Geralt's actions affect his world. The plot is immersive and your actions do matter. One thing I really liked was that after making a major choice and eventually seeing the consequences, you would get a cutscene with an illustration of what has transpired in the style of a storybook. During the cutscene, Geralt will narrate on the effects of that choice, giving some insight into how this has affected the world. There's a decent number of these throughout the game, usually associated with major quests, and they were one of my favorite parts of the game. I also give special praise to the design of the chapter endings, which were universally strong and usually brought a climatic resolution to the plotlines that were devevloped throughout each chapter. I also felt that Geralt's dry wit was highly amusing, much as it rubbed some of the non-player characters the wrong way.There is also a decent sense of progression in the game as Geralt levels up, builds his identity, and relearns witcher magic. It does take time, as some of the upgrades the player can purchase on leveling up are relatively small, but it is very satisfying witnessing Geralt tear through hordes of opponents in the endgame after starting so humbly in the prologue.FlawsAlthough this is an overall positive review, The Witcher is not without noticeable flaws. Even though the environment is detailed, the placement of the world geometry on some of the maps, especially in the various swamp areas, can make traveling through them much more time consuming and annoying than it needed to be.For many, the biggest flaw will simply be the combat system. At its worst, the combat in The Witcher devolves into a dull repetition of waiting for the attack prompts to appear over and over. If one finds the rhythm based clicking and management of sword styles unappealing or was expecting control over the individual swings, blocks, and parries, their enjoyment of The Witcher's combat will be severely limited. Furthermore, there are occasionally oddities in hit detection and movement attributable to the mechanics of the Aurora engine. I did not let these hurt my experience, but I recognized them from having previously played the Neverwinter Nights series.And much as I praised the story overall earlier, the game does have some pacing problems. In my opinion, this was most noticeable in the early game. The prologue is excellent as the attack on Kaer Morhen serves as a good impetus for Geralt's quests, but chapters one and two can go very slowly at times. Both of them have excellent climaxes at the chapter endings, but the gameplay in the middle can sometimes feel like it is moving at a crawl with too much repetitive traveling through the same villages and swamps. This is compounded by some quest design problems, as I feel that a number of quests were executed somewhat badly, resulting in confusion, tedium, or both. There is also some uneven dialogue and subpar voice acting that simply does not match the quality of other parts of the game.All that said, I did not find these problems overwhelming and when the game really hit its stride, it was extremely compelling.Summa SummarumI really enjoyed The Witcher, but will also readily admit that it has its share of flaws. Provided one is forgiving of the game's rougher portions and is willing to put up with some aged mechanics, I do recommend this game.  It also sets up very nicely for import into Assassins of Kings for those interested in playing the entire trilogy from start to finish. I know I'm looking forward to continuing my game into the sequel and then into The Wild Hunt.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												After getting swept up in the Witcher 3 hype, I decided I would force myself to play the first two games first to get the whole story, because I'm usually a bit of a completionist. I'm glad I did, because this, the first Witcher game, has a few pretty amazing elements going for it. Don't get me wrong, this game has a lot of problems, some small, some pretty major, but its storytelling and world-building is so good that it's totally worth slogging through the issues. The Witcher is the story of Geralt of Rivia, a monster slayer who, despite his protestations of neutrality, becomes caught up in a four-way political struggle in and around the city of Vizima, the capital of the nation of Temeria. The factions are: the King of Temeria, Foltest, and his loyalists; the Squirrels, a group of non-human (i.e. elves, dwarves) freedom fighters/terrorists who despise humans' treatment of the elder races; the Order of the Flaming Rose, a trans-national group of jingoistic knights whose goal is to safeguard humanity at all costs; and a shadowy group of mages and assassins who attack the Witcher stronghold of Kaer Morhen at the beginning of the game and steal some of the Witchers' secret formulae and materials. Geralt sets out from Kaer Morhen in search of this group, but his quest for revenge thrusts him into the middle of the Viziman political struggle whether he likes it or not. With the exception of the prologue, the entire game takes place in Vizima and its immediate surroundings. (The furthest you travel is to a fishing village across the lake). This narrowness of focus is to the game's great benefit. So many developers attempt to make every RPG a globe-trotting adventure with enormous maps and hundreds of distinct locations. Given that this particular game was based on a popular series of novels, it's notable that CDPR managed to avoid the temptation to try to hit as many plot points from the novels as they could. Instead, the decided to focus on one particular locale and conflict, and in doing so, they've created a narrative in which subtlety and nuance can easily co-exist with monsters and mages. The smallness of the game world means that you'll spend much of your time in this game running around in the same general area and interacting with the same groups of people. While this may sound boring, what this actually does is create the opportunity for your choices to have time-delayed consequences that feel natural and unforced. When a few harsh words to a certain NPC come back to haunt you in a later chapter, the resolution feels realistic because that's typically how being a jerk in real life turns out. The way choices are presented to you also feels extremely natural. With one or two exceptions, major plot choices occur dynamically within conversations or battles without a big banner or dialogue popping up saying "Here's the big choice! You better think! You better make the choice right!" There's also no morality meter telling you where your choice might fall on the scale from good to bad. There's (usually) nobody screaming at you about how they'll remember what you've done. You just do things, and later other stuff happens because of it. The choice-based scripting is so subtle that you frequently might not even realize that the choice you made was a significant plot element. And that's great, because it's realistic. The combination of the natural, grounded scope and pace of the plot, and the unobtrusive decision-making system, makes the game feel immersive in a way that few other RPGs can match. In terms of its narrative, the game has another narrative strength: the conclusion. Without spoiling anything, I'll say only that if you're not paying close attention throughout the game, the conclusion may seem a little weak as it relies on a very "standard" twist of revealing the "true" enemy at the last second, then you have a fight, then yay! You win!But if you're paying attention, you'll see that the game's clearly hinting at another, far more mind-blowing revelation. CDPR never actually explicitly spells this twist out for you, but if you're paying attention, the truth behind the narrative is clear, and it makes the entire game ten times better. CDPR's choice to make the reveal subtle rather than explicit matches and enhances the naturalistic tone of the narrative and actually makes the player feel more connected to the game world. The ending leaves the player with this one dangling question, as well as numerous other marginally-resolved plot threads, but that's actually much more immersive than tying everything up neatly with a bow, like so many RPGs do. And I would still say this even if there weren't a sequel to the Witcher. The story feels like "just some stuff that happened during the history of this country" rather than feeling like some kind of apocalyptic endwar with an overly glib or final conclusion. After the end of the Witcher, life goes on. People are changed, but the world's still there. The world still would have been there even if you failed, but it would be different. At the risk of sounding dumb, that's so real - and that's what's amazing about it.----So I've gushed about the story for a huge amount of time now. What about the other stuff?Well, gameplay-wise, it's a mixed bag. Combat is just OK - not great, but also not so bad that it ruins the game. The swordplay is almost a proto-Arkham system in which you build up more powerful strikes by properly timing your button presses. You also have to make sure you're using the proper fighting style and weapon for each enemy you are facing, but this is just a matter of pausing the game and clicking on some icons in the HUD - the way you actually control the swordplay never varies. You can also use magical signs, which do things like burn or knock down enemies or create a temporary shield. Casting signs uses endurance (while swordplay does not) and your endurance pool is limited, so you can't really play as a pure caster (at least not until the late game). The combat is not particularly dynamic and does take some getting used to. I didn't find it to be particularly different on hard as it was on easy, so IMO this is a game that you shouldn't feel bad about just playing on easy to get through the story. They completely overhauled the combat system for Witcher 2, so getting good at Witcher 1 combat will not help you going forward in the series.The crafting and meditation systems are actually really cool. You can craft potions using alchemical ingredients. You can find or buy recipes for specific potions in the world, or you can just guess and make up mystery potions that might help you or hurt you. You can also substitute in similar (but not identical) ingredients into known potions that may slightly alter the effect of the potion. This level of flexibility with the alchemy - as if you were cooking in your own kitchen - adds another layer of realism and immersion to the game world.Now, the game does have some issues outside of the combat. For one thing, there are too many fetch quests and the quest log can occasionally break, leaving you with no idea what to do next. Also, the pacing in the first few chapters drags, with too much criss-crossing of the first few areas. Stick with it, though: I promise the payoff is worth it.I did have some issues getting this game to run properly on Windows 10. I had to use Borderless Gaming to get it to run stably. Also, I couldn't hold 60 fps in situations involving lots of NPCs. This is clearly an issue of poor CPU optimization: Much like Crysis, which came out the same year, this game seems to only use 1 core. I was usually seeing 100% usage on core 1 when the FPS dropped. I have an i5-3470 at nearly 4Ghz and a GTX 970, so my hardware is much newer than the game and should be enough - it's just clearly coded to only use one core.Overall, the game is astounding despite the issues. A must-play.

												I would like to say The Witcher is the first serious RPG I had played ( played Lord of The Rings Online because of friends ) , and I am really entertained by the vast lore.I suggest you play this game for the plot, as the battle system seems quite awkward. content:
Posted: February 4
												The game is worth your time and money if you can get past the clunky controls, outdated graphic with some weird and outdated characters animations, some ocasional game breaking bugs that forces you to load earlier saves to fix them. I recommend you to save a lot and never overwrite the saves so you have some backups in case these bugs occurs. Since there are no fast travel points , expect to walk a lot from house to house and village to village  ( you do unlock some sort of portal that allow you to teleport in some regions but thats at Chapter II)The game and story starts rather slow but if you have patience and pay atention at details and conversations it will get a lot better further after chapter 3. There are a lot of hard moral choices that affect the storyline and the way people/elves/dwarves interact to you so there can be a lot of replayability to see how each choice affects you and some characters. There are also some unexpected twists that Ill let you discover . Once you reach chapter III you will  get deep into politics and the things get really interesting. There are lots of rommance options that rewards you with some cards you can collect. Dont worry there are no consequinces if you jump from flower to flower. There are 2 major rommance options and you will have to choose between them.You will meet a lot of interesting characters with their own motivations , you will make firends that will help you remember some pieces of your history or enemies that will backstab you when you dont expect.I played this game long time ago and it was amazing, its still holds up nowdays if you can get past the things I mentioned at the beginning. The whole package is totally worth the money and for a Witcher fan or new players I totally recommend it.Have fun brothers and good luck  in your paths .

												La version française de ce commentaire se trouve après :)One of the best RPG I have played! Great game in most ways but it has his flaws like the fight system which not respond as quickly or accurate as it could be. But finally you get used to it ;o) Well, sometimes that doesn't do what exactly is supposed to as you have to choose the right sword first - depends if you fight a creature or a humanoid - and then you have to choose the style of your fight and here begin the trouble as sometimes you reach the target but finally that wasn't the good option and sometimes you had the good one but you missed every time.In fact that the biggest and mostly only complaint I have against this game. Every other aspect is great nonetheless: great scenario with quite a good bunch of third parties quest, nice ambiance music, graphic very well done (mostly when we know that is a 2008 game!), the dialogue system nicely put (you have to make a choice between the different option you get as it will have some impact for the rest of the game), the alchemic system not so difficult to understand and which could help you a lot and finally you had lots of information regarding the history/explanation of the different people you will meet during the game, the monsters, the places etc.So as you can imagine I warmly recommend this game for every gamers who like RPG, I'm sure you won't regret it!-------------------------Un des meilleurs RPG auquel j'ai joué!Un superbe jeu sur plusieurs plans malgré quelques défauts comme le système de combat qui ne répond pas aussi vite ou précisément que l'on souhaite. Mais on finit par s'y habituer :) Mais des fois cela ne fait pas exactement ce que c’est supposer faire du fait que vous devez d’abord choisir le bon type d’arme en premier – selon si vous devez vous battre contre une créature ou un humanoïde – et après vous devez choisir le style de combat et c’est là que les problèmes commencent car des fois vous arrivez à atteindre votre cible alors que ce ne sont pas les bonnes options choisies et des fois vous avez les bonnes options mais vous rater votre cible à chaque fois.Cela dit, c’est la plus grosse récrimination que j’aurais envers ce jeu. Tous les autres aspects sont excellents : un très bon scénario avec pas mal de quêtes annexes, excellente musique d’ambiance, graphique très bien fait (surtout quand on sait que c’est un jeu de 2008!), le système de dialogue bien mis en place (vous devez faire un choix entre les options que vous avez car cela aura de l’influence sur le reste du jeu), l’alchimie pas trop compliqué à comprendre et qui pourra beaucoup vous aider et enfin vous pouvez avoir beaucoup d’information à propos de l’histoire / explication des différents protagonistes que vous allez rencontrer durant le jeu, les monstres, les régions visitées etc.Donc comme vous pouvez l’imaginer je recommande chaudement ce jeu pour tous les amateurs de RPG, je suis sûr que vous ne le regretterez pas!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Had Moral Dilemmas: WingThe Witcher, this is the first part of the famous Trilogy made by Polish Studio CD Projekt RED, they were making Witcher Series, every four years (Witcher - 2007 ; Witcher 2 - 2011 ; Witcher 3 - 2015). This game is in my opinion definitely better than The Witcher 2 but, it won't beat Witcher 3, as for game from 2007, it's clean masterpiece.To feel the story, you must play it. Description says true "There is no Good or Evil, only your choices and their consequences". Every character is unique, but here's a tip from me, don't trust anyone fully. Let's show here few of them [BEWARE OF SPOILERS]:Triss Merigold - Sorceress, red-haired, cute but dangerous, she will help us even when she won't like usShani - Also red-haired, greatest medic in Vizima, had a crush on GeraltAlvin - Child, powerful, in his veins flows Elven Elder Blood, decision in mid-game = Give him to Shani or Triss, beware that one of them will be hating you, depends to which girl you'll deliver the childSiegfried - Knight from the Order of the Flaming Rose, depends on which side we'll hold, Order or Scoia'tael, if Order - he'll help us to the end, if Scoia'tael, he'll want to kill usKing of the Wild Hunt - (Who told there will be only Good characters?) - Unseen follows Geralt until the end, where we have a choice to fight with himJacob the Aldersberg, Great Master of Order of the Flaming Rose - He do not shows himself until end of the game, but from there, he is our enemy and main target to the end of the gameAzar Javed - Main Enemy until the near end, powerful Zerrikan mage, destroys Kaer Morhen, Witcher's homeBerengar - Witcher, we look for him about 60% of the game, he becomes our friend, he dies on fight with Azar but we are avenging him shortly afterVesemir, Eskel, Leo (dead in prologue), Lambert - Witchers, we see them only in prologue but we can identify with them in that short period of timeLet's talk here about few organisations in the game:Salamandra - main antagonist organisation, main chiefs are Azar Javed and Jacob de Aldersberg, they attack Kaer Morhen from Berengar information and steal Witchers Secrets, Geralt hunts them all game until all Secrets are safe.Order of the Flaming Rose - fanatics, Jacob de Aldersberg is the Great Master, one of 2 sides we can stand with in the gameScoia'tael - Elven rebels, killing humans to retrieve freedom, one of 2 sides we can stand with in the gameThere are much more organisations in the game, but these are the most importantLet's talk shortly about Combat System it's simple but satysfying - clicking mouse and respectively Z,X and C to change styles.SUMMARYGameplay - 10/10 - Masterpiece, one of those RPG games where you really want to know moreAudio - 9/10 - From simple ambients to combat music, it's climatic and awesomeGraphics - 7/10 - It's from 2007, but with few graphic mods it can be satysfying, but if you want to fully experience The Witcher, just play without themStory - 11/10 - Just too goodCharacters - 8/10 - Every one is unique, every one can either hate or like GeraltDifficulty (On normal) - Combat 6/10 - Simple and satysfying / Side-quests - 7/10 - There are hard quests, and easy quests, no grinding ;)OVERALL - 9/10 - It's piece of solid, good RPG, beginning of beautiful Trilogy based on Andrzej Sapkowski books, length is really good - It took me 32 hours to beat the game with doing every side quest I could, I completed the game with 38 lvl, pretty high as for that game, if you are doing side-quests, you shouldn't have any problems with Main StoryIf you are a fan of Witcher and didn't played that part or you look for part of solid RPG, just buy it, don't even think, just buy. You're still not convinced? Geralt had sex with 7 different girls during his journey, alright?Greetings, Wing

content:
Posted: January 23
												Short version:The Witcher has a lot of lore and a long and interesting story, Unfortunately the gameplay is very shallow and boring. Whether playing this game is worth it or not will depend on your personal preference. If you play games for the story or if you want to get into the witcher series, you might want to play this game, but i don't think that it is worth the effort.Long version:The Witcher's main problem is that it is an incredibly boring game. In this review i will be talking about the things that make the game so boring. If you are considering playing this game simply because you want to play The Witcher 2 and 3, i recommend that you read a recap and skip this game because it's simply not worth your time or money.The good:Lore: There's plenty of lore to be found in the dialogue, but most of it is in the journal. You can read about monsters, potions, plants, locations etc. Unfortunately, lore only makes a good game better, and it is not enough to make a bad game a worthwhile experience.Story: The Witcher has a pretty good story. There is a large cast of characters with different personalities and motivations, and the main character, Geralt, is very likable. Every choice that you make matters and affects the story and the way that other characters treat you. Sometimes it can be very slow, and some parts feel like they are unnecessary, but if you are not bothered by the terrible Combat system, it may be worth your while.The bad: Boring combat system: At first glance, The Witcher's combat system seems interesting. When fighting an enemy, you need to choose the correct type of sword (iron/ silver) and the correct fighting stance (strong/ fast/ group). But very quickly you realize how bad and boring it actually is. After choosing the correct sword and stance, you need to press LMB whenever your cursor turns into a sword, and thats about it. No skill or strategy involved. Sounds boring? because it is.  You can also dodge and use spells. I never figured out how to dodge properly, and i did just fine without dodging. While the spells are not as useless as dodging, they don't add enough to the combat to make it fun or interesting. It doesn't matter who you're fighting, every battle plays exactly the same. A few minutes after the game started, i was already bored because of the combat system.Boring side quests: There are two types of side quests: The first type is a contract that requires you to kill monsters and take their loot, and because of the combat system, this is already boring enough. But in order to loot a monster you need to unlock the corresponding bestiary entry, and in order to unlock the bestiary entry you need to read a book about said monster. But the game doesn't tell you where you can find that book. Sometimes you can buy it from a book store, and sometimes you need to talk to a random NPC in order to acquire it. Sounds like a huge waste of time? because it is. I spent a huge amount of time trying to figure out how to get a single book, and in the end i gave up and used the game's wiki. Apparently i needed to give food to some old lady in a town to get the book. How was i supposed to know that by myself?The second type of side quest requires you to play dice poker with other NPC's and win. Dice poker is like normal poker but with dice. The problem with dice poker is that it depends on your luck most of the time, and it can take you a lot of time until you actually win a game.The game also wastes a lot of your time. Walking from one quest to another will take a few minutes, and you will have to do so very frequently. Unlike a game such as skyrim, for example,  where the world is big and diverse, and whenever you travel from one quest to another you see new places that look and feel different (and you can also fast travel between locations that you already discovered, which saves a huge amount of time.), the world in this game is relatively small, and you will have to go to the same boring places over and over again. Unfortunately for you, the game has a very limited fast travel system, that only lets you travel between a few specific locations.In conclusion, The Witcher is an incredibly boring game that doesn't seem to care about your time. Its very unfortunate, because the story is pretty good.

number of helpful: 15 of 22 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14
												One could excuse the numerous faults in The Witcher on its age. But it's not that old really, and by RPG standards it's positively modern. Other RPGs from the era had solved much of the flagrant problems plaguing the game long before The Witcher was released. Chalk this up the CDProject's inexperience, which they gradually rectified as the series continued.PRESENTATIONFor its generation the graphics are passable. Nothing is breath taking and environments look like what they are supposed to look like. Characters are wooden, but facial animation technology was in its infancy in 2006. More problematic is the lack of variation. You'll find yourself in a cave/crypt, a meadow/swamp, and a town. That's about it. While The Witcher  aims for a dull, grim universe the lack of vibrancy in its settings takes a weary toll on the player.Voice acting is excellent. Geralt is probably the weakest link, with little emotional inflection beyond his gravelly tones. The supporting characters do an admirable job however.STORYThere's enough here to keep your interest, but like most RPGs you start to forget why you are chasing person X or McGuffin Y from the start. The constant side tracking makes you forget what the big picture was all about, or at least so distant it feels less significant than what it was. Characterization is good at least, and you'll develop an attachment to Geralt and many his companions.The 'grim fantasy' setting has been done to death since the release of The Witcher, and the conception here is not particularly original. It's Tolkein with swearing and nudity."Romance", a generous word for what amounts to a series of one-night stands, is superficial but is a lot more fun for the completionist than picking up arbitrary tokens. You are awarded a XXX card for each female 'conquest', a concept laudable only for the fact it would blow the minds of 2017's SJWs.GAMEPLAYAnd here's the rub. There's nothing fun about actually playing The Witcher. Everything from combat, to questing, to role playing, to conversation is utterly boring. Combat is as simple as left clicking on an enemy, Diablo style. While there's more timing involved, it still amounts to "Left click on what you want dead". Other distractions, like picking a type of sword as well as a stance adds an artificial layer of complexity that increases the tedium rather than the fun factor. Spells are cast with a right click, draining a mana bar that gradually refills. Spells are both limited and rote: A nuke, a trap, a stun, a shield, and a charm. Left click to attack and right click to cast a spell makes up 90% of your combat decisions, with the other 10% being potion and consumable usage.Consumables are gained through alchemy. Like most RPGs, Geralt will harvest materials from herbs, dead bodies, or from loot. However the limiting factor isn't raw materials but bottles of booze required to mix potions. This means you'll have tons of ingredients, but not enough alcohol to use it all. Second, while there are over a hundred harvestable ingredients they all are broken down into ~ 6 colors which are used in the recipe. That means your Ghoul's Blood is effectively the same thing as your Donkey Asses, it just takes up an extra inventory slot. It's a cumbersome system but not unworkable, and you'll be crafting a decent variety of potions for the more tricky encounters.Looting and inventory management is also a chore. Running out of inventory space is a constant problem. Worse, most everything you gather sells for almost nothing. But that's if you can even find a vendor. You can't just sell something to anyone if that merchant doesn't specialize in that item. What ends up happening is you either store stuff at the inn, never to be used again, or just trash the item in question. There's also no auto-looting after defeating enemies. Each corpse has to first be found on the ground (harder than it sounds), clicked on once to open the looting menu, and the clicked again to 'take all'. Clean up after a battle is tiresome, but fortunately as there's almost nothing of value you're likely to find and little of value you're likely to buy, you probably don't need it. If looting seems unfulfilling already, it gets worse. Geralt has 5 slots to equip items: A single armor piece, a silver and plain sword, and two rings. The rings offer no combat benefits at all. You will be lucky if you manage to find a single upgrade for any of the other slots throughout the entire game. Somehow an RPG was made in 2006 where upgrading your armor was an after thought, and it wasn't called Zelda.This may make progression seems impossible - how does your character get more powerful if not through items? Geralt does level up, and skills are distributed through familiar talent trees. Lower tier talents requires bronze points, and silver and gold are required for higher tiers. However gold and silver are far less common, meaning you will likely fill out all the lower tier skills and have to specialize in a select number of more advanced skills. This works reasonably well and you can tell the difference in Geralt's prowess as the game continues on.Where you see a lot less progression is with enemy encounters. Get ready to fight humanoids and lots of them. Human-fish things, Human-Zombie things, and Human-humans. There are some non-anthropomorphic creatures but fighting them isn't anymore interesting. A dearth of boss fights also saps the joy your encounters.Questing is no better. The environments are not especially large, but they are especially padded. Get ready to run across the same swamp and same town over and over ago. In a particularly egregious example, Geralt is instructed to go to point A, then return to point B, then return to point A, without any distraction in between. I think I know how they got their 20 hours of gameplay. The quest log is cumbersome as well, allowing tracking of only one quest at a time, with some quests providing no information as to where to complete them. Good luck locating that one wandering NPC without a minimap pip. Some quests are simply suspended until a trigger from another quest allows its completion, yet they still remain as active quests. And lastly, once a chapter concludes, which can happen without warning, you are unable to complete most active quests from that chapter.To its credit you occasionally get to make morally grey or mutually exclusive decisions. These choices do affect the story, but not with as many ripples as you'd expect. Still, it's always nice to see your choices make some impact on character interactions going forward.The Witcher was an ambitious project for a novice group. I can applaud what they were trying to do and what they eventually became. I just can't recommend this particular game when better RPGs from that time exist, namely Dragon Age, or even Neverwinter Nights.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												This game really brings a lot of classic RPG elements into the gameplay and story. As you expect the The Witcher is based on a book series written by the polish author Andrzej Sapkowski, so from the beginning the game already has a really large and well established lore to start with. The game puts you into the boots of Geralt of Rivia, a witcher that was trained since he was very young to become a badass monster slayer, but he is not doing it for free, you need to throw a couple of gold if you want your local atrocity to be dealt with. In terms of gameplay the game can be a little clunky but it's rewarding as well. Geralt is able to equip one of his two swords, more precisely the steel sword and the silver sword. The steel one is used for killing humans and the other one is for monsters. I still can't see how the silver one is not that effective against humans but I let that pass. Geralt will be able to explore a large open world with interesting characters and I will warn you, that there is a lot of dark comedic tone in pretty much all the dialogue but somehow it manages to give The Witcher the personality it strived for. The UI is gonna be very strange at first but will get used to it and it will never break immersion when you shuffle through your inventory for potions and recipes. The music and sound is pretty good and matches the medieval fantasy air that the game brings, but the voice acting is kinda less to be desired (apart from Geralt's voice actor that does a good job most the time).  On the bad note The Witcher suffers from the disease called "♥♥♥♥yourquesttracking"-ilia. Is not really easy to get all your quests managed when you can't find where the hell are you supposed to go or how many of "x" monster you have to kill to get "y" item so you can fetch it back to "z" NPC. Despite the many flaws The Witcher compensate with others unique features (like the Combat System, a simple but satisfying gimmick). It has been a really fun experience and I would recommend it only to people that enjoy a darker comedic tone a mature story and a nice 2000' RPG classic game.P.S. I don't like to give games that I review any grades or any other kind of number to mark their "worth" so I'll say that if you find yourself attracted towards a game, you should try it yourself first hand, before totally judging it from someone else POV.Always have fun gaming!

												The first witcher game in the popular series.Pros:Graphics still hold up today for a 2007 gameVoice acting is pretty good though im not sure about geralt's voice....User interface at first seems complex but very easy to use (apparently before a few updates it was bad)Combat at first also seems to be awkward but its not once you get use to it, ( to explain it, you click the mouse once and then wait for the cursor to flash yellow and click again, not hard at all)Story is really good as well as the side quests. Decent mini games with "Dice poker" and "Fist fights"Lots of interesting characters, monsters and areas.Cons:Game will not work on windows 10 (seems to run fine for the first few chapters, waiting for confirmation on the last few chapters)When you need to use the flame torch sometimes geralt randomly puts it away (annoying as hell in dark crypts and tombs) though you mainly use "cat" potions that allow you to see in the dark.Lots of people report random crashes which is most frequent on windows 10 as i mentioned although on chapter 5 i myself experience a few random crashes on windows 8.1 but they were very rare for me and didnt halt my playing experience.Overall decent action rpg game people tend to complain about the combat and user interface but i think these reviews that mention this were written before the "enhanced update" came into play, honestly no where near as bad as people are making out.7/10

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Oh, The Witcher. One of my favourite RPGs from now on.I had to admit, I could only play it through for the third time I started it, yet, I feel this is just something that everyone has to try out. At first glance, it may seem a little complex and boring (because of the alchemy stuff for example), but once you get into it, you just can't stop. The choices you have to make, actually make you think about the world in the game. I can say, that I totally got familiar with my character in the game, I was able to make choices that were really mine. The story sucks you in, and after  40-50 hours of gameplay, and finishing the game, you just still want more of it. And that's the time you buy The Witcher 2. :) Oh, and a good advice for newcomers to the game. Make sure you do a lot of alchemy, you'll need  it mostly in mid-game.I haven't played the second game, so I don't know how much the game got improved after this.Of course, The Witcher also has some negative aspects. Actually, it has a bunch of it, at first it may not seem like an AAA game, but believe me, it is. One of the worst aspect is the voice acting. I played it in Hungarian, which, in my opinion was  actually not that bad, but as I tried out the English version, I just couldn't stand it. Another little negative thing is, that sometimes you have to do a lot of running, between quest givers, or merchants to sell all the loot you just can't carry. One thing that troubled me about the story is, that in the beginning there's a lot of references in the game which you know nothing about, but by reading in-game books and talking to people, you can get to know a lot about The Witcher's lore.Regarding everything, as I already said above, this gem became one of my favourite RPGs of all time. Another good thing is, that you can import your saved games to The Witcher 2, however I don't know how much will it affect the second game, yet.If you read my review to this point, then I only have one more thing to say.Go, and play this game!

content:
Posted: February 22
												I find that the positive reviews for this game are either too glowing, or the negative reviews miss the mark or are simply the wrong kind of fussy.The graphics hold up fairly well.  You won't be walking through the Uncanny Valley with this title, but they more than do their job here.  Sound design is good too, though the game could have used more songs.  Every npc has reasonable voice acting.Lots of people argue for or against the combat system.  It is indeed a little clunky, but my argument is more about repetition.  Until you spend skill points (talents) in acquiring more moves in a set, you'll be viewing short, repeated sword animations for a long time.  I found the game too easy on Normal.  The pattern goes like this:  If it's a human, hit Q to use the steel sword.  If it's a monster, hit E to use the silver sword.  If it's a tough, single opponent, you hit Z.  If it's quick, you hit X.  And if there's more than one, you hit C.  Then you left click away with a brain-dead easy timing minigame of sorts. That's it.  You've got 1-5 for the Sign spells if you want to toss some variety in there, but by no stretch of the imagination is the game's combat difficult.  I fault the game for having very few explorable areas that are a little too small.  You'll feel somewhat confined the entire game.  However, the game flips this and gives you about 50 hours worth of quests.  That's right, quests.  Not superfluous grinding.  I do, to some degree, fault the game for having so many missable quests.  If you move on to a chapter finale before finishing some, they'll be locked off forever.  The game is a bit stingy with money for the first half.  Before you can harvest plants or monster parts, you need the knowledge.  Almost all of it you acquire by buying books from vendors, and this can be very expensive.  However, by Chapter 4 of 5, if you've been doing all the quests, you will have thousands upon thousands of oren (gold) with almost nothing to spend it on.  I found it strange in that there was surprisingly little loot for an rpg, and a surprisingly obnoxious number of potion ingredients that you can make potions, bombs, and blade oils out of.  If you're playing on Normal, hardly any of it is necessary.  By contrast, it is impossible to loot more than two weapons at a time, for any purpose, including selling.  If the cash didn't balance out so much in my favor for the latter third of the game, I would have griped about this. The skill trees are somewhat elaborate for leveling.  Four attributes, five signs, and 6 sword styles all with over a dozen nodes.  I don't believe you can max out everything in the game, but honestly the game will be done before you hit the cap anyway.  There is a dice poker mini-game, but I found it heavily rigged at the professional level.  The first tier before that can net you some early cash, but it's unnecessary in the end.    Should you read the books first?  Let me give you an example.  During one particular quest you're asked to find a lute that a character left behind after sleeping with a merchant's daughter (lol).  It's a simple matter to retrieve it, and the reward is miniscule.  In fact, this fetch quest is so inconsequential that you may be tempted to skip it entirely.  However, what you don't know is that in another life, Geralt and this character were tied up and after a lengthy philosophical discussion, were about to be executed by a band of homicidal elves before being spared by a local agricultural deity.  One of the elves gave this lute to your friend as a parting gift.  None of that has anything to do with this quest, but knowledge of the lute's origins gives the affair entirely new dimensions.  Such is the case with some characters and places in the game.  You could get by without the books, but you'd be missing a much richer experience.

content:
Posted: January 7
												Another gaming albatross drops from my neck. A very satisfying conclusion to a near decade-long pursuit, this game represents a phenomenal achievement, not only from a player's perspective but also that of a developer: a game that is fundamentally a modification of another game's engine (Neverwinter Night's "Aurora") and also what launched CD PROJEKT RED on the path to ultimate computer role-playing game domination in the Witcher 3: Wild Hunt.I wanted to finish this original entry to follow a policy I've had in place for several years now, that of not playing sequels until I'd finished the earlier versions. With the growing popularity of Wild Hunt, I felt a need to explore the world of Geralt of Rivia to its fullest.While this game doesn't quite merit a "5 star" rating, it is an excellent introduction to a very well-built and fleshed-out fantasy universe. The second chapter was what kept me from reaching the credit roll in a speedy manner: the plot gets twisted and the flow of the game interrupted by a sudden explosion of side-quests that serve more as distraction than direction. Once through the dreaded "swamp part", the game picks up momentum and becomes much easier to follow through to conclusion.As my policy is designed to provide, I feel playing the original first game in this series was very rewarding. I'm super-motivated to start the next game, Assassins of Kings, not only because of the depth of introduction received through this play-though, but also the fact that it ends [spoiler/not spoiler alert] in a cliffhanger.4 out of 5 mutagens

Posted: June 9, 2015
												I finally finished The Witcher after starting it over a year ago. I wanted to savour the mature storyline and it's richly detailed world. The game has 70+ hours if you do most of the sidequesting and you're trying to get all the girls (Yes, you can have sex with many of the women in the game - but all you get is the same blurry animation and a nude or seminude card of them). Hence you often get distracted from your main goal and the main story tends to become secondary to all your conquests.  The only problem with the Witcher is that because it is so long it tends to get repetitive, a lot of fetch quests and back and forth travelling (no fast travel) and specially the same NPC models returning for different characters on the new towns and villages. Even the enhanced edition feels like it could have been more polished with a few extra models (for old ladies and beggars for example - there's only one for each kind), even the women have limited models, you have the peasant woman, the town girl, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, the nun and of course the elves and druids but after 40 hours of gameplay you get tired of always finding the same innkeeper and women in each town. Nevertheless you will want to own this game just to watch the epic CGI opening and closing sequences and to try the rather original if not entirely satisfying combat system;  or, if you don't have the time, just try the flash parody game 'the ♥♥♥♥♥er', it basically gets the gist.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is the re-release edition of The Wticher with more content, revised and expanded dialogue, and unedited mature content that was censored in the North American edition (which is basically the "nudity" of romance cards if the player decides to have relationships with women). The Witcher is an immensive RPG game developed by CD Projekt RED, a famous Polish game company and its legacy for enhanced role playing mechanics. The game is less known in the United States, but got highly praised reviews for one of the greatest RPG in the decade. Unlike the majority of games in the market, The Witcher has a very complex story and excellent political intrigue that will grab your attention. While most RPG games has a clear distinction on moral choices between good and evil, The Witcher puts the player on tough choices to choose and have a direct impact to the storyline (without the importance of morality in the game) as many choices are in the shades of gray. This demonstrates that moral choices is not necessary to be in RPG games. In addition, The Witcher: Enhanced Edition has a very immersive soundtrack that will immediately seek your attention. There are plenty of side quests to do and certain decisions will affect the entire game and few major choices will go directly to its sequel, The Witcher 2. In the game, you play as Geralt of Rivia (known as the White Wolf) who seeks justice against the Salamandra who attack his camp, Kaer Morhen,  and kills one of his allies. While the Salamndra storyline is the main plot,  Geralt faced a society that is conflicted by two distinctive factions: The Order and the Scoia'tael. The Order is a specialzed human organization that cracksdown uprisings and use brute force to silence nonhuman insurgencies, but displays a change in reformation within the organization for tolerance. The other faction is the Scoia'tael, the nonhuman (dwarfs, elves, etc.) insurgent group that have the ideologies of independence and freedom for everyone, but their methods are unorthodox by putting so many members on suicide battles and radical methods to destroy human societies. Arguably, one of the best parts in The Witcher has to be the political intrigue in the main storyline.The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is a lengthy 40-60 hour game that immerses you with its beautiful soundtrack, complex choices and dialogue variety. A must purchase for any RPG gamer and become a Witcher fan.

Posted: September 29, 2016
												Hey! Well at this point there's not much to say about this game, but i still want to give my positive review, especially considered how many people actually say to skip this game and go to the sequels. While i think this game is a bit less fun and epic than some of the other western rpg (Gothic 2, Risen 2, Demon/Dark souls), this game is a great entry on the western rpg genre and a great start of an incredible saga. Long story short, do not believe anyone who tells you to skip this game. The two things i think are the strong point of this game are: 1) How polished this game is, no crashes, bugs, etc. 2) And this is a really interesting point that should be really adressed in a lot other games/ movies and books but i rarely see it mentioned/used (the only other game that comes to mind is Army of Two: the 40 day, and even there it's not as deep as in this game) it's that not only choices really matters but as in life sometimes every choice is wrong, and even an apparently wise choice is wrong. The only bad thing i found about this version of the game is that the "dlc" isn't worth it, there's two super short additional adventures from the developers, while all of the others are bad/boring mod like adventures from the community. I give this game a 7/10, be sure to play it.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												I have finished The Witcher Enhanced Edition yesterday, after 71 awesome hours of gameplay. During my playthrough, I really enjoyed the game and when I was not playing it, I was dreaming about playing it :). It is one of the best games and best story RPGs that I have played, it is really intense, has an awesome story, lovely progression system and a great game alltogether that really makes me feel awesome. Normally, I would be sad after finishing such a game. However, it is awesome that I had the possibility to import the save games in the Witcher 2 and the adventure will continue :D. You play the Game as Geralt of Rivia, one of the best warriors in the game world and also a witcher, belonging to a guild of monster slayers. The game takes you through beautiful medieval castles, cities and villages. The story is very intense and you have many decisions which affect the game and COMPLETELY change the main story. Some little sudden and seemingly insignificant decision somewhere in the game might have an effect in a further quest very close by, or maybe in the next chapter after 10 more hours of gameplay or maybe even towards the culmination of the story. I just loved how my decisions not only mattered but shaped the story in a completely different course to the other choices. This game is awesome. From a graphics point of view, the graphics are beautiful. I enjoyed seeing the big city of Temeria with all it's huts, medieval fortificantions, swamps, villages, beautiful fields and more. The game also runs smoothly, with no bugs. The combat is very awesome, very fun and addictive.  There are also many interesting things about it such as enhancing your weapons, preparing bombs, potions, using oils, magic. I really also loved how the game  has a discovery feeling to it. You encounter certain monsters in the wonderful world. Then you might hear a story about them or read a book about them to give you more information and tell you about some valuable ingredients for your potions that you can take from them. I really liked how nothing was random in this game, every monster species has its own purpose, own description, own location and time in which it appears, own secret book to find about them, own quest or quests involving them. After travelling in this game through such a fantastic fantasy filled with great characters, stories, lovely places (the city, fields and water will tell you of another gorgeous world which exists beyond our own), I feel awesome and will probably start the Witcher 2 today. Thank you, developers, 10/10, 100% recommended, one of the most beautiful games you ca play, like reading an awesome book or seeing a great, memorable movie, but here you are it's awesome hero.
