content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												Ah, The Witcher. I'll admit - I was one of the naysayers - I played this game a couple years back. Gave it an hour or two of my time. However I just couldn't get over the hurdle of combat. It didn't feel right, fruitlessly clicking to time your attacks. It felt clunky, disjointed. I tossed it into the backlog and thought nothing of it.I gave it a second chance recently, due to all the Witcher 3 hype, and am thoroughly glad I did. Yes, the terrible combat mechanics are still there, but they are not even nearly as bad as I thought them to be in my first attempt at playing. Behind all this lies a deep and engrossing storyline that makes you care about the characters and the areas in which you frequent. There are many choices in the game that change the course of the story as you go. Actions have consequences - it usually ends up as the lesser of two evils. The game has an overall 'dirty' feel to it - towns aren't entirely 'happy' and cheerful. You see things like racism, foul language, and general debauchery. You can even go so far as to sleep with many different women, who are more than happy to provide you 'trading cards' showing off their, ahem, assets. Its things like this however, that greatly set it apart from other RPGs, which is certainly welcoming as a lot of other games utilize the 'cookie cutter' approach far too often. Its good to be 'bold' with your games, and I highly respect companies like CD Projekt for doing so.The game has three difficulty settings - I recommend playing on hardest. It's really not all that hard, aside from a boss fight or two, but it makes you rely on using alchemy and potions, as well as utilizing sword stances and parries/dodging. It really brings out the best in the game and gives it a steady pace as you progress through it. At its core, the game plays like most other action RPGs, but you do have to time your mouse clicks to chain attack combos, which has notably been this game's biggest shortcoming. Otherwise, you have your typical potions and buffs/food, alchemy ingredients, and a few weapons here and there (you only swap armor literally once). The focus is less on the loot, more on the story. However the 'less is more' approach tends to lend more weight to the new items you acquire, and gives you a better appreciation of them.You can level up quite often, and the game has a skill tree where you can upgrade talents based on your traditional stats such as strength, dexterity, etc., as well as a few magical spells you use (you have a total of 5 spells, but they, much like the weapons I mentioned above, have more weight to them and are very useful). You can also upgrade your sword techniques from here. There are a multitude of potions you can craft, which result from collecting herbs and ingredients on your journeys. The key to fights are finding hints and literature before approaching most monsters, and preparing accordingly with potions or oils. Overall, The Witcher is a very well rounded game. Its graphics are older, but still hold up well today. It presents much of the same RPG elements but injects many other angles that make it unique and memorable. I definitely recommend this game if you have the time for it. It took me about 48 hours to beat (my time says 51, but I do not count the 2-3 hours from my original attempt a while ago). I didn't rush through it, did about 85-90% of side quests, and took my time. Enjoy it for the story, and remember that there's no wrong way to play this game. Live with your choices and press on. The story of Geralt of Rivia is an amazing one, and you won't regret it.

												The Witcher combines spectacular action and an intriguing storyline. You are a Witcher, a warrior who has been trained to fight since childhood, subjected to mutations and trials that have transformed you. You earn a living killing monsters, and are a member of a brotherhood founded long ago to protect people from werewolves, the undead, and a host of other beasts. The game's visual style and physics systems shoot for a high-powered blend of brutal action, complex RPG options and character configuration, and sweeping storytelling.

Posted: November 29, 2015
												So Witcher 2 and 3 came and they are great games so I decided to start the series with the very first.This game is old now but despite that I had a great experience all in all.You have the option to play mouse only but I was playing mouse and keyboard didn't bother with the other options,The graphics are really good, well made, the animations however are so so, my only issue was with the fighting system, it is outdated I hated it at first but when I got used to it I was kicking some striga♥♥♥♥♥with it, like when you understand the potions and how each opponent should be treated the fighting gets better no issues but still am glad they changed that in their next games. The most awesome thing in this game is the story, it is a long game there is much to do and you direct the story based on your decisions and they really really matter a lot towards how the game will develop, I made better decisions in this game then I do in my life, the story is that interesting!! Chapeter 4 was a bit boring I wanted to kill everybody burn the town and leave but I managed to get through and the next ones were really good.Another highlight for this game, you will get laid a lot, you will sleep with every girl from every race available in this game, if someone comes to you with a quest for his sister or any female you can satisfyingly prioritize that.As for the the general gameplay, you have the sword fighting you have your magic, potions and crafting are the most important thing to stay alive, you can play poker or fist fight to get money, you'll have plenty of side quests to level up and improve your character it is a really good rpg game and in the sales it drops to a really cheap price so if you've played the second and the third or planning to, you should really start with this one especially that the save data will carry on to the second and will give you some useful in game bonuses.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												The story in The Witcher is deep, the main character is amazing in his complexity (a moral code he created himself in order not to question himself, a neutrality he cannot maintain...), the dialogues are in my opinion even better than those in DA:O, there are changes happening in the world that made me totally immersed in the game. It made me want to read the books which are comparable to Terry Goodkind's The Sword of Truth and Robin Hobb's The Royal Assassin and I now want to have a computer able to run the second properly (and hopefully the third too). Story aside, some people say that the combat system is clunky ; it is not that bad, it's just different from what we are used to in other games but the good side is that it makes you need to look for ingredients and use alchemy to create elixirs and these are what makes Geralt what he is : a witcher, no longer truly human.It takes a few minutes to understand how the combat system works, with the different stances, the two main different weapons (one for humans, one for monsters) and the importance of adapting to each enemy.I recommend this for anyone willing to play the sequels or who is looking for a new quality book series (note that the stories from the books and from the games don't overlap and that there are many references to the books in the dialogues of the game).

content:
Posted: January 5
												Honestly, if you're looking to get into The Witcher series and you're really into lore, I'd start with this one. It's cheaper than TW3 and some of the story elements in TW3 mildly spoil this game, since you're role-playing as a dude who just woke up with no memory of recent events, and it's hard to do that if you already know the story. Anyways, that's just a pre-comment.+ amazing story, with an unexpected plot twist (unless you're an idiot like me and discover spoilers on the interwebs)+ your choices actually have a noticeable impact+ graphics are decent for a 10-year-old game+ hours and hours of entertainment+ very reasonably priced (I picked my copy up for £1 in a sale, but I'd be happy to pay up to £20 for this game)+ weird combat mechanics are fairly easy to learn+ kinda same as above, but the tutorial is pretty good at helping you figure out how to press buttons in the right order+ you can import your save file into TW2 so that some of your choices carry through (while I haven't played TW2 yet, I've heard that this doesn't actually change a huge amount in TW2)+ I personally found it really awesome how you NEEDED books to complete certain contracts or extract certain alchemy ingredients from plants, and that you need (quite a lot) of money to afford those books, so you often find yourself scrambling to put together a few coins so you can finish a mission, making this game more realistic (as opposed to being rich af and not even needing money like wtf even is poverty amirite?)- weird combat mechanics, particularly if you've just played one of the other Witcher games- some of the boss fights are particularly difficult, such as the chapter 1 boss fight where you get stunned and mauled every 5 seconds- unlike it's sequels, this game isn't open-world, so your passage within Temeria feels very limited. On the other hand, this helps to direct you to certain key locations, so this could be a good thing too I guess.- some of the chapters feel unnecessarily drawn out. Particularly chapter 4, where the quests involve a lot of running back and forth, and the main quest doesn't seem to contribute much to the story being told in chapters 0-3All in all, a fantastic game, especially considering that this is the first time CD Project ever made a videogame.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												The Witcher Enhanced Edition Director's Cut is an amazing RPG that honestly deserves a play-through for even the most casual RPG fans out there. In the world of Witcher (based on the fantasy novels of Polish writer, Andrzej Sapkowski) you play as renowned monster slayer Geralt of Rivia, who is thrust into a fight against the mysterious and hidden organization, Salamandra. In the game, not only is the fantasy setting well done with sufficient and detailed back-story to the game's world, the themes contained in the game are ones not usually seen (or portrayed as seriously and thought provoking) in fantasy video games today: Racism and the ambivalence of the choices we make in specific situations (basically how there really is no good or evil in a grand majority of our world, that all depends on the perspective we have). These two themes are showcased in the game's major political factions, The Scoia'tel (non-humans fighting for their rights) and the Order of the Flaming Rose (Knights who fight for the safety of the human population and persecute non-humans). The characters that you interact with as well are all fully fleshed out and developed, making your future choices all the more difficult, as you wonder how your allies will react.  The game's combat is also very unique for its time and in RPG's in general, instead of making it a turn based real time RPG, the combat is real time player controlled combat (basically you click on enemies to attack them, you control Geralt's movement, the enemy being attacked, the magical powers you use, etc.). It may sound overly complex the way I've described it, but its actually (in my opinion) really well done and fun to play. Especially with the ability to make alchemical potions to enhance your abilities in combat (like Blizzard, which makes you move and dodge faster and slows down time, allowing you to avoid damage, or Shrike, which deals damage to opponents during combat) adding in greater strategic complexity and detail. The game's soundtrack is serene at times, beautiful at others, and simply put, epic overall. Mixing in Irish folk flutes and drums with orchestral melodies and choruses to give the world that extra push towards total immersion for the player. (Plus the credits song is the best thing to wake up to.) Overall I'd say The Witcher, is a gem (not perfect however, with some technical issues; not too game breaking or annoying however) of a game, and a fine example of the power of video games to portray intellectual ideas and concepts with the same amount of depth shown in novels or films/TV shows/etc.  You really need to get this game!

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												I started playing this game back in 2015 because I've watched friends play The Witcher 2, and the Witcher 3; I thought the games looked fun and the story seemed interesting.After I started playing it, I really started enjoying it - I had to get used to the combat system, but I learned it quickly and had a blast in the game. It inspired me to start reading the books as well (I highly recommend them)A bit off-target in regards to the books, and why I recommend reading them as well (preferably before playing the games):- You will understand things so much clearer and will get the little references that are strewn throughout the game.- The books are amazing!Anyway... back to the game review:PROS:- The combat system was fun once I got used to it- The story is excellent- The world is really fleshed out; everywhere has a purpose and as do most people- Your choices actually matter and have a lasting effect on the world and people around youCONS:- The graphics are a bit dated, but don't let that stop you from playing this great game please!- The combat does take a bit of time to get used to - I've heard people call it dated as well- By the time I was halfway through chapter 2, I never wanted to see another swamp again... I saw more of the swamp... a lot more...- I didn't know about trophy quests until chapter 2, so I missed out on a powerful silver sword since I didn't kill them all... although this con ties into a pro about the choices having impact and fleshed out world... I just wasn't observant enough.Anyway, I finished this game about a month ago, and I'm about 1/6th done with the 4th book (The Time of Contempt), so now I'm playing the Witcher 2, which I will likely write a positive review for in like a year when I beat it.TL;DR: Do I recommend this? YES, very much so. It's worth full price, but you can probably get it for like... $2 soon.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Even back when it was first released The Witcher suffered from some questionable design decisions which could, especially in retrospective today, be seen as archaic but it would be a mistake to dismiss the game based on those few anomalies considering it most definitely still stands out as one of the more memorable RPGs of its type.Everything from extremely grounded world further reinforced by a story that does not, in fact, revolve around being some kind of a Chosen One destined to save the world or similar genre tripe, as well as fleshed out characters with actual agendas and flawed personalities of their own - it all plays perfectly into portraying a lived-in and believable setting which never really takes you out as you explore, from act to act, locations ranging from cruel outskirts to idyllic rural countryside. Mechanical systems like alchemy, character development and extensive documentation (journal, bestiary, etc) also help to immerse you in the world with their seamless integration as well as succeed at NOT being mere fluff as they often hold clues to making your life easier as you wander about doing some Witcher work.Sadly, it is precisely those mechanics where The Witcher somewhat falters. This could be attributed to the fact it’s powered by a heavily retooled, which was even then already old, Aurora engine simply not built for real-time so you have a strange hybrid combat system, but you cannot deny its combat is basically a glorified rhythm game at its core with some additional bells and whistles which you unlock along the way. Game may also seem slightly obtuse at certain points, but I maintain that’s mainly because it still is a product of its time and rewards attentiveness over incessant hand-holding.

												Alright. If you're going to play the Witcher series then you need to start here. You won't be able to go from playing Witcher 2 to playing this one. This has one of the worst combat systems I've ever played with. That said, the Witcher has the best lore in my opinion and I love this series. I don't really find the combat rewarding so I just play it on easy but it's got an amazing narrative and I've heard people say the voice acting is amateurish. SOME of the characters don't always read their lines in the way that you'd expect someone in their shoes to, but maybe that's just their character and the lore and story more than compensate for all the negatives.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												I like story centered games and The Witcher is a good example of a story told right. The choices and consequences system is well done, it adds replay value and it influences the ending. Also I like the fact that you can remain neutral throughout the whole flaming rose vs nonhuman conflict.The story kind of loses focus in chapter IV which i think is the weakest of all because it forces you to do some random quests that don't relate to the main storyline that much.On a bad side, I encountered several crashes on windows 10. The game uses the aurora engine which is known for its bugs and map limitations. It sucks that there are very few face models for NPCs, and that I cant customize Geralt at all (there are a total of three armors in the whole game).The combat is not that great but you get used to it and after a few hours of playtime it doesn't represent a problem anymore.In the end this is a very good lengthy RPG (it took me 44 hours with a few side quests done) with a mature tone and interesting storyline.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												I bought this when it came out and am playing it and Witcher 2 again to generate new save games for when Wild Hunt comes out because my old pc with my old games on it died.What can I say about this game that no other reviewer has said? Probably nothing. It's f4cking awesome!  (take that censorship!)Without a doubt one of the best crpgs ever made with a world that feels lived in, endlessly entertaining with wry and not-so-wry humor - "It's a Witcher. Hide your women!" and filled with choices that are not so well-defined, both in terms of morality and consequences in game. The combat is really not intended to be the center of the game. For many people it is the weakest aspect of this game. You are a very dangerous man and defeating most enemies is really child's play. Only the strongest of monsters and most skilled of humans are much of a bother, and those fights are won by planning and preparation, not button mashing. If you haven't played the Witcher and its sequel, you are missing out on what i think is the best storytelling and world-building in this generation of rpg's. It is very easy to become completely immersed in the game. The first time I played it I felt pulled along by the story and events in the game, compelled to play through to the end to see what happens. Playing it again years later I am still struck by just how great it is.Some games are fun. Some games are an experience. This game is one of the best experiences you can possibly have playing an rpg.

content:
Posted: April 22
												The Witcher is an excellent game with unique combat. To be honest, I regret having to play this recently, because I should've dont it a year ago back when I bought it during 2015 summer sale. This game will tell you the story for the Wild Hunt.Pro:- Good graphic for an old game, but character's animations are ok.- Good combat system, I like the combat in this game, it has strategy element to it. You have 3 styles for each swords, strong, fast and group, each style are for different enemies and situation. When you click once to attack, wait for sword icon to burn and then click it again to continue attacking, do this for 4 times (3 at first, until you get the neccessary skill).- Story, especially the surprise at the end and the epilogue ending- Sound & music are pretty good, I love the music when I was in the Village, its my favourite so far. - The world building in this game is quite huge, there are quite amount of lore you can read in the game, including Ciri's Father kingdom, eventhough the game doesnt tell you explicitly, you can find the info about her from the innkeeper in Chapter IV- Sex cards, its the art style that I like, not the boobs or the bootyCons:- The combat is not for everyone, I put it in cons because not everyone like the combat, in fact it was the reason I didnt play this game a year ago, but after you sink 5-7 hours, there is a chance you are going to like it- As I said before, animations are a bit off.- Combat animations, some are weird, even funny. Geralt can be look like a witcher who was born in a circus at some times.- Got 2-4 crashes while playing, but that didnt make me stop playingDespite the flaws, Witcher is one of the good old games. Get this if you're a Witcher fan.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												PROS:- Geralt's character development (with quite original method of talents)- potion making (includes picking of herbs, harvesting jaws of vampires etc.)- moral choices reflecting in changing attitudes of other characters- multitude of quests- some parts are really intense- deep, immersive story- nice music, beautiful landscapes, amazing architecture- seducing women is kind of fun- becoming master of dice poker and fist fighting is also kind of fun- original monstersMEH:- somewhere midgame you get a lot of bothersome "run here, talk, run there, talk" quests- you need to adjust to game's combat system- first 30-90 minutes of the game are kind of boringCONS:- you don't get to use many weapons or armors, because other weapons than swords are not usable in witcher battle styles making them ineffective especially later in the game- after you start feeling which skills are important and focus on developing them, fighting becomes quite easyOverall: you need to bite the bullet and endure the first hour of the game. After that you get a really good, immersive RPG with damn good story and lots of locations.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
Note: No doubt you've noticed my hours but I played this with the FCR & Rise of the White Wolf mods installed, which Steam apparently doesn't recognise. Total playtime at the time of writing this is about 40 hours, give or take.Provided that you can stick out the massive grind at the start, you'll get hooked quite easily on this. Design, in most respects, holds itself quite well even after all these years and I do recommend playing this if you're planning to get into the Witcher series or have played the other games. - The story is quite good though fairly limited in location and the amount of sex avaliable will leave you wondering why Geralt hasn't had a heart attack from all that action. - The developer's decision to use the world of Andrzej Sapkowski's beloved books was a brilliant idea and they've done a superb job of recreating the characters, atmosphere and setting. - The combat and voice acting are the weaker parts of the game with the latter being often irritating to listen to. - Nevertheless, this is still an extraordinary achievement for it's time and surprisingly addictive.The Witcher: Enhanced Edition certainly isn't perfect but the debut for CD Projekt Red remains one of the most immersive RPGs to date and a worthy entry in the series and your library.

Posted: January 25, 2011
												I hate medieval RPG's. Consider them to be child-ish, its﻿ always like "yeah im going to help everybody with their problems just cos im a white knight--- Oh noes! a choice! what should i do, kill the good guy and become evil or save the princess and be the hero? boy that sure is a tough choice, not to mention the crappy combat on games like "Dragon Age" where you have to pause all the time and♥♥♥♥♥♥.. and then The Witcher came in, told me to STFU and hooked me with more than 50 hours of awesomenes. Fluid combat (no need to pause or take turns), a deep story where you have to think, its all shades of gray so if you're looking for a "white knight tale" better skip this one. Decent enough graphics/voice acting/animations to keep you immersed. But as i said before, i usually dont like medieval RPG, its clear this game is different so it may not be for everyone.

Neutral: This first instalment in the Witcher series is something of a flawed gem: a good story well-told that suffers at the hands of it's needless complexity and poor combat system.  It seems to mistake complexity for quality in many aspects, creating an overly complicated series of mechanics that ultimately end up resembling a Rube Goldberg machine.  Nonetheless, an above-average plot and some decent character writing help buoy the Witcher to be a worthwhile CRPG if you can stomach the complexity and insubstantial combat.Read the full review here[www.highlandarrow.com]

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												What can be said about the Witcher?Well, you can clearly see it is a "first game" for CDprojekt Red. It uses the Aurora engine, Neverwinter Nights good old engine.  What they did with the engine is kind of magic if you compare how fugly NWN is (The Engine do have its own charm although) The big fuss people have is the combat but  I find one get used to it. Nor is it just QTE, magic, potions and positioning is of importance.The models are not the greatest and reused but the characters are not bad, the story is not bad. It is a great build up to Witcher 2 and even if some quests are "gather 10 wolf balls and bring them to me" but it kinda fit the team of being the monster hunting Witcher. And the drop rate is usually 100% so you do not have to kill 40 wolves to get 10 wolf balls. So I can live with it. I believe I almost finished all the quest and I did complain a lot. But it is more of a "Damn I want to play Witcher 2". Since I did finish the game and explored all corners of the map and gathered my wolf pelts, basilisk scales and drowner brains everywhere. If one like RPGs with a bit of a darker tone to it  (You can simply not please every side) and can stand the combat  it is worth it. The game is a good bridge into Witcher 2 and the world is big. Many  areas are super cozy and even with this engine they manage to pull them off as appealing and vibrant. Lot of NPC just going by their day. ♥♥♥♥ the swamps although, that is a big area but in the end you get used to it. It is not the strongest game made, it got flaws but it is also a charming, strong game that can stand on its own. A first game from a small Polish studio, so it is hard to be overly judgemental on it.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												The Witcher is a difficult game to get into at first because of its very simple, clunky combat and the lower budget than the sequels, it is a dated game in a lot of areas. However if you stick with the game and get past the shortcomings this is a very rewarding game. The very strong story, characters and lore hold this game up so well especially when you get over the halfway point and you have learned about the world and the characters close to geralt and geralt himself. You also start visiting some very interesting and memorable locations. It does an amazing job of introducing you to everything, they even used the cliche of geralt losing his memory so you have an excuse to learn everything about the world. The game does a great job of getting you invested in this world once you learn about it, I did not want to put the game down the more I played because I was so invested into everything that was going on. It has one of the best stories and character development I’ve ever seen in a game and I’m expecting much more of that in the sequels. A lot of twists and turns throughout the story and I love the choices the game presents and some of them are not easy to decide and are thought provoking at times. Most people that have tried this game are not willing to get to that point which is a shame because they are really missing out. I want to point out that the combat is not bad it’s very enjoyable at times but it’s not really deep or interesting. The clunky and stiff character animations make it hard to get immersed into the combat at times as well. The way characters interact with each other during conversations doesn’t feel natural but I was able to get past that because the dialogue is so interesting. The game got me really excited to play the sequels because this was my first experience with a witcher game and I can’t wait to experience more story and learn more about this world and these very interesting characters. I think that this game is a must play for rpg fans they just need to be very patient with it.  8/10 (Great)

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Still a good looking game despite its age. The additions of "enhanced" and "directors cut" solve all the problems of the early release whilst improving many aspects of the game. I remember when it first came out there were floods of complaints about very slow loading screens and there are no such issues now. The game itself is a perfect example of an rpg with heavy action elements. The storyline is as absorbing as it ever was and the characters are memorable. Despite the rave reviews of W2 I, personally, feel this original was superior. The Witcher feels far less of an on-rails series of action segments linking cutscenes than does The Assassin of Kings which, to me, felt more like a console rpg with its set progression and boss fights. Regardless of what you think of any of the 3 games there is something to be said for the increased immersion that can be had from playing them in their original order and that is why I am revisiting this aging classic and its sequel before doing much with the gorgeous looking Wild Hunt. I think those going back to this will be surprised and delighted at how well it has weathered and that there is no better place to start for those new to the now legendary series.*edit* I also remember that there was some outcry over the "sex cards" at the time of release. Compare this to the abject voyeurism in sections of W3 and it will make you realise how times have changed. As far as I'm concerned if a game has an age rating you may as well make good use of it; and in no small way The Witcher contributed to paving the way to the many adult orientated games we see today.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												The fact that this is one of the better cRPGs released in the last 10 years mainly speaks to the fact that there are very few good cRPGs. The graphics are nice, and there's lots to do, but almost everything is either very uneven or downright poor.Combat, after you get used to the "rhythm game" style is very repetitive, and by mid-game poses absolutely zero challenge since certain powers are so stupidly overpowered. Enemies give diminishing XP, so there's thankfully no real reason to fight most of them since little fun is provided. Since you never really have a party to work with, all strategy is eliminated, which I think is why they added the rhythm element to try and add some sort of depth. They failed. After the first act of trying things out, combat is never really engaging or fun. Fire spells are so stupidly overpowered that by midgame, it's basically a "win" button on medium difficulty.The story of the game is also super uneven. Feels like a handful of good ideas that were screwed up by people completely inexperienced in writing a screenplay. Dialogue is uneven and not helped by mostly below average voice acting, and lots of plot threads just kind of lurch back and forth with bad pacing. The "big twist" in the game doesn't happen until the Epilogue and is both crappy and comes too late. I honestly didn't care about the character involved and the reasoning behind it made zero logical sense. The makers have obviously tried to make choice a "shades of gray" kind of thing with both sides you can choose between basically being ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and unlikeable. The humans are racists who are killing and stealing from the elves and dwarves and putting them in ghettos, while the elves and dwarves retaliate by murdering civilian families.... and you have to pick a side that ultimately will have very little effect on the grand scheme of things. Every time you do something that seems obviously humane, they have to stick something in there to make sure there really was no "good guy" option.Certain characters that I assume come from the source books show up and play key roles. They get little to no backstory (since you already know them!), so unless you've read the books (i didn't), you will have little attachment to them even though the game treats them like they're your dear old friends. Not helped by really bored voice actors. The other characters don't get much backstory, so you won't get attached to any of them either. Dialogue is really uneven, and characters' motivations, including the main character, are all in all very poorly handled and it really seems amateurish.The makers shoehorned lots of sex into the game, so basically if you don't explicity tell every female character that you don't want to have sex with them, you'll be shown a still picture of them naked. Most of the time, the naked still drawing doesn't look like their in-game model. I guess that's supposed to give the game a "mature" theme, but I just found it to be weird.There's an ok quantity of loot in the form of craftable potions and buffs, but you'll probably upgrade your weapons 2-4 times and armor twice in the course of the game. Potions really aren't necessary on normal difficulty. Inventory management is just a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ You have space to hold about 94% of the game's different crafting materials a ta time. Why not 100%, really? Bad design. There's one item in the game you'll have to save up money for, and once you've done that, take my advice and don't bother hoarding food or treasure items. No point, really.Quest structure is the most frustrating part of this game. There's not really any fast travel. Each act takes place over 3-4 relatively small "zones". Most quests involve "go 2 zones over, get something, and then come back here before going back 2 zones over and coming back again". Most questgivers start indoors, so going 2 zones over generally means 3-4 loading screens each way plus some walking. There isn't much to do besides the main quest and a small number of side quests, so doing a few quests at the same time and multitasking your trips to different zones really isn't an option. It took me 40 hours to play through the game, but I felt like if there was a decent fast travel system, even one that just let you teleport to the start of each zone after you've visited each once, the game probably only would have taken 25-40 hours. Literally 25-35% of game time felt like meaningless jogging between quest markers and load screens.I should also say that if you hated Dragon Age 2's running around in the city, that you spend over half of this game in one city, which is much much smaller and has much much less to do than Kirkwall did. The game looks nice and the setting is generally good (the glaring excepting being when they shoehorn the lady of the lake/holy grail/excalibur legend into the game which really smashes immersion), and the music is quite strong. In all, I'd still actually recommend this game IF AND ONLY IF you haven't already played:Dragon Age 1 + 2Baldur's Gate 1 + 2Icewind Dale 1 + 2Elder Scrolls 3 + 4 + 5The Divinity SeriesNeverwinter Nights 2 + ModulesArcanum(maybe Neverwinter Nights 1 + expansions as well)They are all better cRPGs that are in fantasy settings, and are basically better in all gameplay and story aspects other than graphics.I'm going to play Witcher 2 next, which might end up making me appreciate Witcher 1 more (or not.)

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
 An incredible game, but only for certain kinds of RPG fansI loved this game. But I wouldn't recommend it if you are only into modern games with technically amazing graphics and fast-paced, streamlined gameplay. Instead, I would skip right to the Witcher 3. I also wouldn't recommend it if you don't have 40-80 hours or more to dedicate to playing, because it is not a short game even if you were to ignore most of the side-quests.But if you have a fond history with games like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, or Morrowind... get this game now!Even though it came out in 2007, it plays more like an RPG from an older era. Clunky best describes most aspects of the gameplay. The combat is based on timed clicks, which feels like something that you would have done in the 90s. The inventory and menu screens are a confusing mess at times. You have to look at your map often because there is no quest arrow constantly holding your hand. At times the combat feels super repetitive and there are parts of the game where you are grinding and nothing more. Also, the game is demanding and does not hold your hand with its difficulty level. You will die a lot.The main reason to play this game is the story content. Despite living in lifeless models (many of which are reused with barely any changes), almost every character is memorable. The Witcher's lore is deep, aided by a fantastic book series, and this only adds to it. The voice acting can be cheesy in parts, but in a charming way. You will feel a kinship with your allies and real hate for your foes in this game. Very rarely did I find any dialogue to be boring.The story is also told through some fantastic quests. The main quest has tons of mystery and surprising turns that keep you engaged. With this are some side-quests that are absolutely hilariously entertaining. Let's just say that Geralt gets into the kind of mischief that other fantasy heroes would stay far away from. He isn't one to turn down a drink in a tavern. Anyway, while there are plenty of fetch quests too, even those tend to have some interesting story element to them.Also, the graphics and music are awesome. While the graphics show aged textures and models, they still have a certain appeal. Each area is dripping with its own distinct atmosphere. From caves and swamps to bustling towns and creepy temples, you really get a sense for the geography of Vizima and it will feel like a place you actually visited. The music has an epic celtic folk feel. I can't think of a single moment where the music playing wasn't a perfect fit for my surroundings.In summary, if you want an easier pick-up-and-play experience and cheap entertainment, this game won't give you that. But if you are an ambitious fantasy gamer who is tolerant of flaws, and motivated to have a great old-school RPG experience, this is a great game for you. It also sets the stage for two other fantastic games which improved on the original in almost every way.

I am still thumping this old game up, cos there is no undecided option. Just be aware that it might not run stable on your pc.

Posted: November 22, 2015
												Just a short review.... actually my first one....I played Witcher 3 a few months ago and was wondering if I should play witcher 1. At first I tought I shouldn´t, but I´m glad I did play it. At first it seemed really strange, specially the combat, but I got used to it. It feels like an older game, as it should, but it was very enjoyable and gave me a lot of background on the witcher story. Characters are good, voice acting is Ok and it was a much better experience than I was expecting. Graphics are good for the time, but of course the characters seem a bit "dolly", although the environment looks really good. Sometimes quests feel a bit like a chore... go there, come back, go there again, come back again, etc.... games nowadays have less of these "tricks" to make it longer, since they´re huge anyway.  The story is good and I´m glad I did play it! So if you like the witcher and was wondering if you should play this.... go for it. Give it a shot! You´ll get used to it after the beginning and I think you´ll enjoy it, if you´re in for the story.I´m now playing witcher 2 now, and I´m glad I played this one first.

Posted: February 5, 2016
												This game is incredible. It has all the Witcher lore and characters that any fan would love. The gameplay and the user interface aren't brilliant, so be prepared to deal with that. Apart from that everything else is great. It has that sort of hardcore old school RPG feel to it where the game gives you minimal guidance and leaves you to do most of the thinking to very, nowadays, extreme levels. I wouldn't recommend it as an introduction to the Witcher universe unless you're into that hardcore old school style of RPGs. I would recommend, instead, either reading one or more of the books or playing the second game. It is much easier to fall in love with this universe if you do that and this specific game becomes a lot better once you do.Overall it is an incredible game and a must play for any Witcher fan.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												I started this game three times before I finally made it past the tutorial phase at the beginning.  The tutorial was just so slow and cliché that I lost interest each time.  But, seeing the good reviews of The Witcher 3, I figured I had better go back and play 1 and 2.  So, I finally played through the whole game and finished almost every quest.  It's a solid RPG once you get past the tutorial/intro.  A bit dated graphically by today's standards, but you get used to it and it's really not bad since everything is voiced and the voice acting is pretty good.  There are a few good plot twists and solid, immersive worlds.  Nice integration of ambiguous ethical choices and "adult situations", although at times both can seem a bit forced.  Still, a worthwhile experience and a good story.The combat is OK, decent considering how old the game is and the engine that they were using.  Combat is way more fun if you level up a few magic skills so that you can do some magic combos.  Particularly, the powerful fire magic combined with "group" sword styles is really fun.The menus and quest tracking work pretty well too.  Not perfect, but overall very good.  There are a few mods out there which rework the interface if you're looking for something a bit more modern without all the graphic flair.I definitely recommend getting a movement-speed mod for this game, which can easily be found on the Nexus site.  Otherwise you will spend a LOT of extra time just jogging from place to place with not much happening in between except a few monster battles.  A lot of the side-quests are go-fetch quests, so if you want to complete all those you will spend a lot of time jogging and running errands.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Great game, still holds up after 7 years. It can get tedious at times (I'm looking at you Chapter II) but the great story and the consequences of your choices make up for that.It's also a great time-sink. One playthrough as a Sign focused witcher took me almost 70 hours. The combat near the end was ridiculously easy thanks to maxed out Igni and Aard signs. Will play through the game again as a bloodthirsty swordsman just to experience that side of the game, too. I bet it will feel like a completely different game.Another great thing is that you can import your saves to the second game and see the results of your actions.All in all, if you're looking for a good old RPG with lots to offer, you should definitely play this game.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Story: The story in this RPG is surprisenly good and honestly reminds me of Game Of Thrones (Dark, gory and lots of sex) though it has a lot more fantasy in it. There are some problems with it like characters acting completly different than what they were a chapter ago or, something that makes no sense, the prologue rushing you, and chapter 1 being boring as heck but still the story was really good. 8/10Graphics: The graphics here are pretty okay to be honest, some textures though are definitely dated, and the character models and textures are dated as well. 7/10Gameplay: Here we go and I'm gonna say it to get it out of my system.....the combat is mediocere, there I said. The combat is just for show with it's animations, there's nothing strategic about it just click till you hit some combos and that's it. Also let's not forget that chapter 1 really dragged on the whole going back and forth to your objective. Overall the gameplay is mediocere at best. 6/10New Adventures: Honestly I wouldn't recommend these, these were made on the adventure editor and there's no voice acting and it really isn't that long.Overall: While Witcher 1 has a really great story, the going back and forth from the quests and mediocere combat may stop you from buying this. 7.5/10Recommended price to buy: Full price or wait for sale.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												Original 2007 review is included below.2015 ReviewWhile the incredible story and masterpiece of worldbuilding remain quite intact, a few things a very dated and don't quite survive the years. If you are dedicated enough to pick up the game these days, you'll want a few things: Full Combat Rebalance Mod (glitchy, but not moreoso than the original game). The witcher wikia for when you get stuck. Because you will, on a stupid and poorly worded quest. A very large amount of free time. An obsessive love of consumables. An insane amount of patience. I almost broke my keyboard a couple times.Unlike modern games, the movement and comb at systems are very unforgiving and do not hold your hand. You'll want to spend some decent time "grinding", or killing creatures over and over until you are comfortable with the gameplay. On harder difficulties, there's really no way to handle many scenarios unless you have thoroughl explored and completed each and every quest, and on that note been lucky enough to not have locked away rewards behind a poor choice or questline started too early.You'll also need to rely heavily on consumables and an inventory strategy at all times - management and planning because a mini-game all in itself which could be a turn off for some players and a joy for others. All in all, the Witcher 1 still retains its shine and stands out boldy from the other games of its time period - this is the game where CDPR showed Bioware how to use its own engine fully, and did it better.2007 ReviewWhile other RPG's are in a race downhill to appeal to the lowest common denominator, the Witcher proudly shouts a few obscenities and then descends into a tub of bloodbaths. The dialogue may leave a little to be desired, it can be forgiven thanks to the vast and powerful storyline with twists and turns worthy of any 5 star RPG. Also, that its translated from Polish, so there's that.The mythology of the Witcher world itself is heavily rooted in Scandinavian and specifically Polish culture and it really shines through. Brutal and murderous takes on every fantasy tropes are there in there ancient yet recognizable form, lurking, waiting to be turned into alchemical componds and pricey trophies.The combat is frustating at points to be sure, but it can be compensated for by reading up on monsters in your codex. The game heavily relies on you exploring and learning every last detail, not to mention taking advantage of its fully fleshed out alchemy system coupled with a medium to small inventory for the amount of items in the world.Honestly, even with its faults, the Witcher is my 2007 game of the year. Sorry BioShock and Crysis, you'll need to fight over second place.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Like:+ the story,it's very engaging and deep, got me hooked. + that you have choices which can affect things later on, making you often question if you should of made that decision.+ Main characters are memorable. + the fist fighting and poker playing.+ I think the graphics are quite good.Dislike:- Combat is terrible, click enemy wait for sword to glow, click again succeed and repeat or fail and start again.at first didn't like how the combat felt, but after getting used to it past the first boss, it doesn't seem too bad and is worth putting up with as the story is good. And once you start getting combo's into the 3's to 5's it's quite fun to watch Geralt do elaborate multiple swings and backflips.-Not fond of the easy, trashy women, every woman I come across in the game wants Geralt. None of them seem to have any morals or respect for themselves. And don't have old fashion values of courting, romance or being wooed properly.-Monster hunting side quests a bit boring and repetitive.-some quests have a lot of back tracking with no quick way to travel. -inventory is so small with no way to expand it.-unimportant NPC's have many replica's such as old peasant women all look the same, the merchants all are fat richly robed etc.-A bit too linear, can't go back to previous areas.-A bit disapointed at the end to obviously what Alvin has become in the future.-even playing on normal mode, didn't need alchemy much, mostly just used swallow, Cat, white rafford's Decoction and the occasional oil coating. Didn't bother with bombs.-With the signs only used Aard for knockback and Igni for Incineration, didn't find the others that useful or necessary. Despite the things I didn't like, I definitely reccomend this game, especially for those who like RPG's and a good story. This game to me is a must play. 7/10 Not worthy of an 8 as the combat is rather clunky and not very good.

												This game is absolutely awesome.  I was never bothered about Witcher when it first came out or even when others mentioned it.   When i saw the trailer for The Witcher 3 i was blown away and straight away thought this is going to be right up my street (RPG fan), so i bought 1 & 2.From the start of Witcher the story is a little hazy and for some reason it doesn't grab you right away.  A bit of advise:  Stick with it!  After about 3 hours in the story begins to unfold and the gameplay really picks up.  As you play more and more the more additive is becomes.  The story is just brilliant and really draws you in.  I was really surprised how i was so into it and how i just wanted to play more and more to unfold more of the story and path i had chosen.  The path you choose is up to you, choose wisely on what you do and who you go with, it all matters in the end.  If you are looking for a good RPG, then this a great game to play and you won't be disappointed.  Just great!Feel epic when you complete:-)

content:
Posted: March 2
												Ahh... The Witcher, a compelling story following the amnesiac Geralt. This is the first game in the trilogy of The Witcher and sets you up with not many guidelines. The ongoing question is "Who is Geralt" and is a big focus of the game despite it being recognised as a sidequest. Because you're not told who Geralt really is you get to choose options depending on what you want instead of what "Geralt" wants, this marks the RPG aspect, as you get to choose more or less who Geralt actually is. |Geography| 72/100The Witcher is also set in the beutiful world of "The Continent", and yes there is mostly swamplands around for three whole chapters of the game, but they also mix in other places like: Vizima (Which is a big focus of the game), The Outskirts of Vizima (The starting point of the game and where you really get into the world of The Witcher), Lakeside and the Fields (This is my personal favorite as it is quite diffirent from the other locations and introduces a few minor character that are still slightly important which is very fun to see)|Lore| 76/100The Witcher contains a lot of lore, and even if you haven't read the books or know anything about it you get to learn all that in due time, a little problem is that a lot of things gets explained through sidequests and while I do recommend doing the sidequests everyone won't and therefore won't hear everything that there is to offer. I think that you really have to do EVERYTHING to enjoy the absolute most, reading in the books and similar is also very interesting and fun. |Characters| 85/100This is hands down one of my favorite parts of the game, it has a lot of interesting characters that have their own personality. Not only that but you get to choose some over other depending on what you want, this very Interesting and can really change the future of the game for you. This is as I said only the first part of the trilogy and if you play all the games you will get to know a lot of characters and expand your view of previous ones.|Story| 63/100The story is a little complicated for me, because I do enjoy looking around for the group named Salamandra and really finding out a lot more about them (the ending is really fascinating) but I feel somewhat thrown in to it. Salamandra who is the main focus of the game has little connection to Geralt, which is a little dissapointing, they pursue their goals out of own interest and except for the fact that you think they are evil you don't neccesarily care a lot about them. Yeah, maybe they make you a little upset in the beginning but still I remain with my words.|Combat| 38/100This might be the biggest flaw of The Witcher, the combat is not very interesting, it really feels like a passive combat system where you time one button click awaiting the enemies death, I do appreciate them adding diffirent type of attacks like the group attack (though it became more and more useless as the game progressed.) Buffing yourself and buying armor felt kind of off and while I think the economy works decently it didn't feel worth it.  I will say though that CD PROJECT RED really stepped up and made a truly beautiful combat system in the end with The Witcher 3: Wild HuntTo sum up my experience I had an amazing time playing through The Witcher and I am really eager to play through the next to games (again) and really do everything you can. I highly recommend you play the game for yourself and if you like either Fantasy, RPG or Adventure this is pretty much a must buy. And to finally conclude my Review I give The Witcher a 83.5/100 rating making it one of my favorite games (even though it's not near the first place (currently The Witcher 3)).Thanks for reading my review I hope you liked the game aswell if you have played it that is. -Mingus

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Now let me begin first by saying that i realise this game is old, this review is my opinion on the game and what i think of it. This game♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off more than flappy bird did by far, all because of its crappy combat mechanics. You can't block or parry or dodge attacks by will, it is all determined by chance, which increases as you level up the correct skills. It is a 3rd person click mini game to put it short, you draw your sword and click on an enemy to execute techniques to damage your foes. It was good  that you couldn't spam click, you had to wait and click at the right time to execute a move correctly, otherwise it will fail. One thing i admire about the combat mechanics is the fact that you have 3 different stances, one is slow but does a lot of damage, one is for swift enemies, and the other stance is used when you fight against more than 1 enemy, i loved that idea. But AGAIN, its broken, at some point i was surrounded by 10 enemies and switched to group stance, my attacks never registered for some reason and i always ended up just casting Area of effect spells.You had the ability to cast spells in this game, which were very useful. You could cast a certain amount of spells based on your "endurance" levels. Finally a game that excludes the word mana. The spells were extremely hard to land sometimes as it is always casted in front of you. The enemy AI of the game is completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Sometimes they would just take it up the♥♥♥♥♥while you hit them with your sword, you could run in circles of tables and stuff and they will blindy follow you. When they have your back turned to you and are unaware to your presence, they would suddenly turn around when you get close enough and start attacking you. So there wasn't really advanced intelligence of enemies in this game, its very basic. One thing i liked a lot of the game is the variety of enemies you could face. Each enemy had its weakness for example, certain enemies are immune to fire, some enemies require you to fight them in different stances, some enemies are weak to silver more than steel etc. The game required you to purchase/find books containing information about the various monsters found in the witcher world, as this information is not known from the very start. I liked this concept, it made me feel like a true monster hunter doing research and planning ahead before facing an enemy.Another thing i really liked about the game is the Alchemy. You could find various recipes of potions that could aid you in a fight. Recipes could be bought or found randomly in the world. Ingredients could be found via plants, organs of slain monsters and potion bases which are found in alchemy shops. It was interesting to see that when you drink a potion a little animation would pop out, quite nice I liked this concept a lot. Certain potions gave you permanent benefits, which could only be crafted if a boss was slain and its rare ingredient obtained, this was very encouraging for me to hunt down and kill bosses.One very interesting thing about the game is that you could earn experience, and gain levels and attribute points which you could distirbute in one big skill tree. Skills that could be leveled up include the 3 different fighting stances for steel as well as silver weapons, Intensity of the spells you cast and their effectiveness, the amount of health you regenerate and have at once, and also your resistances to stuns and blindness and heaps of other degrading effects.IN the game you could also find weapons and armor, but the variety in them is extremely dissapointing. I only got a new sword when i have played 75% of the game, you could buy other swords and pick up weapons from enemies but they always carry the same stuff, no 'rare' loot in the game really. Some shops had better armor and weapons but they were so expensive to buy, there is no way you could make enough money in the game to afford it, unless you spend 10 hours slaying monsters and selling their organs. You could only use swords in the game, daggers and axes were very inneffective to use as it "couldn't be used with witcher combat moves"The plot of the game was quite enjoyable, it was my main motivation to finish this game and move on to the sequel. Characters in the game were unique, but there was no real bonding towards characters, i couldn't care less if someone i knew died in the game. The game didnt have a lot of variety in characters, there where a lot of similar looking NPC's with the same face as well as the same voice. In the game you also had to make decisions that would impact you at the end of the game, this I really enjoyed, you had the free will to choose sides or stay neutural. Pick friends and foes alike, and there were a lot of combinations of different choices you could pick as well.The game is quite violent, there are swear words in there, lots of adult themes and of course, lots of sex and nudity as well as a bit of gambling. I found the gambling to be quite entertaining. It was called "poker dice" where each player started with 6 dice each and would roll them to get pairs, three of a kind and a full house etc. Bids are placed at the start, after the first roll and it consistet of best out of 3. Though the gambling wasn't very big in the game, you would encounter someone to play with every now and again, but not always.Map design was quite well done, but it was annoying to navigate around landscapes, as the character you were playing as could not vault over a tiny little fence. YOu would always have a map of the area you were playing in and quests would give you map markers, but not always. I found the waypoints to be a bit faulty at times as it led me to places where my objectives weren't even close to.All and all, the game was at certain points very frustrating for me to play, as the combat mechanics faultyness caused me to die numerous times. I played the game from the hardest difficulty, I highly reccomend you play this game on the easiest difficulty otherwise you might smash your computer screen if you have a bad temper. One of my friends recommended me this game, and now i will recommend it to you, as this game has turned into a franchise and its sequel is much much better.SUMMARY:THE GOOD:-Interesting variety of enemies that required preperation for them to be faced.-Complex Alchemy that was always useful in a fight.-Interesting story, which is the biggest thing that kept me playing.-Had the free will to pick your friends and enemies, the game has alternative endings.-Good skill tree development that had to be chosen carefully-Fun gambling-PornTHE BAD:-Absolutely terrible combat mechanics that make you want to smash your screen-Identical npc's everywhere-not a lot of loot variety-Combat is repetitive 'click, click, click, click"-Annoying companions at some point.-Quest system a bit faulty, quest markers would sometimes lead you to the wrong places.OVERALL I give this game a solid 7/10.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												This game is hauntingly atmospheric with a soundtrack and visuals that tend to be too beautiful to have any business belonging to such a dark storyline. I still can't believe that CD Projekt Red pulled all of this off with a heavily modified Aurora engine, which goes all the way back to 2002's Neverwinter Nights. Though the combat can feel strange and jittery at some points, the overall gameplay is very fun and the storyline is extremely well-crafted. An impressive selection of choices and consequences make this worth a few replays as well to take Geralt on a different path. To me, this game along with its sequel both play more like action/adventure titles with RPG elements rather than pure RPGs, but they do it extremely well. Recommended.

Posted: March 5, 2015
												Having just now concluded the story of this game and most of the side quests, the word to describe how I feel is: Amazed.Woah, what a ride this game takes you in. For those who don't know, this game was based on a polish book series and this first game certainly does it justice. The story is indeed amazing, real kudos to the author Andrzej Sapkowski for this experience and to CD Projekt Red for making it playable. I got drunk, made love to 10+ women, was a successful detective, got drunk again, slayed tens of different beasts, died of an overdose, left the present and came back. The only con of this game is the combat which sometimes will fail hard on you and might result in frustration, more so in the last 6 hours of the game.All and all, a must-play for every RPG lover and any gamer who loves a game with an amazing story. For me this worked perfectly, as I am both.Rewarding experience. 8/10 would get drunk again.

Posted: May 5, 2014
												I remember playing this game 7 years ago, and yet when I started playing it again, the story was different.Instead of your usual linear RPGs, or those who have choices but they barely make any impact ingame, in The Witcher, everything you do has an impact on - the story, enemies and others. It feels great! Few games have ever achieved this level of detail.Everything you do has an outcome, so not only this game has a high rate of re-playability, it will suprise you on your second run how things go different.Also if you are a big pervert like me, you also will enjoy the sexual theme going in this game(infact in the book Geralt, the main hero, bangs anything that moves and is female apparently).Well written story/ies, very original and distinct from what we are used to, the only downside is the combat system, but I got used to it.One of the best RPGs out there indeed! I highly recommend you to try it and I tip my hat to CD Projekt RED.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												So, this is where it all started. Well, actually, it started in the books, but still. A nice journey into the trilogy before "The Wild Hunt" and even, on my second playthrough, I still enjoyed it.Witcher 1 offers a detailed and interesting story with some funny dialogues, as well as marvelous maps with quite beautiful graphics for 2008. Such combination definitely provides a fascinating and involving medieval fantasy atmosphere to the players, which, I guess, is one of the main reasons people love the trilogy so much. The other, probably, is sex. Witcher 1 stands out from the other parts with special romance cards thay you get for sexual encounters... and Triss Merigold is as charming as ever.I appreciate that the developers bring dark and mature themes to the game and that they weren't concerned about political correctness. There are number of things, for which feminists would call the developers sexists. But, since I'm not a feminist, kudos for CD Projekt Red, because I prefer my games uncensored.With that said, there are number of things, that make the gameplay less pleasant, namely:1) Frequent crashes, freezing and black screens (I played it on Windows 10)2) Despite the cool combos, the combat system is dull and gets boring soon. Fighting is not about the skill, as much as it is about damage stats and choosing the right stance and weapon3) There are too many monsters around and they respawn too often. It doesn't make the game more difficult, just artificially longer, as you need time to deal with them. You can run pass them, but still.4) Inventory is too small. There is a mod for that, but it doesn't provide more slots, it just allows to stack more items of the same type5) The game offers choices that have consequences, leading to alternative scenarios, but none of those consequences are sufficiently serious as it was in Mass Effect. Almost nothing you did has any relevant effect in Witcher 2.Also:6) The "mature" element of this game is mostly sex, profanity and morally grey choices, which all is fine by me, but I wish the story was more sophisticated. Come to think of it, the main storyline is actually quite robust and behind those primitive fetch quests there aren't that many side quests that stand out.But even with those faults Witcher is one of my favourite games. I had great fun playing it and with the extra content (a digital comic and fan made adventure modules) I had some more. "Witchmas" adventure is very funny! "Price of Neutrality" and "Side Effects" were nice, too. The other modules were interesting, but they have some gamebreaking bugs.The game has plenty of mods and a game editor to create your own modules, so that's another good thing about it.My overall rating 8/10.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												-THE WITCHER: ENHANCED EDITION-I've heard a lot of people complain about this game, mainly because of its "boring combat" or lack of fast travel. Although not being able to easily warp from one location to another is a little bit annoying, I never found it to be a major issue, and I wholeheartedly disagree with the Witcher's combat being poor; it's simple, yes, and generally pretty easy, but increasing the difficulty or brewing a few of the many potions in the game can help to spice things up.The reason I adore this game, however, is less due to the gameplay (which I have no trouble with) but more to do with Andrzej Sapkowski's fantastic characters and world, coupled with CD PROJEKT's great writing and incredible musical score. My only complaint with the Witcher is the fact that Geralt, who gets more action than most of the game's courtesans, looks frighteningly like a lizard.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												My only experience of any witcher games was The Witcher 2 on xbox 360 a while ago and I never really got into it enough to finish.So, when I saw the witcher games on sale recently I grabbed them, why not? they where really cheap.I do not regret it one bit.I decided to start from the first, because the best place to begin any epic tale is from the beginning.Expecting a mediocre experience and clunky gameplay (I'd heard the second had improved drastically on combat) I went ahead and started a game.Oh man, what a game, I'm only 5 hours into it as i write this review and i'm already sucked right into the story. This game does it's story better than most recent games I have played. The characters are extremely likeable and the voice acting is pretty good for the most part.The game itself looks very nice visually, true it isn't the best graphics but it looks extremely well done given it's age.The combat is a bit limited, however, this doesn't make it any less fun. While you are limited to the three fighting styles there are ways to string together combos and use magic too. The game cleverly forces you to use strategy in your fights which also mixes things up a bit. If you're expecting to hack and slash your way through I suggest you play on easy. If you try that on normal or hard you'll find yourself face down in the dirt.Finding things is extremely easy as you can mark each quest or item you're trying to find on your map. A mini map in the top corner constantly points you in the right direction too.I'm pleasantly surprised so far....... and i expect to be pleasantly surprised some more as I play through this story.I definately recommend this game to everyone, the history and lore behind the game alone is so expansive, it's as if this whole other world actually exists.Pick it up, give it a try, become intregued and emotionally involved in Geralts story. You wont regret it.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I bought the Witcher back in 2010, long before it came to Steam. I have played through the game four times and it still holds up as one of my favorite RPGs.The game is based on the book series written by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. The games titular "protagonist" is a Witcher named Geralt of Rivia. A Witcher is an individual who undergoes extensive training via combat, alchemic processes, and consumption of wild ingredients. This training gives them lightning-quick reflexes and magical aptitude in order to fight powerful monsters. If you are worried that you will not understand the game's premises, then have no fear. Geralt suffers from amnesia at the beginning of the game, so he's just as clueless as you about the Witcher universe.The story is immersive. The writers loved to dabble in moral relativity. Your choices also matter to the story. For example, in chapter 1, you will be hired by a "merchant" to chill outside his house and protect his cargo. In the middle of the night, some Scoi'atel (a group of radical dwarves and elves fighting for freedom), will demand that you hand over the merchant's goods. If you agree to their demands, they will come back in chapter 2 and kill a certain NPC, making it more difficult to accomplish the chapter's primary quest.Combat is straightforward, but can be clunky, cumbersome, and may take some time to get used to. Geralt uses two swords; one is steel, while the other is silver. The steel sword is used to fight humanoids (humans, dwarves, elves, etc.) while the silver sword is used to fight monsters. You also have 3 stances - one is used to fight big enemies, the second is used to fight small, agile enemies, and the third is to fight groups of enemies. You left click on your enemy, and when your cursor flashes, you click again to do a chain attack. This combat mechanic is vastly different from the mechanics of the sequels, so some players get annoyed with it. Finally, the voice acting is...hilarious. Since this is a Polish game, they needed to find English voice actors quickly. While there are one or two good VAs, the rest of them are hilariously awful.In conclusion, if you're willing to overlook the somewhat clunky combat and bad voice acting, you will find The Witcher to be a good start to a great series.

												While everyone is praising this game for it's story, I found this game to be quite bad honestly. The above average story couldn't motivate me enough to slog through the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ quests and horrid combat of this game. Now, I know this is released in 2007, but I couldn't not say that every single non-important character looks exactly the same. Not a big concern, but I just though I'd put it in there. This game is an RPG, and it kind of sucks hard in the 'Game' part of 'Role-Playing Game'. The quests are uninteresting and boring to do, and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ combat system isn't helping. Did I mention combat? The whole of combat in this game is clicking on things you want to kill. Just clicking, and no back pedaling or anything like that, your character goes to the enemy whom you clicked, and does some random sword swish swoosh that lasts a second and a half or so and then you click again. Dodging is utterly useless as any enemy that attacks   in at least a below-average speed cannot be attacked and then dodged without getting a hit in return, so you're better off just tanking. The one use dodging has is to escape quickly to drink a potion. There's this rock paper scissors style system of "styles" of attacks, but they dont really change the actual gameplay much. You just choose which of the three styles counters the enemy.The combat just feels boring, honestly.I'm not going to talk about the story as the other reviews already do. But I will say that It wasn't as good as I expected. Above average, sure but not good enough to keep me in the game.After slogging through 30+ hours in this game to see if it gets better later on (It didn't), I decided to do something better with my time than fight drowners. Really shoud've refunded this game when I had a chance.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
Geralt the ballerina TL;DR The Witcher is a story rich semi-rpg with a new for its time combat system, that follows Geralt regaining some memories and finding out who attacked his home. You will have fun with the combat system for the first 2 hours, but then you’ll realise that grouping up as many enemies and using the group style is was easier. The Story quickly changes from a revenge story into a political war story where you work on get revenge along the way. I wouldn’t really count this game as an rpg because if you make a decision that goes against what Geralt would normally do as a witcher he’ll call you out on it. You’re given the option to change your weapons and armor but there is no reason to , your weapons are usually strong throughout the entire game and as I recall there was only one opportunity to change my armor through a vendor.Follow us here Steamship Discord:https://discord.gg/XbsKrtKSteamship Steam group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamshipPros  Innovative Combat SystemLore richGood StoryMade Witcher 3 possibleCons Linear worldAwful quests A lot of pointless featuresCan be punished for exploring---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GameplayEach enemy has a specific style its weak too and is usually obvious by their stature, But multiple enemies of any type are weak too the group style. The Witcher feels like it has a façade of a rpg your given to option to switch out your weapons and armor, but you most likely never will, and you definitely will never use the offhand small weapon because it is absolutely useless. Skill points are given out to very simple upgrades to combat like +10% damage, nothing really pops in the skill trees that become game changers.The quests given in this game really are not good, most are collection quests or require you to talk to someone else. You’ll find yourself running through the linear world back and forth many times. The Alchemy system is very detailed with many potions you can create , but you wont need most, bar the special monster ones, healing and nightvision the others are pretty useless.The Morality system is one of the few where the main character will argue on your choice. So maybe I want to half sex with the vampire ladies and not help the angry knights. Even your choices don’t really make a difference in the main story line anyway. Characters There is quite a few characters that are very interesting and have good personalities. Geralt comes off as a cold and cynical man but with sense of humor which makes him very likeable as a main character. The other characters never gave off a vibe of real concern for Geralt and seemed more like quest and info givers. Story The story of the Witcher stats out as a decent revenge story after you are run out of your home by an evil group. The story takes a quick turn into a political war and which side will you choose, The revenge plot feels like a side plot at this point. Side quests have no impact to anything else so they feel of little importance. Art/Graphics The Witcher has some very detailed designs for the monsters and some very pretty environments but I feel like the restrictive maps don’t give the environments justice. Characters have unique designs and are all recognizable. Bonus Notes If your interested in playing the Witcher 3 but thought that you should go through the others first, you should skip this one and just look at some foot notes to get the references.If you like this join us here to get the latest Reviews:Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtKSteamship Steam group : http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamshipWhat would you like to see for our next review ? Ask in the comment section!

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												When I was a kid, I used to love all kinds of RPGs, JRPGs, CRPGs or even MMORPGs like Runescape! This game made me recall those memories. This game may be old, may be not in the moment's trends but it's the games that step out of the conformities that are the best. At first, the combat may be different than you expected, but you get used to it. In the beginning I hated the combat system, but now it seems to add a little something to the game.The story is amazing, has alot of punches and you get attached to the characters pretty quickly.The feel of genuine RPG is present. Now for the things I found less pleasant in the game. The characters body models are not varied: I think it becomes repetetive seeing the same faces all over again. There are not many weapons in this game, so this withdraws the experience of character customization. When you are in a chapter, you are restriced to a little number of places to explore and finish your quests in. This withdraws the feel of open-world.Final Verdict: 8.5/10 -A must play for RPG purists
