content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												In Witcher you follow around some guy named Geralt, who looks like he just hit his midlife crisis. Lucky for him, he has amnesia and doesn't remember anything. Much to everyone's disappointment though, he doesn't forget how to be extremely boring. Geralt has many redeeming qualities like being in heat all the time and nothing else. I don't know how he sleeps with enough women to populate a large village, but he does, and it's as sad as it sounds. Watching Geralt  try to seduce women is like watching your recently divorced father beg a Wal Mart greeter for a date.What's worse than that though? The game doesn't let you forgot your moment of shame because it drops a card in your journal to remind you of that proud moment when started collecting video game women like trophies. They might as well include a fedora and self help book with the game.After you take a shower to wash away all that sleaze, you can enjoy... Oh no wait, this is when the developers thought slow clicking and micromanaging how dumb your character looks would make for a great combat system. Well don't worry about that, because after all the grinding you get to spend your hard earned points on thrilling, state-of-the-art skills that mostly just increase your main damage or some other vague damage that doesn't really matter. All the different damages and micromanaging seem like a failed attempt to add some depth to battles.And you definitely won't forget how mature this game is: every other character uses cuss words like they don't understand how language works, but that's ok because no character seems to know how being memorable works. When the writing isn't too busy being vulgar for no reason, it also finds time to show how grown up it is by throwing around morality and politics like the clumsy kid in gym class.You might be thinking "Wow that sounds negative, how can you be recommending this?"Well here is how this little trick works: Just copy and paste the second word of every sentence and that's what my actual review says! Just kidding. But seriously, I enjoyed this game despite the flaws and I was pretty swept up by it.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												As a person who knows the story very well, and read all the novels, I feel that my impression of the game is twofold. On the one hand, the game is great, it has amazing dialogues, storyline, quests, lore, characters, etc. - it is obvious that PC Project did a great job. However, I highly advise to read the actual novel prior to playing this game, or many things might be totally unclear to you (the entire story of 7 books is very long though, and it is understandable that not many people have enough time to do it) or at least, try to find the Polish movie of 2000 (which is a crap though). Unfortunately, the Witcher series are not that popular as Game of Thrones in North America, which becomes a problem because majority of people know nothing of this Universe and what had happened in the world prior to this game - and there were lots of things happening. I ll try to summarize everything in one sentence - a war had happened which united the Northern Kingdoms against an army of Southerners, the war was won - at the same time, there is a huge Elven rebellion happening, and of course, Witchers, the mystique organization which had sworn to protect humans from evil, is slowly disapepearing from the public. Geralt is among the last ones to survive.Of course, devs did a good job explain everything from the start, but still the game has enormous amount of flashbacks which test your knowledge of the series, and in order to enjoy the game in full extent it is advisable to know what the heck is going on at least. On the other hand, there is some element of uncertainty. A. Sapkowski, the original author of the series, made it clear several years ago that the story of Witcher did not end in his books yet, and if I understand it correctly - he is working on another book currently. In this way, I am just very confused whether how this game as well as Witcher 2 and 3, would fit into Universe. But this is a question which cannot be answered yet. For now, I give a strong A + to the game.9 / 10

												Picked up The Witcher a long time ago, but due to compatibility issues I never gave it much of a go. As the launch of W3 approached I figured I should do the whole series. I'm a story guy, so reports of lacklustre combat didn't bother me (it's not great, in truth) and the story more than makes up for it. Took me 45 hours start to finish. I would certainly recommend the game for those that want a good RPG. It's starting to show its age graphically, however because the story and characters are so good, you forget you're playing a 10 year old game. Lots of choices to make, taking you down a different path depending on your decisions and an adult themed collection of in-game cards aquirable upon coupling with the various characters. I can honestly say I enjoyed the game world so much that upon finishing, I looked for the books the game is based on, and started installing the sequel.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Note: This reviewer played this game for the first time in 2015Story: 9/10      The Witcher's strongest feature. The narrative in the game holds your attention due to its morally gray character motivations as well as its well realized central protagonist. Modern RPGs are plagued with the "fetch either an angel halo for the gods or a dead baby for the demons" choice system. The Witcher's choices are very gray at first glance, and for much of the game character motives are wonderfully opaque. This leads to real thought, and at times regret, for decisions you've made.     The other issue RPGs have is the "build your own protagonist" system a la Skyrim. This becomes tantamount to there being NO protagonist but instead a soulless fetch quest runner who gets to witness the other ACTUAL character fulfill their motivations. Geralt is his own man, with his own mindset. There is plenty of choice in this game, but no matter your decision, its Geralt making that choice in the narrative. If you kill someone it'll be in a way Geralt would kill them, and likewise if you show mercy. Choice is not diluted and neither is character development. It proves unbelievably refreshing in a world of nameless chosen ones out to fulfill some prophecy or whatever.Sound: 8/10    You can tell The Witcher is a freshman effort by its dev team in a lot of technical places, and the sound is no exception. the farther you get into the script, the better the voice acting (and likely, the voice actors' directing) gets, even for characters we've known since the beginning. Its a small gripe but its there. The music is wonderfully moody and neither overpowers nor fails to be noticed. I have walked away humming numerous central melodies.Graphics 7/10    I imagine I'm being cruel here, but it is nearly impossible to review an eight year game on the first playthrough with no knowledge of the gaming technologies of today. Having said that, The Witcher realizes its imagery well enough. Environments are focused on capturing realism and largely succeed. Character models serve well enough and have a large enough pool of animations to suffice, but in the end like all older Bioware engine RPGs, you become very familiar with how exactly someones hands will move when excited, happy, indignant, or surprised. Facial expressions are non existent, which unfortunately is probably the only thing holding its story from a 10/10. I imagine for its time, The Witcher was stunning.Gameplay: 6/10     So many people will not make it to the best this game has to offer because of this. With a hindsight view of singleplayer ARPGs, The Witcher proved difficult to get into in terms of gameplay. Its either a hack n slash with the soul of Baulder's Gate, or the exact opposite, I'm not quite sure. All evasion/parrying is dice based, like a DnD rpg. All combat is based on clicking a target and essentially playing a rhythm game by clicking again at the next part of the attack combo. Clicking too early ends everything and leaves you vulnerable to damage. Also, The Witcher's combat is heavily influenced on its characterization of Witchers. This is fine, but it means you must know three fighting stances for three different scenarios with two different swords. Each fighting stance has its own tech tree on each sword, leading to 6(!) tech trees governing your auto attacks, all with essentially the same generic talent as the others. It can be maddening.      Other aspects that plague the Witcher are its attempts follow realism into laughable conclusions. For example, drunkenness is a big thing in this game, but you walk so slow when drunk its not functional. You can sleep this off, but you can only rest at campfires or inns. There's no fast travel (I repeat: no fast travel) meaning on more than one occasion I took ten plus minutes of gameplay to stumble out of a house, into the street, down to the slums, and into an inn to sleep off the drunkenness. Other cases of this would be quests where someone asks for six monster teeth. You cannot simply kill six monsters. You must educate Geralt in how to properly extract monster teeth. You do that by reading books or finding someone who is willing to bring it up in casual conversation. There are almost no indicators of any kind within the game as to where this information is, and every tooth, tuft of hair, berry you pick, or potion you concoct requires a source of knowledge first. Couple that with, again, NO FAST TRAVEL, and youre going to be backtracking. a lot. And married to a witcher wiki if you're a completionist.Replayability 8/10    I am already planning to attack this game again with my new understanding of its mechanics, as well as apply my knowledge of the world come the end of it to the events that occur in the beginning. There is a plethora of choices and changes in this game, all of which tempt the player to return again.OVERALL: 9/10   I realize only the plot scored this high, but the Witcher truly is a whole lot more than the sum of its parts. I highly suggest playing it now, as the window of its first-play-through-enjoyability is closing. Newer and shinier games with simpler, more user friendly systems will come to make hindsight playthroughs of The Witcher like mine a task too onerous to tackle. This is a real shame, as the Witcher tells a story like books do, with various motives and questionable decisions. It skirts so many videogame narrative tropes of "The Chosen One" or the "Mute Protagonist" and pulls itself above the rest because of this. Play this now, before you can't stomach it, or windows can't run it.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												So, let me tell you a story about how I came to put 38 hours into The Witcher: Enhanced Edition.Like many of the people probably reading this review I was scouring the internet finding out whether or not it was worth playing this game or skipping straight to The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings, before jumping into the recently released and critically acclaimed The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt.A friend of mine (who also left a review here, check it out under 'Thorns') brought me the first 2 in the Steam sale last winter and suggested I played them both.After much research over whether or not the first game was still worth playing, it seemed unanimous that YES, it was because it is a unique and enjoyable game with fantastic lore, music, and characterization (albeit with janky combat and some strange, questionable decisions made throughout) although it wasnt a necessity if i was going to play it for story alone.Well.After taking the plunge I am happy to report that this game is well worth the time and effort I put into playing it, and stands true as one of the most interesting game worlds i've ever had the pleasure of being a part of.YES. The combat is initially a confusing and unrepsonsive mess. You cant use a controller with this game and so the combat consists of you choosing the necessary sword (steel or silver) and a combat style best suited to the situation (strong, fast or group) and quite literally having to time mouse clicks via on screen prompts.Yeah, it's an odd choice.This being said at around hour 4 I had the hang of it and actually came to love and respect it's uniqueness in it's own way. If you can get passed this early on, along with the relatively old animations, occasional hiccup in writing and lack of multiple chracter models (seriously, there cant be anymore than about 20 in this 35+ hour game) then you will be enthralled by the music, the deep and interesting lore, the humor and the cast of fun and enticing characters. In the end I would say I possibly enjoyesd this more than I did The Elder Scrolls V:  Skyrim.I know, that's a bold statement. But I think Skyrim delivered everything I expected and nothing more. The Witcher exceeded my expectations immensely. Don't do what I did and pass on this game because you think it's too old or outdated.Play it, love it.P.S. - You can have sex with a HUGE amount of the women in the game, and each time you do you collect an old school "Nudey" trading card. Just because.On one occasion, I beat up a young girl's father because he wouldnt let me see his daughter to fetch a friend's lute back, convinced I was going to shag her because that's what my friend did. I then proceeded to shag her brains out. She loved it.10/10 would throw done with daddy again...

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												If you're reading this you're probably conflicted whether you should buy the game or not.***COMBAT***Firstly, answer is yes. Although the combat may be somewhat odd at first, it grows on you. In my opinion I find it a little more entertaining than that in The Witcher 2. Mixing different potions, oils, bombs and signs you can one shot almost every creature there is, making it easier when outnumbered 10 to one.***GAMEPLAY***Gameplay is really fun, minor little glitches here and there where you're trying to walk forward but end up walking left or right. Luckily, none of it happens during combat (yay \o/) One of the most exciting parts of the game is the monsters and alchemy. In order to harvest certain plants or creatures you have to find books relating to those creatures, which makes it more fun than you'd think. Instead of instantly knowing everything about different creatures and plants at the get-go, you have to go learn about them, adding character to the story and game. In the books you will learn all the weaknesses, strengths, fighting styles and counters to all monsters.Now the most important part of The Witcher,***STORY***I won't give any spoilers, but the story in The Witcher is highly interesting. Unlike most games, if you fail or make the incorrect decision, you have to live with it. The game does not end, it carries on and you have to deal with your mistake and the reprecussions  it brings. Even the side quests are interesting and often contribute to the main story quests.All in all, an amazing must play game for all Story-Rich game lovers and RPG fans.9/10

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												When I was a kid, I used to love all kinds of RPGs, JRPGs, CRPGs or even MMORPGs like Runescape! This game made me recall those memories. This game may be old, may be not in the moment's trends but it's the games that step out of the conformities that are the best. At first, the combat may be different than you expected, but you get used to it. In the beginning I hated the combat system, but now it seems to add a little something to the game.The story is amazing, has alot of punches and you get attached to the characters pretty quickly.The feel of genuine RPG is present. Now for the things I found less pleasant in the game. The characters body models are not varied: I think it becomes repetetive seeing the same faces all over again. There are not many weapons in this game, so this withdraws the experience of character customization. When you are in a chapter, you are restriced to a little number of places to explore and finish your quests in. This withdraws the feel of open-world.Final Verdict: 8.5/10 -A must play for RPG purists

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Picked up The Witcher a long time ago, but due to compatibility issues I never gave it much of a go. As the launch of W3 approached I figured I should do the whole series. I'm a story guy, so reports of lacklustre combat didn't bother me (it's not great, in truth) and the story more than makes up for it. Took me 45 hours start to finish. I would certainly recommend the game for those that want a good RPG. It's starting to show its age graphically, however because the story and characters are so good, you forget you're playing a 10 year old game. Lots of choices to make, taking you down a different path depending on your decisions and an adult themed collection of in-game cards aquirable upon coupling with the various characters. I can honestly say I enjoyed the game world so much that upon finishing, I looked for the books the game is based on, and started installing the sequel.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Note: This reviewer played this game for the first time in 2015Story: 9/10      The Witcher's strongest feature. The narrative in the game holds your attention due to its morally gray character motivations as well as its well realized central protagonist. Modern RPGs are plagued with the "fetch either an angel halo for the gods or a dead baby for the demons" choice system. The Witcher's choices are very gray at first glance, and for much of the game character motives are wonderfully opaque. This leads to real thought, and at times regret, for decisions you've made.     The other issue RPGs have is the "build your own protagonist" system a la Skyrim. This becomes tantamount to there being NO protagonist but instead a soulless fetch quest runner who gets to witness the other ACTUAL character fulfill their motivations. Geralt is his own man, with his own mindset. There is plenty of choice in this game, but no matter your decision, its Geralt making that choice in the narrative. If you kill someone it'll be in a way Geralt would kill them, and likewise if you show mercy. Choice is not diluted and neither is character development. It proves unbelievably refreshing in a world of nameless chosen ones out to fulfill some prophecy or whatever.Sound: 8/10    You can tell The Witcher is a freshman effort by its dev team in a lot of technical places, and the sound is no exception. the farther you get into the script, the better the voice acting (and likely, the voice actors' directing) gets, even for characters we've known since the beginning. Its a small gripe but its there. The music is wonderfully moody and neither overpowers nor fails to be noticed. I have walked away humming numerous central melodies.Graphics 7/10    I imagine I'm being cruel here, but it is nearly impossible to review an eight year game on the first playthrough with no knowledge of the gaming technologies of today. Having said that, The Witcher realizes its imagery well enough. Environments are focused on capturing realism and largely succeed. Character models serve well enough and have a large enough pool of animations to suffice, but in the end like all older Bioware engine RPGs, you become very familiar with how exactly someones hands will move when excited, happy, indignant, or surprised. Facial expressions are non existent, which unfortunately is probably the only thing holding its story from a 10/10. I imagine for its time, The Witcher was stunning.Gameplay: 6/10     So many people will not make it to the best this game has to offer because of this. With a hindsight view of singleplayer ARPGs, The Witcher proved difficult to get into in terms of gameplay. Its either a hack n slash with the soul of Baulder's Gate, or the exact opposite, I'm not quite sure. All evasion/parrying is dice based, like a DnD rpg. All combat is based on clicking a target and essentially playing a rhythm game by clicking again at the next part of the attack combo. Clicking too early ends everything and leaves you vulnerable to damage. Also, The Witcher's combat is heavily influenced on its characterization of Witchers. This is fine, but it means you must know three fighting stances for three different scenarios with two different swords. Each fighting stance has its own tech tree on each sword, leading to 6(!) tech trees governing your auto attacks, all with essentially the same generic talent as the others. It can be maddening.      Other aspects that plague the Witcher are its attempts follow realism into laughable conclusions. For example, drunkenness is a big thing in this game, but you walk so slow when drunk its not functional. You can sleep this off, but you can only rest at campfires or inns. There's no fast travel (I repeat: no fast travel) meaning on more than one occasion I took ten plus minutes of gameplay to stumble out of a house, into the street, down to the slums, and into an inn to sleep off the drunkenness. Other cases of this would be quests where someone asks for six monster teeth. You cannot simply kill six monsters. You must educate Geralt in how to properly extract monster teeth. You do that by reading books or finding someone who is willing to bring it up in casual conversation. There are almost no indicators of any kind within the game as to where this information is, and every tooth, tuft of hair, berry you pick, or potion you concoct requires a source of knowledge first. Couple that with, again, NO FAST TRAVEL, and youre going to be backtracking. a lot. And married to a witcher wiki if you're a completionist.Replayability 8/10    I am already planning to attack this game again with my new understanding of its mechanics, as well as apply my knowledge of the world come the end of it to the events that occur in the beginning. There is a plethora of choices and changes in this game, all of which tempt the player to return again.OVERALL: 9/10   I realize only the plot scored this high, but the Witcher truly is a whole lot more than the sum of its parts. I highly suggest playing it now, as the window of its first-play-through-enjoyability is closing. Newer and shinier games with simpler, more user friendly systems will come to make hindsight playthroughs of The Witcher like mine a task too onerous to tackle. This is a real shame, as the Witcher tells a story like books do, with various motives and questionable decisions. It skirts so many videogame narrative tropes of "The Chosen One" or the "Mute Protagonist" and pulls itself above the rest because of this. Play this now, before you can't stomach it, or windows can't run it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I am recommending this game with a few caveats. It's 2016 as I write this, and I refuse to play The Witcher 3 until I beat the previous two, and we all know that I have to play The Witcher 3... I HAVE TO! I am now 50-something hours into this beast and I'm not gonna lie to you, it is a ♥♥♥♥ing grind sometimes. Collect ten of these, bring this to there, grind money, farm herbs... It reminds me of some of the worst parts of WoW at its low points. There's also The Witcher's graphics, which, in its day, probably would have melted my face off like the ark of the covenant, but now they're pretty rough. The gameplay is equally dated and suffers from some truely bizarre implementation choices (Parapa the Rappa style combat?). It takes grit to get through it sometimes.But despite all of that, there is a seed of greatness taking root here. Even by modern standards, the original Witcher has an incredible depth to its mechanics (flawed as they are), and a richness of character and storytelling that is woefully lacking in most games (even modern RPGs). There's no black and white moral scale here to define your actions. No need to max out your good or evil points to get this or that ability. Just choices. You make choices and you live with the consequences. That's the price of admission. Sometimes you'll make a choice, and twenty hours later that♥♥♥♥♥♥will come back to bite you in the♥♥♥♥♥ and it's not because you made the wrong choice, but because there wasn't a right choice. This game's not about finding the optimal path of least resistance. It's about moral ambiguity, and the story of an active participant in history, ♥♥♥♥-ups and all. This game made me step away from my keyboard a few times to think it over before I made my choices. I agonized over them sometimes, but in the end, no matter the outcome, it always felt right.I will say this however: If you're just trying to get through this to play the next one, you don't have to. The Witcher 1 isn't a blank slate either, so no matter which one you start playing, you'll feel like you only know part of the story. And if you insist, but just can't take an 80-hour game, just play it on easy so you can get through it quick and see what happens. That's where the Witcher does its best work. The story.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												I'm just going to put this out there that this was the best RPG I have ever played hands down. I do not really play many RPGs and never really played any, but compared to other RPGs I have had time with, this was something else. Considering it came out in 2007 and provided me with over 30 hours of gameplay really amazed me. I was really proud with what CD Projekt Red had made here and obviously has evolved onto the current generation platforms. Of course with a great response outta me there were a few bumps in the road. Probably the most addressed here is the fighting mechanics. They aren't the best. Some can even say it sucked and I wouldn't blame them. Of course we should all factor in that it did come out in 2007 and this game was most likely on a tight budget (I am not saying it was on a tight budget but it seems likely). However the rest of the gameplay and plot does eclipse the bad fighting mechanics and really gives a you a great expeirence and also expands your "book fanatsies" in terms of a monster riddled world (not sexual fantasies you uncultured cactus). In the end I would only change the fighting mechanics, and also the lack of direction in certain parts of the game, but can easily be figured out if you have a lot of gaming expeirence. Now at the time I am writing this review, The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is not available for individual download and is only in a Witcher bundle. I would wait until it is being sold on Steam individually because during Steam sale I paid $1.49 for it and it was a helluva deal and it gave me 30+ hours of gameplay. Definite Buy when it's not in that bundle because $5 doesn't hurt you terribly. Get the game and try it, and don't be like me with a scrub Mac with a crap GPU and can't play The Witcher 2 because of it..*EDIT*I have beaten the second Witcher on Xbox 360 and surprisingly the first Witcher is the best of the two. First one offers more hours of gameplay, better music, more engaging story, but however the improved combat makes up in the second Witcher no doubt. Still recommend that you play both because the lore is unmatched in this series. Don't diss on the first one despite it's lack luster combat.*Second Edit*Witcher 3 is the best RPG I've ever played now, but still give this game a shot if on sale.

												Welp to Start off despite what Steam says I played of this game I played about 20 hours of it offline do to my internet being destroyed. So this game atleast for me took about 45 hours give or take and you can probably do it in less. Would I reccommend the game for its story 100% but there are some issues that the game has regardless of its amazing story. First I'll start off with the positives story, setting, lore and all of that are so fasinating. The dialogue in this game can also be so golden and this game has a cast of very memorable characters. Now the downsides the combat is really basic and not really unique. The sword play is a combo system based on timing your clicks and not really special and trying to use abilities in tandem feels really clunky so combat is nothing that special. Also I just remembered this the crafting system in the game is really unique but only on the alchemy side when your making potions besides that I never needed to make bombs and never saw a use for them and also I just got so much grease and such from drops that I hardly ever had to make any. 11/10 story like woah7/10 Overall

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												This is a very solid game, and the graphics are still very good for a 2007 game. The story is extremely engrossing, and morality is handled in an organic way, there is no "good/evil points" system. The characters are all believable and interesting, and the game world feels alive with NPCs moving about. The game tells an engrossing story without dragging on for too long. My initial playthrough took around 40 hours, and I did a fair amount of side quests on my way through the game. The parts of this game that some people might struggle with is the combat system and inventory management. Combat consists of selecting your sword (silver or steel) and combat style (heavy, fast, or group) and then clicking at the proper time to combo attacks on your enemies. I'm sure that some people will find this boring. (There are combat overhaul mods, but I did not use them, so I cannot vouch for how good/bad they are).Inventory management is a chore in this game, but luckily there are not too many things that are vital to carry around. Also, quest items get their own inventory with unlimited space, and alchemical ingredients also get their own section. This helps alleviate the problem, but it can still be annoying.Minor gripes aside, this is a very good game, and if you aren't put off by the combat system it is certainly worth playing.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												The Witcher has a measure of flaws, to be sure. The combat isn't terribly challenging, some of the quests fall into the RPG tropes of "fetch quests" or "go here and kill x number of y", and I even ran into a few game-crashing bugs. Some of that may be simply age -- the game was released in 2007, and I finally played it eight years later -- but it's by no means perfect.Having said that, I really did enjoy my time with Geralt of Rivia. While some of the quests in the game are "FedEx" style trips, others are interesting investigations that are both interesting to play and get the player invested in the plot and characters. The game certainly has a story to tell, and is pushing you along that path -- but it's a good story, and one that I quite enjoyed. Sometimes I felt like the game was holding my hand a bit much, telling me where to go or what to do, but other times it let the lore and subtle clues fill in story details or render characters. And the world-builiding and story is really the best thing about this game. The titular character, in particular, is well-done. The game has introduced me to the works of Andrzej Sapkowski, and I look forward to finding out more about Geralt of Rivia in both the novels and CD Projekt RED's follow-up games.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												The Witcher 1 is a very fun game to play especially if you are going to go down the series. To start, I'm going to say that you should buy this game when it goes on sale for 85% for $1.49 (which it does often). For the price that you pay, you get well worth the cost back with fun.The Witcher 1 has a nice compelling story with a good conclusion. You play as a Witcher called Geralt who lost his memory and try to track down Salamandra. There are a phlethora of both main story quests and side quests and the intermingling of those actually make the quest line very fun. It also makes the side quests (grinding ones sometimes) much less boring and some can get done while you do the main quest. As for the main story quest, you can alter it depending on who you side with at times. There will be quite a few times where you have to side with people or make key decisions. Although they don't ruin the story if you chose the "other" side, they do change some of the narrative in the future.So onto some of the cons that make me want to rage sometimes. First of all, there is no jump option. This isn't a big deal or anything since the space bar is just atactical pause, but there are quite a few hidden walls where there clearly shouldnt be or could not be. You litearlly cannot jump off any kind of ledge at all, no matter how small. Furthermore, the combat is a bit clunky in many regards and like with the invisible walls, enemies have their own "invisible wall" region that acts like a block. My last critique of this game is their character models. They recycle the same character models for a lot of side characters and some quests characters way too much. The same old man, fat rich man, drunkard, etc keeps appearing over and over. The voice actor is even the same for those most of the time. However, the essential characters are unique and have their own unique voice actors.Overall, the Witcher 1 is a bit clunky, but is well worth the play, especially for the price of $1.49. If you want to play down the series to Witcher 3, it can only get better and therefore by starting with Witcher 1, you derive the maximum possible utility for playing the whole series.Rating: 8.0/10

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												The Witcher is a story-driven action RPG. I'll admit that it took me a few tries to get into this game; this was part due to its different combat system. The Witcher’s combat isn't about blindly clicking the mouse, but instead requires timing to effectively chain a number of progressively stronger attacks together (sort of a really cut down fighter’s style of combos) as well as picking the right fighting style for the situation.The equippable item system in Witcher is rather basic. If you’re looking for a Diabloesce game with an exorbitant amount of different weapons and armour, you won’t find it here. Fundamentally, you’ll use 2 unique swords and a set of armour. These items have a couple of upgrades as the game progresses, but for the most part, that’s all you’ll use. The real item aspect of the Witcher is with its “power ups”. You’ll spend most of your time looting corpses and objects in search of crafting components to create potions, bombs and weapon boosts. I thought the levelling system in the game could have been a little more interesting. Every time you level up, you get certain kinds of skill points to allocate to a skill tree. These points mostly just influence your character’s numbers (extra damage, extra resistances, extra chances to dodge) and don’t necessarily feel noticeable. You do get to chain more attacks as you level those skills, but perhaps some completely new abilities as you level to show your advancement may help?The visuals were quite good, especially given the game came out in 2008. I especially liked the look of the combat as well as the visual effect on the weapons when “power up” items were applied to them. My biggest con for this game however was the repetitive character models. You will run into the same NPCs and enemies models a LOT.Lastly, the story. The Witcher story was quite enjoyable with a rather hefty length to it. The game offers you a lot of opportunities to make decisions, but ultimately the game’s outcome will be the same. We’re offer 3 endings, based on a few key decisions, with different set dressings along the way based on other decisions. In saying that though, I did get invested in the story and had wished some of my decisions had had different outcomes in the story.Overall, a very enjoyable game and I’m looking forward to playing the sequel, Witcher 2. Should you so choose, your save file from Witcher 1 can be imported into Witcher 2, so that your decisions  and equipment following you, allowing it to really feel like it’s a continuation of your character.It you enjoy your stored driven RPG and have the time and patients to invest into a long story, I’d recommend giving The Witcher a try.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												The Witcher 1 is a very fun game to play especially if you are going to go down the series. To start, I'm going to say that you should buy this game when it goes on sale for 85% for $1.49 (which it does often). For the price that you pay, you get well worth the cost back with fun.The Witcher 1 has a nice compelling story with a good conclusion. You play as a Witcher called Geralt who lost his memory and try to track down Salamandra. There are a phlethora of both main story quests and side quests and the intermingling of those actually make the quest line very fun. It also makes the side quests (grinding ones sometimes) much less boring and some can get done while you do the main quest. As for the main story quest, you can alter it depending on who you side with at times. There will be quite a few times where you have to side with people or make key decisions. Although they don't ruin the story if you chose the "other" side, they do change some of the narrative in the future.So onto some of the cons that make me want to rage sometimes. First of all, there is no jump option. This isn't a big deal or anything since the space bar is just atactical pause, but there are quite a few hidden walls where there clearly shouldnt be or could not be. You litearlly cannot jump off any kind of ledge at all, no matter how small. Furthermore, the combat is a bit clunky in many regards and like with the invisible walls, enemies have their own "invisible wall" region that acts like a block. My last critique of this game is their character models. They recycle the same character models for a lot of side characters and some quests characters way too much. The same old man, fat rich man, drunkard, etc keeps appearing over and over. The voice actor is even the same for those most of the time. However, the essential characters are unique and have their own unique voice actors.Overall, the Witcher 1 is a bit clunky, but is well worth the play, especially for the price of $1.49. If you want to play down the series to Witcher 3, it can only get better and therefore by starting with Witcher 1, you derive the maximum possible utility for playing the whole series.Rating: 8.0/10

content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												So, let me tell you a story about how I came to put 38 hours into The Witcher: Enhanced Edition.Like many of the people probably reading this review I was scouring the internet finding out whether or not it was worth playing this game or skipping straight to The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings, before jumping into the recently released and critically acclaimed The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt.A friend of mine (who also left a review here, check it out under 'Thorns') brought me the first 2 in the Steam sale last winter and suggested I played them both.After much research over whether or not the first game was still worth playing, it seemed unanimous that YES, it was because it is a unique and enjoyable game with fantastic lore, music, and characterization (albeit with janky combat and some strange, questionable decisions made throughout) although it wasnt a necessity if i was going to play it for story alone.Well.After taking the plunge I am happy to report that this game is well worth the time and effort I put into playing it, and stands true as one of the most interesting game worlds i've ever had the pleasure of being a part of.YES. The combat is initially a confusing and unrepsonsive mess. You cant use a controller with this game and so the combat consists of you choosing the necessary sword (steel or silver) and a combat style best suited to the situation (strong, fast or group) and quite literally having to time mouse clicks via on screen prompts.Yeah, it's an odd choice.This being said at around hour 4 I had the hang of it and actually came to love and respect it's uniqueness in it's own way. If you can get passed this early on, along with the relatively old animations, occasional hiccup in writing and lack of multiple chracter models (seriously, there cant be anymore than about 20 in this 35+ hour game) then you will be enthralled by the music, the deep and interesting lore, the humor and the cast of fun and enticing characters. In the end I would say I possibly enjoyesd this more than I did The Elder Scrolls V:  Skyrim.I know, that's a bold statement. But I think Skyrim delivered everything I expected and nothing more. The Witcher exceeded my expectations immensely. Don't do what I did and pass on this game because you think it's too old or outdated.Play it, love it.P.S. - You can have sex with a HUGE amount of the women in the game, and each time you do you collect an old school "Nudey" trading card. Just because.On one occasion, I beat up a young girl's father because he wouldnt let me see his daughter to fetch a friend's lute back, convinced I was going to shag her because that's what my friend did. I then proceeded to shag her brains out. She loved it.10/10 would throw done with daddy again...

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												After having a bit of a struggle, I decided to give this game a thumps up. My opinion doesn't differ alot from most of the positive reviews: The Witcher 1 is a game with a well-designed story which is based on the witcher-novels of Andrzej Sapkowski,  astounishing graphics (at least back in it's release-days in 2008), complexe quests and tough/impactful decisions as well as memorable characters...Yet it also suffers from certain problems, mainly considering the fighting system and (from todays perspective) some lesser gameplay issues as well as "bad" graphics and a very deep lore which needs quite some time to be fully understood. This may scare you off if you're not 100% determined to finish this game.In my opinion one should watch some gameplay videos or read the first novel before considering to play this game. This will make it easier to understand the lore and might also give you some determination to play it. All in all one could say that it's worth playing for the sale price of one dollar/euro...

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												A beautiful game, even after 7 years. The Witcher is a dark and rather mature game. You get to make game-changing decisions that let you feel as though you are a part of the game. The first chapter is rather slow, but it gives you time to experiment around and get a feel for the combat. Some of the game mechanics were not explained properly (such as the alchemy) and it took a bit of experimenting to get some things to work. The combat is not truly combat. You click when an icon appears and let your character do the rest. That, coupled with the fact that signs were too overpowered, led to a dull gameplay experience. However, all that are minor annoyances compared to what the game is truly capable of. The developers don't hold your hand and lead you through the entire game. Instead, they give you a few basic tutorials and leave the rest to experimentation. It also helps that alchemy is not a must (unless you're on higher difficulties). All in all, the games treats you like an adult, leaving you with choices that feel real. You must choose between several choices based on your moral code, since nothing in this game is truly black and white. You would be hard pressed to decide sometimes and what you choose really just comes down to what you feel is right. The graphics are'nt amazing, and there are quite a few technical issues, but overall, I feel that this game is worth playing.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												Since coming out in 2007 The Witcher has aged nicely, thanks to some extra care from the devs. The combat system is a bit clunky, and the graphics are certainly not modern, but it nonetheless remains very playable. Compared to other games of that era like Oblivion or Mass Effect it's a bit below them, but a still solid game. If those are 5's this would be a 4.It's a super interesting world and story that has a really nice hook at the beginning. Sadly, the game's pacing suffers for the first half after that. Thankfully it picks up steam in the second half before ending in a full-speed-ahead-rollercoaster-esque finale, complete with some unexpected (but welcome and thoroughly explained) plot twists. I was very happy with the way things ended and everything leading up to it.My biggest complaint other than the pacing problems early on is really difficulty. After the game first gives you some non-linear freedom it is incredibly difficult. Frustratingly so. But somewhere around a third of the way in you unlock enough abilities that it becomes exceedingly easy, and it stays that way through the end. I wish there had been more of a gradual incline rather than this steep cliff drop off. Hopefully the sequels correct this.And my favorite thing about this game is just how adult it is. They really don't hold back and that's something I've been waiting for in games for a very long time. This is really the first game that aligns more with a movie's R rating, and that makes it unique. Some others have caught up recently, but for the time I'd say this was pretty revolutionary.Overall I'm glad to have sunk time into this, and I'll be installing The Witcher 2 soon.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												My first attempt to play through The Witcher came to a halt only 4-5 hours in.  The begining is very slow and feels muted considering the gravity of the situation.  You get tossed into a life or death, crazy situation right off.  After it's over, the game comes to a halt that feels as if it'll never end.  I am sure I am not the only person who thought that was just how The Witcher would be and gave up.  That the map was boring and hollow, sprinkled with fetch quests and long stretches of backtracking.After watching some gameplay for The Witcher 2, I came to the conclusion I was missing out on something special.  So I thought "suffer through the first game to get to the awesome sequel".  Little did I realize, I was about embark on my most favorite (gaming) journey.STORY and PACE:Seriously, this game starts poorly.  The opening is the cliche half tutorial, half prologue stuff you always have to slog through when you buy a game these days.  This really gives the game a generic feel right off.  No reason to play this game over any other.Things only get worse in chapter 1.  The area is rural, with a circular path that comes back to itself and only a few small groups of enter-able buildings with even fewer NPCs.  The quest-line will not impress out the gate either.  You're going to run from one NPC to the next, over and over while dealing with enemies that respawn in the same spots after you leave and come back.  When I said "slog", I meant it.Fortunately,  after an insanely difficult boss battle, chapter 1 closes out.  You'll make a big decision that will immediately change your entire perception of the game.  This is when you'll know if you're in it for the long haul.If you've made it, you'll be glad you stuck with The Witcher. Chapter 2 goes inside city walls and stretches all the way out into a large swamp area.  You'll get loaded full of quests of all different variety.  Meet a lot of interesting characters.  The story starts flying along as well.Not only does the overarching story grab your attention, but so too will the sidequests.  saving, killing or walking away will always be your choice.  Those choices will forever change the direction of the game and will also impact your character for the remained of the series via saved game importing.GAMEPLAY:One big complaint about The Witcher is the combat.  In The Witcher, you use a steel sword on humans and a silver sword on monsters.  You must use the corresponding weapons correctly, or you'll be penalizing yourself heavily.  With those swords you can do three different style of attacks.  One style is based on brutal finishers that really do a lot of damage.  Another style is quicker, to keep pace with fast enemies or to dominate a slow one.  The other style is used to attack groups of enemies all at once.When you attack, a timing mechanic pops up.  If you time your next attack correctly, you will automatically strike your opponent.  This becomes very simple and a bit repetitive after a while.  This makes any boss fights really disappointing too.GRAPHICS:The Witcher is not not high tech by any means, but the atmosphere and art-work really is incredible.  The monsters are ugly, creepy and vile.  The areas all have their own distinct feel.  You will not get sick of seeing the same textures over and over.  The game runs smoothly on fairly old hardware.SOUND:This is a highpoint for the franchise as a whole.  The music is both somber and beautiful.  A lot of interesting instrumentals and soft vocals.  I almost always turn music off in games after I've played them for a few hours, but not here.I have never been more disappointed when the credits started rolling.  Not due to the ending, but the game ending itself.  I am the prototypical jaded gamer and yet even I can't get enough of The Witcher.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												The Witcher is one of my favorite series, with that said the game hasn't aged well. Voice acting is horrible, animations are awful and the combat system is boring. You will spend most of your time running from 1 location to the other doing fetch quests or just aimlessly wandering around until you find a solution to a quest.The issues I had with the combat is that it resembles a clicker game. After chapter 2 you will find yourself dying over and over in certain missions because they decided that you can go 1 v 10 against a room full of enemies. I wouldn't mind this if it weren't for a total stunlock when the enemies surround you, at which point death is certain.For newcomers I would recommend downloading these mods to make the experience somewhat better:- The witcher texturen mod - improves textures for environments and objects- The witcher hi res character models - improves textures for characters- Item Stacking and Equipment Slots Mod - you will need this if you don't plan on organising your inventory every 5 minutes- Faster Movement Mod - this mod increases your movement speed by 25% but can be changed to even more. The game makes you run around, alot. The issue here is that the maps are pretty big and if you plan on doing sidequests you will be running all over the place and the default movement speed is lousy. If you don't want to uninstall after 1 hour pick this up.If you came only for the story you will be satisfied, but only if you don't mind all the shortcomings. An added bonus is that you can import your choices into The Witcher 2.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												The Witcher 1 Enchanced Edition is a great game that is underestimated by many. The biggest issue for people is combat. Well it's not that bad when you're 20h into the game. Of course the combat may be an obstruction for most, but you just need to ignore that single fact. The combat actually becomes enjoyable when you are around level 10-14. thats when the real fun begins.9.5/10Story is just amazing. It starts slowly, introduces player into the world, teaches ropes of the game. Later on it picks up the pace seriously fast throughout the game only to put player under maximum pressure in chapter 5. There is a lot of sex and I mean it. Geralt can have unlimited number of intercourses and he wont have a baby (no need for protection eh? lucky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ :P).Regardless of old age of the game it has a lot to offer and will deliver a lot of fun and enjoyment. If you decide to do completionist walkhrough you need around 55 hours to do so. Not only you get countless sex occasions (that includes threesomes, foursomes even going at it with goddess!). All is presented in very tasteful style and player is rewarded with a hand drawn card of a woman, Geralt had intercourse with. All is done in very tasteful manner, not vulgar <insert any hardcore mature video names here>. Ever wanted to beat up father so hard, that he would beg you to stop only so you could get to his daughter 5 minutes later upstairs while he is still recovering from beating downstairs? This game is definetly for you!The graphic is outdated but that does not matter, in the longer run once you get used to it, you may consider some shader play and reflections actually pretty (i.e. shader play in the sewers, reflections in royal rooms, etc). Textures are so low resolution that its laughable. There is mod to improve overall graphic quality but I didnt use it personally. The game regardless of huge amount of patches that were released, still suffers from occasional stutters in some areas throughout entire game. They occur only in some insignificant places. To do list in the game:* get to know as much women as possible, that includes working girls(if u get a deal with brothel lady, one cheap flower is enough for full service with one of girls:P)* beat up a father till a point he begs you to stop. ofc u get to his daughter 5 mins later upstairs while he is taking the inflicted pain downstairs lol* get in a threesome with 3 nice vampire ladies* get drunk a lot, especially during cutscenes with dandelion * get on in action with village waitress from chapter 1 in the mill, locals will believe ghosts haunt the mill again xD* get drunk hard, purchase a special drunk bonus skill and fight everyone while totally wasted* even more sex!* slay some memorable monsters* seduce a goddess in the game* become so op with strenght and dexteriety that opponents cant hit you 95% of times :D* run around the sarcophagus in crypts while being chased by the striga, do not forget to play benny hill theme in the background! priceless laughs guaranteed :D* beat up everyone in the inn's* get laid even more (food for fun lol)* allow yourself to be immersed into the world of the witcher, this is great world you just need to open yourself for it* fight the evil and bad guys* become a gambling legend and whoop king's butt for almost 4000 orens :D* make decisions that fit your own morality, conscience and values* even more stuff to do, list would be way too long. oh have i mentioned more sex?* epic alvin twist at the end of the gameTo sum things up the Witcher 1 Enchanced Edition is one of greatest games ever released. Great atmosphere, immersion, story, characters, world, amazing soundtrack. There is way too much to  mention! It has its own flaws but lets face it, nothing is perfect. Technnologically (some animations, some movement, some funny bugs are here, but not many). Perfection is plain boring. (this is why ill never understand people abusing plastic surgeries, perfection doesnt exist and each surgery needs maitenance each 6-10 years period). The combat may be flawed but it's very rewarding once your character develops to certain level. If you're looking for great game or want to experience Witcher series from scratch, go ahead and start with first installment of the series. You will not be dissapointed whether you buy it on normal price or as soon as it's on sale. It will be money well spent. Assuming that you have got the game, do not forget to check Witcher 2 Assasins of the Kings and Witcher 3 Wild Hunt :)

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												After tying up every lose ends in the first of the witcher series and nearly logging in 50 hours into this game, I can say that I`m mentally exhausted. I didn`t expect that a game released 7 years ago would achieve such a feat. CD Projekt did a wonderful job creating a deep, rich and satisfying story that reminded me that sometimes having an excellent story is as important as having fantastic gameplay mechanics. Albeit the magnificent tale, the witcher falls short of delivering in its combat system, sometimes being painfully buggy during the heat of battle. Power-ups frequently doesn`t work and some spells are way more overpowered than others. In the end however, the absorbing nature of the game keeps pulling me back for more. I hope the witcher 2 would solve the above issues and it`ll be splendid.Pros:- Undeniably good story- Lots of quests to take on, sometimes overwhelmed by what to do next and often lead astray- Good alchemy and skill tree system- So many chats to chat- Not so terrible graphics for a 2007 gameCons:- Combat mechanics are buggy, some skills are OP, early game is tough for hard mode- Tutorial are thin and for the first few hours, prepare to be confused- Small variety of weapons and armorsHope you enjoyed reading it as much as I enjoyed writing this.This game deserves a 9/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2011
												The Witcher is a unique RPG. It eschews the standard "fight monsters, save the world" formula and instead presents a detective story in 5 chapters. In the city of Vizima, you will unveil plots, woo ladies, play politics, negotiate settlements, and interrogate suspects. You'll make excursions to nearby swamps and cemeteries, so expect a fair dose of combat, but the core of the game is the investigation storyline.Along the way, you'll face ethical quandaries and tough choices. Some choices can significantly affect the game's final chaper. Other choices might simply affect which girl you'll bed that evening...I really enjoyed The Witcher. If I have any complaint, it's the pacing. As each chapter begins, you find yourself assaulted with quests. Eventually you'll figure out how quests turn on and off over the course of the game as you are able to advance each one. Turns out quests are actually highly intertwined plot elements.Despite this complaint, it's a fresh and entertaining RPG.

Posted: March 30
You can say whatever you want but this game actually is a more Witcher game than any of the following one's are.                It has a much more deep atmosphere soaring around the dirty air of a northern kingdoms.                It has a much more deep and mystery and dramatic soundtrack that gives you a real feeling of medieval                                                                                              despair, sadness and fear.And the plot is not a common AAA movie story about someone trying to invade and destroy the human world (i mean it is in core but in detalis it's completely not), Witcher  tells you a bunch of a simple storylines about few characters trying to survive and success in the cruel world of Sapkowski. They are neither good or bad, they are just people, like all we are. It faces a lot of things like faith, greed, racism, politics, simple injustice of our lifes and our world.Witcher just shows the human vices but doesn't push you to make any conclusions. It presents the human world in grey colors where nothing could be good or bad, everything is just exists.Like a great story-teller, it just tells and nothing more.A lot of time passed and you might be frightened by the game graphics or combat mechanics but you still have to play it if you wanna call yourself a real RPG fan. Totally recommended.

												In this third person action RPG you play Geralt of Rivia a warrior/monk for hire who specializes in slaying beasts and ghouls. A sinister plot hangs in the air as you attempt to find a missing comrade, after an attack on your keep. You choose you alliances and your enemies as the mature and gritty sotry line of political intigue and the occult unravels before you. The deeper you dwell the harder it becomes to destinguish who poses the real threat to Geralt, the monsters or the people around him.This game is one of my favorite games of all time, but with that said it it quite a few years old now. The combat system leaves a bit to be desired but the story and the characters are magnificent. If you're a fan of mature fantasy this is for you, you can often pick this game up for pennies on the dollar with it's sequel during every big sale. P.S. If you're one of those nerds who enjoy literature the Witcher books are excellent as well.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2013
												The Witcher is a fantastic rpg released back in 2007. It is a sequel to a series of fantasy novels centering around it's protagonist, Geralt of Rivia. In this game, after his apparent death in the novels. He awakes with amnesia and no recollection of his death nor the people in his life. After that he is launched on a quest of revenge as he remembers who he is.One of the finest aspects of the Witcher is how it's quests are designed. You are never shown the consequences of your actions immediately. Instead, in later chapters of the game you see the results of your choices. This was done to prevent players simply reloading and not accepting the consequences of their actions. As a result your actions really do feel like they have weight, and it's rare to see this executed properly in a game.There are of course negative aspects of the Witcher. Most people cite it's combat as the biggest drawback of the game. I'm inclined to agree, as I initially stopped playing just before finishing the prologue. My advice is to push on past the prologue as you start to really get into the game during it's first chapter. Eventually you will fall inlove with this game and it's timing based combat.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												In this first chapter of the trilogy based on the novels by Andrzej Sapkowski, you play as Geralt of Rivia, the witcher (monster hunter with supernatural abilities).The game came out in 2007 and was later re-released in 2008 in an Enhanced Edition. From a technical standpoint, it's nothing jaw-dropping but it holds up more than well to this day. The story of the game is easily it's strongest point, with a long and compelling story, varied and colorful cast and tons of side missions.The combat can be played in two ways: with an over-the-top camera with mouse controls or an over-the-shoulder mouse'n'keyboard controls. While it is unintuitive at the beginning, through time you'll get better and better and feel really good about yourself. There is a vast array of weapons, mutagens and potions to improve your abilities. The only problem is that the difficulty is kind of unfair even at the easiest setting.Overall, this is a great beginning for a fantasy trilogy that will go down as one of the best ones. Story: 10Graphics: 8Gameplay: 9Challenge: 8Sound: 8Replayability: 6 ENJOYMENT: 8.5FRUSTRATION: 6  I strongly recommend installing "The Rise of the White Wolf", a mod that improves graphics, interface and difficulty settings: http://www.moddb.com/mods/the-rise-of-the-white-wolf-powrt-biaego-wilka

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												The Witcher, the story originally written as a book by Polish writer Andrzej Sapkowski in 1992, feel old? No. This game expands the main storyline very, very well. Good job Poland, you have created something that no one will forget. One of the best RPGs ever made.STORY:The story, as I said before, expands the storyline from the books, and adds something more to it, the game starts with the witcher, Geralt, that looses his memory, is taken to Kael Morhen, the ancient witcher castle, which is now half destroyed and almost empty. The prologue and then the first chapters of the game may seem a little boring and slow, but after it game takes on regarding what decisions you make.GAMEPLAY:For new players, gameplay in prologue is the main thing why the most players stop playing after 10 minutes of the game. The combat system is based on the right timing clicking, so that confuses most people. Geralt can carry up to 3 swords and 1 optional dagger, another small weapon or torch. Also witcher "spells" called signs are introduced, without it it's not witcher after all.In game, players have also 2 gameplay styles, that can be changed through gameplay, 1st is common keyboard+mouse, where you use keys for weapons and movement and mouse for attacking and actions2nd one is mouse and optional keyboard, this style is made only for mouse, so you move your character by clicking on the ground, but keys can be also used.The game can seem very linear, always it's only kill something, deliver something, talk to someone, do something etc. but changing of environment and locations this lineaness pretty lifts.Pros:+ The story (unexpected plot twists yay)+ Awesome soundtrack+ Characters+ Game stands on your decisions (no turning back, make decisions or don't play)+ UmmmmCons:- That sometimes, linear story (it will tear your hair if you have any)- It's easy (unlike second game, this one lets you take potions in combat, and save everywhere you want, everywhere)- The game holds your hand like a little child (it's easy)It's still worth (very) playing8.5/10 (why? Because 8 is too less and 9 is too much)

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17
												I really like the world of Geralt of Rivia and its characters. There's a lot of interesting lore to find and it very often feels like there's a lot more to find out. However the game itself isn't really that fun to play and also the plot seems to be 'padded' at certain times.My biggest complain is the fighting system. RPGs are not all about the combat, but since the 5th chapter and the epilogue really pack a lot of fighting it is quite a problem if the mechanics are that bad. The idea of having two different swords for different enemies is quite interesting and also that you have to find out which style of fighting to use against which enemy is interesting, but the execution of the whole thing is very weak. You have to click on an enemy at the right time to keep the combo going and while that doesn't sound too bad, the camera and the fact that the attacks push your enemy back make it much harder than it should be. The fact that you are very often attacked by more than one enemy and the hit detection isn't great makes it even worse. Only when you fight against one enemy and have him 'cornered' so that the camera doesn't move the combo system feels satisfactory. Otherwise the combat is quite frustrating and levelling doesn't help that much to make it better.The character advancement is blocked by a rather odd bronze/silver/gold point distribution system. This makes it quite hard (almost impossible if you don't grind a lot of levels) to build a specialised character. You'll end up having way too many bronze points that you can only use to unlock the basics in all the skills that you have. Again this wouldn't be a really bad problem if not most of the skills were combat related.There's only a few ways to use 'shortcuts' in the game and while this isn't a big problem there's a good amount of quests that sends you back and fourth between two or more points rather far away that add up to a lot of time running around the rather sad looking environment. Another minor complain is that the only way to really see in dark areas is to use a potion as you can use a torch, but only as a weapon and once you have to fight anything in the dark you either have to use the torch (which is pretty much useless) or switch to a different weapon and fight in the dark.The second chapter is mainly a murder mystery and the setup is quite interesting. However the execution is quirky at best. You'll end up with a lot of dead ends that can only be resolved by doing other quests first. This means you'll end up with a lot of open quests and have to hope that you don't miss something important. This can get frustrating as the game gives you no hints about what you might have to try to progress. The fourth chapter (while is has two pretty interestig quest lines) feels a bit weird as it has almost no connection to the events in the rest of the game.The graphics, music and sounds are pretty decent. It gives the game a dark atmosphere that is only lifted a bit for brief periods. The voice acting in the game is also very good and Geralt's personality seeps through each one of his dialog lines.Overall I can't recommend the game. There's just too much wrong about it to fully enjoy it. I played it for the story and the world, but I really don't feel like going back to see how the different choices play out.

I relied heavily on the Witcher WIkia to make sure I got a desired result.The only redeeming quality for me outside of the mature, dark world  (Theme, setting, Character, story) are some of the Geralt to NPC character interactions, mostly because of his sarcasm. I played through this simply because I picked up this game so many times and dropped it, and told myself to finish it for the Release of Witcher III, which of course, ended up being delayed after I planned my gaming schedule around it - THE ONE TIME I EVER DID THIS!The nail in the coffin is not much of what happens in this game transfers to the second one, outside a couple weapons, a couple storyline choices (some of which are Retconned in the 2nd game like Shani and the Striga, which are IMPORTANT CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT DEVICES), and a mere 1% of the money you had added to your New game in W2. I really can't recommend this to anybody beyond maybe people who play PC RPGs as their primary genre, even then, alot of people can't get past the combat. Even then, many people new to the game recently posted in the community hub said they loved it, so perhaps I'm in the minority.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												I was introduced to the Witcher series by a friend, and I am glad to say that purchasing this game was one of the best decisions I have made. The Witcher is quite possibly the pinnacle of Action/RPG games.The game boasts an old-timey combat system based on stringing together specifically timed attacks into combos that works very well for this game. The types of attack combinations performed are based on specific combat styles that players must switch between based on the situations they find themselves in. Geralt, the main character, can progressively strengthen his combat capabilities by leveling up and spending talent points to lengthen his combos, increase his damage output, increase his alchemical abilities, and much more. The character development aspect of this game is very well done in that it allows players to upgrade Geralt more or less to their own specific play style based on how they wish to spend their talent points. The storyline of this game is really quite remarkable, and its nonlinearity allows players to explore the open world that they are in to their hearts' desire. The quality of the storyline is only compounded by the game's morality system, for which it has recieved much praise. Morality in the Witcher is not a cleanly-cut black-and-white morality system, and the heavy presence of moral gray-areas allow players to judge morality for themselves rather than on the game's own terms and face the consequences of the decisions they make.All in all, the Witcher is a fantastic Action/RPG game, and everyone who is a fan of these types of games will not be dissapointed by it. It is absolutely worth buying even at full price, and is a marvellous and refreshing gaming experience for fans of the Action/RPG gaming genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												The good:A gritty take on High Fantasy Land which shows us the brutality of an actually medieval world, fleshed out characters with a clear hint an author was behind them and the story. The usage of folklore to create an archaic kind of fantasy magic and monsters is something I only remember from Darklands (an ancient RPG in medieval Germany where all folklore and hexes were equally true). Nice interconnection of event, nice ambiguity in the choices. Graphics are dated but still able to convey the story and atmosphere very well.The bad:I was finishing this to get my Witcher fix for Witcher 3 and the controls are jarring and some elements of the combat like stun chains (which can happen to you without anything to do about it) can be plain frustrating. The inventory is kind of a mess. Sometimes you run around the same areas the xth time and I'd really liked a fast travel because this world has none of the emergent stories a real open world RPG has. By today's standards the world tiles are really small and you still need tons of time to traverse them.The ambigious:To some the preset of the character Geralt (the main protagonist of the novels) might feel a bit limiting but it helps to create a deeper story as the character of Geralt is defined to a large degree. Themes are mature with excessive romance to the point of self parody but also a pretty dark world where none is 100% good.Conclusion:This is primarily a story driven game and I only played it for that. In that sense they could have thrown out plenty of the decisions (which do not have very deep impact on the story anyway) and it would still be interesting to see the relations of fleshed out characters and a well established world.I would recommend the story, but cannot blame anyone taking shortcuts on the gameplay.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
The Witcher, worth buyingOverall impressionIt is an older game, but the graphics are okay. I really enjoyed the atmosphere in this game and the story is entertaining and intersting. I haven't read the books, but the game makes me consider to give those a try because everything appears to be well-thought-out. With all the different options and styles it might take a while before you feel comfortable with the controls, but soon as you remember the hotkeys it becomes a second nature. Geralt's sarcasm and sense of humor really made me enjoy the various dialogues. I also love the fact that this is a mature game with mature content because that fits the medieval setting and makes it feel more immersive. And yes, I had fun to collect all those cards! Player advice:Save early, save often. Learn to play the dice poker game, it is the best way to earn money and remember that everything you do in this game has consequences that can alter the story and make things easier or harder for you.   Bugs: In the first few chapters I encountered no problems. But after chapter 3 the game crashed every few hours. By the time I started chapter 4 it happened every few minutes. The screen often turned black (even though the game itself continued) and/or crashes to desktop often ignoring my last save. It really killed the fun (and my mood) but thanks to various websites I found a way to prevent that from happening; disable the autosave and do not use more than 15 savegame slots to prevent crashes. If you play the game in windowed mode it is less likely to crash and you can download a tool that allows you to play the game windowed whilst appearing to be full screen. After that, the game worked fine again and I've experienced no more crashes.Could be better: I really hope the sequels are less likely to crash, if it wasn't for all the good information of how to prevent it I would have likely stopped playing the game because of that. That said, I'm glad I didn't stop because the game itself was really enjoyable and I want to buy the sequel games as well. Frustrating is Geralt's tiny inventory combined with the item-overkill in the game. You often end up selling or discarding items that you could use a few moments later, or you carry something with you that you have no use of at all. More NPC-models would also be an improvement because you always look at the same old hag because there is only one model for elderly women. Which would not be so frustrating if they were able to age gracefully... Final thingy; I would have never thought I would say this, but please lower the number of redheads in game. I know we are sexy as hell but we do not make up for 85% of the female population... ;-)
