number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												Pros:- Engaging story with non-obvious plot twists.- Excellent voice acting.- Choice-based story consequences.- Long adventure.- Good mix of spells/swords/crafting to keep you entertained.- Additional adventures included by devs and fans that add backstory. Neutral: - No controller support. - Ok background music.-Your decisions not only impact the story, but some lore-important side-quests will be closed off to you depending on what you choose to do/who you do or do not randomly run into in the cities.  There's no real way to experience all the quests without looking online the first time you play.  Some people may like this, but I don't feel this game merits a second play through just to pick up the remaining quests that complete the background lore.  There's often no warning you are completing a main-quest segment and will be leaving the area either, making it double challenging to find all the side-quests yourself.Cons:- Quite unstable for me on Windows 10.  It took me 5 in-game hours and many tweaks to get the crashing down from once every 20 mins to once every couple hours.  They should really re-think the two-hour return limit.- Many glitches and bugs.  There were times a character would try to hand me an important quest item, but my inventory was full, so the item just disappeared from the game.  The last chapter is totally unpolished and many of the mechanics don't work normally at the end of the game.  Several randomly bugged character textures as well, making me think a disfigured monster was attacking when it was actually a book merchant. - The swordplay is based around timed clicking.  This worked ok for Legend of Dragoon, but for an action RPG it feels a little silly.- The cities would often drop down to less than 30 fps in crowded areas, despite using far better hardware than was available when this game came out (using an i5 4590 and an R9 390).- The country-side part of the world feels big and empty, almost like this was supposed to be some kind of MMO but is void of life.- Some weapons and ability upgrades are not spaced out well and come FAR too late into the game so that most of them are pointless.- If you don't do things in the order the game was expecting, it can get confused and your journal will tell you to go somewhere that isn't where you are supposed to go.  The game catches up eventually when you pass certain checkpoints, but the story feels out of order and you wind up feeling like you are missing something.Conclusions: I view a "thumbs up" as saying this game is worth paying full price for.  If you want to play this game for the full Witcher experience, wait until it is on sale.  I view this game as skippable in the series.  Obviously I trudged through and I enjoyed the story, but the game was a mess to play with few solutions to common problems, and it single-handedly convinced me the refund window needs to be lengthened.

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6
												After hearing such good things about The Witcher III, I decided to finally finish a full playthrough of the earlier games before starting in on the third, but I guess it took at least one iteration of Witcher games for CD Projekt Red to actually figure out how to make a functioning game, because The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is a pile of beta-stage crap.- Half of the "innovative" combat features are pointless and often do not work at all. Parrying, bleeding, precise hits, etc. are nothing more than behind the scenes numbers that offer nothing to enrich tedious combat (which consists of absolutely nothing more than swing format A, B or C). Dodging is slower than simply turning around and moving forward, and often enough Geralt is simply not allowed to dogde at all, for seemingly arbitrary reasons. When moving any other direction But forward, Geralt moves like an arthritis-wracked stump, lurching and dragging himself to his death (This gets worse when intoxicated, which is amusing because the game encourages drunk fighting via particular talents). Geralt will frequently refuse any input, disallowing motion, signs, combat, anything. Hit recognition seems to have been abandoned halfway through development, allowing Geralt to be hit across rooms, while opponents spend minutes at a time dodging every single combat style Geralt is allowed, even when knocked down or stunned.- A large amount of talents serve little to no purpose at all, only being taken because of the poorly conceived level system shoving enough talents in your face to unlock literally everything in almost no time at all. So much for strategic specialization. The same goes for potion-brewing, where even on the highest difficulty, where "potions are necessary" the lore-based toxicity system means you will use the same three (out of a few dozen) potions the entire game. The same goes for signs, with nothing past your first unlocked sign being of any use at all. All signs will often have no effect whatsoever, and no explanation is given as to why, not to mention arbitrarily "failing" every few attempts, and not being cast at all.- Sub-quests are the same tedious gather and kill quests RPG players have been tired of for years. Inventory is even more menial, being filled with dozens of random item variations (no doubt meant to be exotic, but instead are just a bother). You're forced to keep everything in order to satisfy the insanely random whims of NPCs desiring particular gifts, but are offered exactly zero in-game functions to track the inane demands of the masses.- Progression consists of new areas filled with old enemies, recolored and renamed. For being a monster-hunter, in a world that is, according to the story, more filled with monsters than ever, there are no more than about 12 species of monster in the entire game.To contrast what Projekt Red brags that their game is:"Enhanced inventory" forces collection to satisfy obscure quests, and storing items in the inn forces you to complete a quantity slider for every single item withdrawn. Red boasts superior item organiztion, but inn storage has absolutely no management options, and does not sort item categories at all, giving you a jumbled, small-fonted mess."Technical improvements" that list combat responsiveness improvements make me shudder to think how slow the game was beforehand. Input lag for signs and dodging is so long that it makes them liabilities in combat as opposed to boons."Character differentiation system" is a cute, bashful way of asking players if it's okay that they don't make new models, because this new enemy is two shades darker than the monster you fought last chapter, and that ♥♥♥♥♥s skirt is blue instead of green."Choose from over 250 special abilities" there are 226 talents, many of which are, as mentioned above, obselete. If you're going to blatantly lie in your bragging, at least make sure what you Did manage to cobble together is at least worth a damn.Later Witcher games might be good, I couldn't say. But skip this one and read a summary, because all playing this game is going to do is put you off the series by being a really garbage game.

number of helpful: 144 of 283 people (51%) found this review helpful42 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
The Witcher ManBefore I begin, let me make a couple of things clear:I have not read the books, and this is not a book review. I'm also not here to make comparisons between the games and books. This is a game review only.If I could give this game a rating between thumbs up and thumbs down... say, like, a fist... I would do that, because my opinion is very mixed. But since I have more negative things to say than positive, I have to give it a thumbs down.I'm not out to "get" you if you enjoy this game, and what makes the world go 'round are differences in opinions. Do not take my criticisms as personal attacks on you and understand that reviews are opinions, and nothing will make me reassess mine. If you want to yell at me about my opinion and tell me how wrong I am and that I'm just some "simpleton", understand that nothing is going to change my mind, so you're only wasting your own time. This review is based on my own experiences with the game and how I reacted to it. Know that not everyone will experience a game the same way.What I liked about the game:1) In The Witcher, there are some pretty decent RPG elements. I like the leveling system, for one. I enjoy the fact that Strength, Dexterity, Endurance, and Intelligence have their own trees to pick from, and that you can also level up your weapons.2) The characters are amusing. Well, the male ones, anyway. The female ones are just sex dispensers with legs. I’ll get to that later.3) I love the alchemy. The starting potions are very “meh” but later you can craft much better ones and be practically unkillable. I also love picking up herbs to craft potions.4) The game on normal is just that: normal. Some games I’ve played on normal (especially fantasy RPGs) seem like the developers misunderstood what “normal” difficulty means.5) The brawling. It's stupid easy to do, so you can make some pretty decent cash off of it.6) I love the music. It fits a fantasy setting perfectly.7) The graphics in the Enhanced Edition are lovely and colorful, especially on the high graphics setting (Although it does seem to have a lot of stuttering and optimization issues).8) The gloomy, rainy weather.What I didn't like about the game:1) The dialogue is very dragging and leaves something to be desired. I'm all for story and role-playing, and I know this game was a book first, but there is a lot of talking, and much of the game's length is padded by it. What the characters sometimes say is very pretentious at times, and at other times, it tries too hard to be “edgy” by making everyone cuss all the time. I have nothing against swearing-- I swear like a sailor in real life-- but I don't do it half as much as this game did. You know that one kid in school who just learned to swear and thinks it’s the greatest thing ever? Yeah. That’s this game’s dialogue. And target audience.2) Female characters almost always have one of two purposes, or at times, both: to be rescued, or to be boned. No matter who the woman is, she will throw herself on Geralt (or whom I love to call "Greyalt") at the opportunity to screw him. I once talked to some elf girl who said she could teach me her language. “Cool!” I thought. “I want to learn elf language! That might come in handy for my character!” Next thing I know, her half-naked trading card flashes me out of nowhere and we’re screwing each other (or gelling together in the background, at least). What the hell? I wanted to learn elvish! I didn’t want to screw her! Then she wandered off and I never saw her again. Great. Pointless. Thank you for wasting my time. Many encounters I had with women were purely accidental out of my desire for completing all of the quests in the game.Despite this complaint, it is really good for a laugh seeing just how hard they were trying to up the sexiness of the game. People say the weirdest sexual things at really odd, inopportune moments, and it’s over-the-top, cheesy as all get out and hilarious. For example: "I can conjure up ♥♥♥♥♥♥s". Who says that, even if you are a sorceress?3) The combat. Yeah, you knew this was coming. This is the most common complaint about The Witcher, and it is 100% justified. It's extremely boring. Click. Wait for the cursor to turn orange. Click. Wait for it to turn orange again. Click. Again. Again. Again. It’s not that it’s hard, or complicated. It’s tedious and puts me to sleep. I have yet to try out Witcher 2, and I pray the combat is nothing like this one. One of the more tedious things about it is switching weapons for different enemies and situations, and how long it takes for him to pull out the next weapon. The game has to register that you made the change, so while you're waiting for Greyalt to pull out his other sword, you're standing there getting pummeled.4) There are no faster means of travel, and the maps are huge. This isn’t too big of a complaint, because I love massive environments. However, I still would have liked a mount of some kind to make it a little quicker.5) The quest tracking is a great feature, but sometimes it’s just plain wrong. It’ll tell you where a character might be rather than where they currently are.6) Those sub-weapons. They’re useless. Except the torch. I love the torch.7) The Signs aren’t good enough for me. Never used them, and I still completed the game just fine without them.8) Fetch quests. I eventually avoided taking contracts. I made money punching people instead. This didn't change the game's plot at all.9) Greyalt is a lousy protagonist. He’s a sarcastic♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that is always looking to start fights. I get that he’s supposed to be a “tough guy” or whatever, but he doesn’t seem to like or get along with anyone unless they open their legs for him. He talks in this really annoying Batman voice and never smiles. He's too busy brooding about which woman to be with.10) This contains semi-spoilers: Alvin (who I call "The Chipmunk"). There was no point to his existence other than to hook you up with one of two women and to pad the game with even more dialogue. You waste so much time playing around with this little runt, and nothing (interesting) ever comes of it. When the game came to its conclusion, I hadn't seen him for two chapters, and he never showed up again. It's possible that your connection with him is based on the path you chose... but should that really matter?11) Greyalt’s “amnesia” is conveniently gone when the plot calls for it.12) Drowners.Biggest Disappointment:This conclusion contains spoilersI have two: the romance elements, and Rayla.Simply put, Rayla was the only female character in the game I actually liked. However, she is never a romance option for you. Well, you can bone her once. But that doesn’t mean a thing. Because she dies immediately after. Twice. First by what’s-his-elfin’-name, and again by you, and you have no choice in this matter. The game saddles you with two possible perma-romance options: Shani (who I call "Yawni") and Triss ("Twits"). I didn’t like Yawni or Twits very much, but because I wanted to give Alvin a place to stay, I figured “here, Yawni, you take him. He’d be better off with you than Twits, who I swear is a psycho in disguise.” Yawni immediately attaches herself to you, even if you don’t want it, and begins to tell you she loves you and pretty much asks you straight up to marry her and have a little family with her. Um, holy crap? I didn’t want this. It seemed like the game refused to move forward unless you settled down with one of them. Well, I didn't like either of them. I called Yawni my "friend" and went about my business. Take that, game.

												With the impending launch of TW3, I made the decision to replay TW and TW2. I didn't finish TW my first time around as I loat interest around chapter 3. Level system allows for some customization. I fully upgraded igni and aard for instance.3. Hard is challenging without using alchemy constantly. 4. Choices matter for the storyline.Drawbacks:1. Combat is static. 3 styles and then signs. Once you know which style and swords to use you can cut up just about any enemy.2. Collecting alchemy ingredients is tedious as is running out of inventory for them.3. Side quests are very repetitive.  Kill x of y. Must read some book first. Boring!4. You can't change geralt's hairstyle!!!!5. Not for younger gamers as there is quite a bit of sexual content. Almost unnecessarily at times. I mean, the nurses? Really?6. Storyline in this game is unnecessary to enjoy TW2. Characters met at the beginning are not revisited after the prologue. Looking forward to seeing them in TW3.7. Some failed quests always remain active in your log. Hot potato for one.8. Holy lag starting in Chapter 3. FPS averaged around 30 in the Trade Quarter and sometimes lower at night in the swamp.Though I have more drawbacks than good points, it can still be worth playing if you like the gameplay mechanics, which grew on me I'll admit. For $1.99 on steam sale, why not buy it?

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												The Witcher is an amazing RPG that features some of the best storytelling and decision making I have ever seen. Everything decision, whether through actions or dialogue, carry weight and actively change the world around you. The game takes around 35-45 hours to complete, depending on how many side quests you do. There is a large amount of content in the game and warrants several playthroughs to see how different decisions change the course of the game. There are only two minor complaints that I have in this wonderful game. The first is the combat, while engaging, tended to be either a bit buggy or laggy, one of the two. The second complaint is a very minor complaint and partially is my fault for I have a short attention span. Some of the areas require a long walk to get from eachother, and you have to go back and forth quite a few times. I started to get bored of the long walks. Overall, the game is a very indepth RPG that defiently warrants several playthroughs. I highly recommend The Witcher to anyone who is a fan of RPGs.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Fantastic game. Took about 50 hours to beat the game 100%, so not too long for a RPG. Regardless, excellent story, great graphics for when it came out and for the most part, great voice acting. (Excluding Dandelion...) Fascinating world, and lot's of fun to be had. Plus there are boobies. And monsters that let their wang hang all the way. (You know, if you're into that sort of thing.)Really dark and mature, and slightly depressing. Game does not shy away from adult content/humor. Plus there is so much sex. No really. This game is like Game of Thrones but for video games. Geralt is such a player that it's not funny. At one point you can choose to have an affair that takes up an entire chapter of the game. It's great fun.Fun decision making with real consequences and some cool optional quests. Also very memorable characters... easy to know what you need to do, and the game isn't overly difficult. (That is if you don't mind spending hours and hours grinding your levels)Plus, it has a great cliff hanger leading straight into the sequel...Highly recommended. Especially since Steam sells the definitive Director's Cut for so cheap.Don't think, just buy it. It's the best RPG you'll play on PC until you play the superior sequel.My rating: A+Happy hunting.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												The Witcher is a RPG game set in a dark fantasy universe. The atmosphere resembles the dark middle ages, where poverty, war and disease has struck down on the denizens of this world.You are Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher who is both respected and despised for his line of work. Your profession is to dispose of creatures of the dark, demons and foul creatures by means of spell, sword and alchemy.However, in the beginning of the game you are struck by amnesia and thus your past is unknown to you. This is a central plot in the game, as you will carve your own destiney in the god-forsaken universe of the Witcher. Choosing between right and wrong is difficult, if not impossible, as every decision you make will depend on your own moral code. There are no heroes, no real villains, as everyone is fighting for themselves and characters are thus "grey" - they all contain classically noble character traits and "evil" traits. Consequently, the demons you are sent to kill can appear more humane than the village priest who would rather have you kill seemingly innocent people. The game is highly recommendable, despite its now outdated graphics. The quality of the game experience is enjoyable, and several replays is almost inevitable if you want to know what would have happened if you just had sided with the other faction.. or none at all.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												This game is generally compared unfavourably to its immediate successor as "dated" and "arcane", "clunky" and "frustrating".Released in September 2008 (7 years ago), you would not blame today's gamers - foisted on to the world of gaming through the generic open-world UbiSoft generic AAA collectathon trash as well as "high-fidelity, linear cinematic experiences" such as COD - to draw hasty conclusions.But draw back a little and remember that those graphics were once revolutionary, and if you can appreciate them for what they were (note: if you are not a millenial this should be easier) and look to the far more elegant design of game mechanics based on story, player autonomy and experimentation...well then, what you have here is a bona-fide RPG classic experience. Well written, clever and witty, with those all-important story impacting choices, character progression and build refinement, I think this is one of the most pleasant games I have played in the last year and easily the most rewarding (I played and got tired of both Bioshock Infinite and The Walking Dead Season 2, but kept coming back to this game).Beautifully done, and with a more gritty mature take on the genre, the game fits in perfectly in the world of Andrzej Sapkowski. A little word of advice - if you plan to read the series then do so first before playing the games or else MAJOR story spoilers will ensue.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												It's pretty rough around the edges (which is understandable given its age and place in CD Projekt Red's catalogue) but quite enjoyable. It is unlike any other RPG I've played in a while. I love the special agent/PI character that is Geralt, it's quite unique for the genre. As is the combat style. Fights (including boss fights) can be surprisingly easy or incredibly difficult based on how much you've paid attention and done your homework. For players of other series, the game has level design and exploration along the lines of Dragon Age, with a combat style that (oddly) reminds me of the Jedi Knight games.The game has many faults, though. Character assets are reused over and over with only a couple dozen unique characters in the game (surprisingly, though, this didn't irritate me as much as it might sound). Voice acting cutscenes are of a mediocre quality; not terrible but they've been surpassed elsewhere (like the subsequent entries in the series). Combat can be incredibly frustrating sometimes. For example, being stunned repeatedly by four wraiths to the point you cannot move or attack is maddening. It also felt that there were too many elements to the game, some of which can be (and ultimately have to be) ignored in favour of others. For example, I didn't get anywhere near maxing out my character (despite doing every quest) and never touched bombs. I also didn't feel all the signs were as useful as they could be; some easily overshadow others. Combat is generally quite easy (with a few exceptions).I very much enjoyed the claustrophobic, urban setting of the first half of the game. When it changed setting in the second half I was, at first, relieved for a change of scenery but the following areas (while containing enjoyable quests) are overly large and it feels like all you're ever doing is walking from point to point (with, surprisingly - compared to earlier areas - few enemies to worry about). The game also has a somewhat awkward, somewhat rewarding epilogue sequence, a huge twist (if you're paying attention) and a cliffhanger ending.Overall, I'd recommend it if you really want to play the entire trilogy. But if you're not that fussed, I'd probably suggest just reading up on what happens in the first game (and about its characters) and moving on to The Witcher 2 (where things improve and change drastically).

												When the Witcher 3 came out I was so eager to play it that i decided to first play The Witcher 1 & 2 beforehand. 												I got this in a Steam sale earlier in the year for around £1 then played for a couple of hours of just the prologue up till the begining of the first chapter. As the combat took some getting use too for me I didn't touch it again.  After a few months I'm back on it, having played further into the story it really has drawn me in. I've also got use to the combat now. The combat itself was for me the only major negative I could think of  that this game had but like I said now I have got use to it. Also some of the voice acting could have been done better. It's not an open world rpg such as Skyrim but has much more depth than that title. It deals with various shades of grey rather than just a moral outlook of black and white.I haven't any of the other Witcher games so I can't compare this one one to the others. I can say that this is a very immersive and good looking rpg. The artwork is very good. If you do see it on sale it is a no brainer to get it and at full price it is still worth it.

This first game intoduces you to Temeria and to it's citizens by interacting with them while you're there and making progress on your storyline. content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												I wanted to play all the witcher games in order so started here, I had initially tried to get in to the game a while ago and just didn't enjoy it, I decided to give it another shot. It has a pretty slow beginning and there is a lot to learn in terms of all the mechanics of the game. Combat can be clunky but I thought it was okay.For me what made this game so great was how immersive it was, not in the sense of awesome graphics, but just how deep and complex the world is, I loved reading all of the background material and the story has lots of twists and turns which for me is what helped keep me hooked and drive me forward. There are some interesting moral choices and I love that none of your choices are "the right choice" everything is morally grey and its up to you.It has its flaws but its worth it for a glimpse into the dark and mysterious world of the Witcher with plenty of unforgettable characters along the way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												Where to begin with the Witcher.The series follows one Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher, through his journeys as a monster slayer, if you've read any of the novels it's based off of you'd know such that the tales are oft delicate. There's not one sure defined answer but it'll be the one that Geralt decides to go with. He's a complex character that does just about whatever he wants to meet his goals, which is why he's fun to play as or hear about. The world this Witcher inhabits is riddled with politics, greed, murder, racism, lust, and whatever other humanly attributes you can think of. Racism is one card I've found interesting in this universe as it's something most other fantasy will stray from. More to the point it is a key driving cause in the present world that Geralt inhabits which causes conflict between the humans and the non-humans. Ingame this conflict is presented throught he Order of the Eternal Flame and the Scoia'tael.I had tried years past playing through this game and struggling to make ground, the controls all felt off and it felt like there was no possible way I would ever make it through. This time I tried again with more patience to learn everything, and I felt that it paid off very well. The game is more of a Strategy RPG than anything else, you essentially click and wait until you've done the 'cutscene' attack and then click again in time to proceed through the attacks, these attacks have to be selected for the opponent in question with strong/quick/group attack variations. You can easily break this element by simply clicking the mouse fast enough and overwhelm your opponent. So the gameplay falls apart quite quick in my opinion. But if you choose to not break the game like I've mentioned, it's still pretty satisfying. The game allows you enough skill points (if you level enough) to acquire nearly EVERYTHING in the game. So regardless of how you do your build you'll still wind up broken at the end of the game. There are a couple of different "builds" you can do but in my opinion the Igni build trumps everything else.Gameplay doesn't end there as most quests require investigations either by reading books with lore to perform tasks like extracting herbs/ingredients from monsters. Potions are also a large part of the game and help out LOADS when it comes to combat.I thought the economy was worthless in this game as money means nothing in the end, spend it all on books or things to progress. You get best weapons and armor free of charge if you make correct decisions.So now let's do spoilers.=================================================================The choices in the game felt all wrong, only an hour or two into the sequel (W2:Assassins of Kings), it had already outdone any of the decisions in the first game where I had to sit and think extraordinarily hard about how I should proceed (referencing: In the Claws of Madness). The Scoia'tael never give a convincing reason to join them, in fact they never explain anything aside from Yaevinn stating a slippery slope fallacy in that: Geralt as a nonhuman will one day change his mind like Yaevinn had. It's unreasonable to blindly join the Scoia'tael (a terrorist group) to give me insight to understand them. Yaevinn had his chance to give a valid argument and gave a faulty one. While preaching about fighting for rights, it's apparent that the Scoia'tael would give humans the same treatment in a reversed situation.The order was far more reasonable but then suddenly decided that they needed to be unreasonable at the end. They just start slaughtering non-humans because the Grand Master said to. Throughout the game we're led to believe they're racist or oppressing the non-humans but the player never witnesses any of this until the massacre shenanigans which felt offputting.So both sides suck equally, however player decisions are even worse.Allow the Scoia'tael to steal crates? Y/NScoia'tael jump the Order and kill some people. Which side do you fight for?The Scoia'tael are performing bank robbery, want to join? Y/NOrder decides to purge non-humans, Scoia'tael fight back - in the marshes the Order plan on killing the Scoia'tael unit even if they surrender. At the same time the Scoia'tael have killed some hostages already.Which side do you join? The other will be massacred.Horrendous right? It's hard to pick a side when both were being unreasonable. Yes there are other decisions in the game but these are supposed to be the 'main ones' that affect the story. And despite the story claiming that staying neutral is impossible, there's actually a neutral side where you tell both groups to ♥♥♥♥ off. It just felt like there was always one blatantly right choice to pick throughout the game. (Minus the Triss/Shani decision for Alvin which is a romance decision.)Other problems I had with this game-Geralt was never defined as a character even at the end of the game, his history is left untouched which leaves a lot to be desired. It feels misleading to have quests in the game that act like we'll uncover who Geralt is but never do so.-The main plot of the game until the epilogue is "Azar Javed steals Witcher secrets for ???". It makes it hard to hate Azar Javed in any sense. The professor was easier to dislike (as he kills a friendly Witcher) but he never had any real motivations besides being the lackey to the other guy. -The final boss was a damn good concept but he should have had some role in an earlier chapter of the game. While we got to affect who he became, it's not the same as having him nearby only to find out he betrays you right at the end. We care so little about the Grand Master that when he's defeated, we only care who he was not what he became. I think the ending could've been even more powerful if we cared about the Grand Master to begin with and understood where he was coming from, not understanding him after we've killed him. It's putting the cart before the horse (i.e. priorities are all backways).-The game rewards the player for exploring however by doing this you can also mess up the quest order (affecting other quests) and Geralt will make explanations on things the player hasn't learned yet. -Game allows NPCs to just kinda disappear and involve them somewhere else, it's annoying because you can have a quest to turn in but because "blank" is happening, they're somewhere else from where the quest marker has them. Some quests will get bugged out from proceeding through the main story and you can never turn them in anyways.-The length of the game: Many people complain the game is too long to get rebuttled with "you don't like longer games?", to phrase a more correct complaint: It's too damn repetitive.Much of the game consists of walking from one place to another, the worst chapter and contender for that title is EASILY Chapter IV. Chapter I and II are great in that there feels like no unneeded content, everything is situated nicely and compact. Chapter III is essentially all of Chapter II with some added areas and repeated quests (go kill NEW monsters that didn't spawn earlier), but is overall repeated content. Chapter IV is awful for quests like "buy bread and come back" or "go to the village repair a mirror and come back". Nearly 90% of the map could be cut out with no negative consequences. Then Chapter V opens to even worse maps of four(?)-ish caves, a map that's 90% swamp, and burning Vizima which also could've been cut since you're there for all ten minutes before leaving to the swamp map. The Epilogue was just a hallway, but it was also meant to end the game which gives it a free pass I suppose.=================================================================

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												I played through this game on easy and just listened in to the story for the most part. Even on easy the game was pretty challenging in parts, but not really due to the difficulty, but due to the very clunky combat system. I felt like I was fighting Geralt's glitchy moves more than I was the monsters at times. However, the game as a whole is pretty good. It's a decently long game and there's a bunch of quests. There's a bit too much backtracking for my tastes, particularly in Chapters 2 and 4 and the quests at times can feel arbitrary (go to person A, find person B, find out person B is dead and then have to talk to A. Go find person C so they can give you xp and orens). I can really only recommend this game if you really don't wanna feel left out for some of the characters in The Witcher 2 and you want to transfer your save file over to the 2nd game a la Mass Effect style. If the game's combat really turns you off that much, I'd honestly just find a wiki summary of the story and read that, though you'd be missing out on the pretty good character interaction.TL;DR: The game is clunky and feels very dated, but the main story is really enthralling and worth the trip if you care about the lore enough.

It's worth noting that this particular company is against DRM and overpriced DLC's.There are more than enough reasons for me to support this company in the future.The story continues into the second game, but I'll bring that up in my review for that game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												It is probably helpful for the reader if I compare The Witcher to Skyrim:While Skyrim 'feels' like a computer game, a role playing game, and maybe could be described as having a slight theatrical vibe, playing The Witcher feels like reading a good book. It is very character- and story-focused. Geralt of Rivia is a very down-to-earth and likeable character and the game doesn't try to glorify or overly dramatize things. Those subtleties make the game feel even more believable and realistic than the medieval setting already does.I was worried that because of this, the game might be overly gruesome, but it's not. It has a certain charme.I actually like that the game world is relatively limited and that you revisit places a lot, which change every now and then. It gives the whole setting more depth. I also can more easily relate to the various quests, see them as part of a whole. At times the game makes it difficult to stop, because, as I said, it's like reading a good book where you're always at some interesting point.The combat isn't overly detailed, which makes it more fun to play around with the various combat stances and alchemical helpers and just watch and enjoy the action. I also like the very limited selection of weapons and armor. It would just be unnecessary complication. I personally don't like stuff that much, and the alchemy is still tolerable to me, because when you play on medium difficulty, you don't have to dive deep into that. A few potions here and there and it'll be fine.I like very much how the game doesn't put too much time pressure on you. Many of the temporarily active helpers are long-lasting (e.g. a blade sharpening that lasts a full day of in-game time), and the in-game time progresses slowly enough that you don't end up hurrying around before the 'wrong time of day' sets in.It's easy for me to overlook the various small flaws of the game. They're not too immersion-breaking, and the UI has some minor complications that aren't too bothersome. (Among the things that bother me most is that in some free range areas there are artificial fences, requiring you to walk all the way around. But it's just a minor inconvenience.)The decisions you make in various situations don't feel like dummies that pretend to have an effect, but there are (some) consequences, so you actually feel like playing a role.I sometimes would have wished for more flexibility in dialogues when decision-making is involved, but again: Not a big deal.The Witcher is just so different from that 'typical game experience'. A very good translation of a book series to a computer game. Again... It's almost as if you're 'playing a novel', but totally not like an interactive novel, and also not like those modern games that linearly push you from scene to scene, but a proper, mature computer game with focus on story and character interaction. You're wandering around in a story.In fact, what makes this game great reminds me a bit of the Half-Life series, but with less action and less linearity. At least the first game was based on the work of a real horror story author.Specific things that bothered me significantly:- No access to storage in chapter 5 - you have to work with what you have and can't restock from your storage. Even worse, at the beginning of the chapter you are allowed access, but shortly after, you are barred from it.- Voice dialogues contain many instances of wrong emphasis due to the VA not knowing the context of the line.- Geralt keeps sheathing his weapon after a few seconds against my intention to not do that.- Drawing the sword (except in strong stance) makes Geralt move faster, so basically for fast travel always draw your sword. I wish there was a better way to travel quickly than this obvious workaround.- Fist fight is very weird. There are skills for various moves, but not enough tutorial to explain how they work, so my fist fighting ended up very simplistic. Situation-dependent combos rarely ever worked properly.- Geralt of Review

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												If you played Witcher 2/3 and wondering if this game is worth checking out, I say yes if you were big into the stories of those games. I played 2 and 3 first and was very surprised first of all by how ambitious the story of this older game is, but also by how much continuity there is between all three games. If you played 2/3, you probably followed along the story just fine, but you missed more than you think if you haven't played this game. And again, the story of this game is just as ambitious as its successors, even if the game itself is pretty rough around the edges.As far as the gameplay, the combat bears little resemblance to its sequels, while the quest format felt surprisingly similar to Witcher 3. I think Witcher 3 is the game they wished they could have made in 2007, if CDPR had the tech and resources back then. But I must be clear about one thing: "clunky" isn't even a good descriptor for this game's combat system. The combat in this game straight up sucks. It's as idiotic as it is frustrating. However in my view it is worth putting up with if you were a fan of Witcher 2/3's stories or just a fan of story-driven games in general.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												The game makes a great and mostly efficient effort at immersion, especially in OTS camera mode, and it's greatly appreciated.However, it all tends to get wrecked by how poorly the quests' parallel timelines are handled: nothing prevents you from advancing in the "wrong" order, but the game often can't deal with you coming at an event from a different angle, and you can quite easily find yourself trecking up a questline backwards, or triggering two or three cinematic scenes at once because you're "catching up" with how far you advanced the other related quests before reaching that trigger zone.A couple of hints for that:1) If a fight seems difficult => you're doing it wrong. You're not supposed to be there, or you missed an environment clue to help with the fight.2) When investigating Salamandra in Vizima => go back and visit the detective's house often, as soon as you get any new developement in any other quest, even minimal…Another point that annoyed me, but it may be nothing to you: the game gets disturbingly sexist, esp in Chapter 3 which deals with Geralt's personal life.The "all named female characters can be swooned by the mere appearance of Hero" I could deal with - F9 is your friend -  but the systematic tone and direction of "Aaah, these damn women, they're unreliable, demanding, unappreciative and impossible to understand, but do we love screwing them!" seriously got on my nerves after a while. =.=Not to mention the infamous catfight rule: 2 women in the same storyline? They're going to be jerks to each other and fight for the attention of whatever man is in the middle". Meh, come on game this is painfully childish. At its worst it felt like the story had been written for - and BY - frustrated teenage boys who watch too much bad TV. :|Yet when all that is said and done, I do recommend that game. I loved more aspects of it than the bad ones annoyed me, and I'm definitely going to replay in hard mode to get the best of it. :)I love the fighting mechanics, even though they may seem a bit… aged if you play the more recent famous titles, but they're clean and easy to master, making the game much more entertaining than stressful for fragile hearts like mine. i only scare-jumped ONCE, and it was my fault for forgetting I wasn't paused when I turned and - Hi, ghoul slashing my face. :<

												The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is an extremely immersive game if you let it be. I didn't like it the first time I tried it because I didn't know what I was getting into. The second time however I feel in love. I will note a few things though:The game as a whole is dull until Chapter 2The game focuses on dialog and character development as much if not more than combat. For instance: You hold down shift to see your mouse cursor to click on your signs. There I just saved you 5 minutes of google searching.The dialog is really bad in the first chapter, but significantly raises in quality after that.Closing Thoughts: If you like RPG's that are character driven this is the game for you. 												I wanted to play all the witcher games in order so started here, I had initially tried to get in to the game a while ago and just didn't enjoy it, I decided to give it another shot. It has a pretty slow beginning and there is a lot to learn in terms of all the mechanics of the game. Combat can be clunky but I thought it was okay.For me what made this game so great was how immersive it was, not in the sense of awesome graphics, but just how deep and complex the world is, I loved reading all of the background material and the story has lots of twists and turns which for me is what helped keep me hooked and drive me forward. There are some interesting moral choices and I love that none of your choices are "the right choice" everything is morally grey and its up to you.It has its flaws but its worth it for a glimpse into the dark and mysterious world of the Witcher with plenty of unforgettable characters along the way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												I like what I've played so far, but I don't think the game has aged the best. It's not a bad game, but there are simply so many better RPGs out there, so i'm finding it harder to find a reason to finish this one. The main story path is decent so far, but it hasn't really blown me away and I've played enough to tell where it's going, which is a huge detriment to me when it comes to RPGs. The side quests are unique and plentiful though. The characters aren't very memorable; especially Geralt who literally is a blank slate (he has amnesia...). The combat system gets the job done, but it has probably aged the worst. It's an interesting idea; switching between 3 fighting styles (fast, strong, group) and timing your mouse clicks to the rythm of your blade swing to chain a combo, but it's not my favorite setup. Everything gets kind of repetitive after a while, even when you throw spells (Signs) and potions into the mix. One thing I do love is the world and the lore behind it, but I'd rather experience a much more thorough, expanded, prettier version of that in the other 2 games. I picked this game up, because I'm somewhat of a completionist, and I try to play the earlier games of every series, but I hear you don't really have to play this game to play The Witcher 2 and 3, so I think I'd rather play the much superior versions instead of investing 30+ more hours into this one. If you have that kind of time, this game is worth a shot, but don't be like me and try to make it an obligation to see it through to the end, when you really don't have to.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												After 44 hours, I must bid farewell to the first game in the Witcher series. Let’s get straight to point: I know that most people start playing and leave the game aside after playing for a few minutes. This is mainly because of the combat system which, at first, may seem complicated and hard to get used to. We've all been there, but trust me, a few hours later into the game and you'll be enjoying both the silver/steel and rock/paper/scissors mechanic, as well as the "well-timed clicking" combat system. You'll get used to it in no time! The only complaints I have regarding the game is that it crashed about 6 o 7 times (in 44 hours, which is not that bad at all) and also that the battle against the Hellhound is the hardest one in the whole game. Yes, I know, I should have improved my Aard sign (a "spell" that fus-ro-dahs enemies) but how was I supposed to know that in the first chapter? Once you get pass this battle, you'll just get better and better and no one will stand a chance against you and your Igni sign (a fire spell), basically the best one in the whole game. In fact, I never really had any reason to use any of the spells besides Igni and Aard, even when playing on the hardest difficulty. I also never used bombs or the additional weapons that Geralt can carry. I’m not even sure what they were for, to be honest. However, I really like how they implemented the alchemy system, and how you really need to make use of it to survive. The fact that potions and food aren't consumed "during menus" but in real time is also a good idea that helps you immerse yourself in the game. I love that it’s often necessary to prepare yourself BEFORE battle if you don’t want to die… but the truth is that you’ll only use the same potions again and again, even though there are a bunch of different ones. Yeah, that reminds me of my eternal search for rebis, the basic ingredient for the regeneration potion (swallow). And well, the story is okay. In my opinion it is definitely not a masterpiece as many would say. I heard so many good things about it that I was already expecting a Mass Effect type of story, but it doesn't even come close to that, yet it's also good in it's own right. Maybe it's just... the way in which it’s told, I don't know. To me, most characters felt kind of bland, and I sometimes just read quickly through the dialogues. The fact that both the translation and voice acting were not the best did not help much either. However, I like how detailed the index is and the music is also worth mentioning, as it was always very fitting and unique. Overall, I enjoyed playing The Witcher and I feel that this is a great classic RPG. You can tell how much effort and dedication the developers have put in making this game. And apart from all this, the Enhanced Edition includes a ton of features like the soundtrack, a comic, wallpapers, making-of videos and keys for a non-DRM copy of the game. I say go for it and give it a try. Just put up with the first hours and you’ll be in for quite a ride. Don’t forget that some decisions, equipment and weapons carry over to the Witcher 2, so you’ll definitely should play this before starting the second if you don’t want to miss anything. Have fun!

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												This is the most Slavic game (or Polish in particular) that I've ever played and this is the best thing about it. Additionally, the main character is really interesting as he has to face common fear and disgust of both human and elves. You as a player have to make moral choices and try to reminise who you are (create identity of "your" witcher). Graphics isn't that good anymore and there are some glitches (jumping breast, hair and beards :D) and ocasional crashes. However, all in all it is worth it to start the journey from the beginning. Score: 7/10Pros:- Slavic identity and interesting lore- Very likeable main character- Extremely good voice acting in Polish- Not only for fans of Witcher novels- Decent storyCons:- boring fighting model- lots of backtracking and quests like "ask the person at the other end of the map and come back with the message from him"- technical problems- multiple "end fights" - ending is kind of inconsistent- I wasn't skipping side-quests in general and still my character was too weak to pass through Act V. I had to use the save editor to be able to finish the game as I didn't want to replay Act IV. It just didn't feel right. There were no warnings in previous acts that I am skipping too many growth opportunities.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												I played through the entirety of Witcher 1 and I enjoyed it overall. Honestly the mechanics of the game are bad. The three stances you have for combat feel like rock paper scissors - enemies are basically defined as fast, strong, and mob-type(multiple yet weak). I would not recommend playing on a hard difficulty as it only makes things tedious rather than interesting. The simplicity of it on easy will let you breeze through the game letting you take in the story which is really where you will enjoy the game.Combat aside, side stories and hidden interactions with the npcs keep the game interesting and it feels like anything could happen. The choices you make have an impact on what happens later in the game. Some do not give an immediate outcome and may come back to you at a later point in the game.The graphics, while dated, do not take much away from the environments built within the game. The first area you start in really turned me off and I had very little desire to play it at that point. The areas after however are well made visually. It's not a true open world but the areas feels large with many areas to explore.If you want to get right into the witcher 2 or 3 games, it may be better to watch a playthrough or read a summary, but I was satisfied and did not regret playing through.Lastly, I can't say how it compares to the books as I have not read them.

Posted: June 30, 2015
												Witcher 1 is an interesting, captivating and even at times, funny game, that is if you can get past many of the little quirks that are guaranteed to annoy you, just a little bit. The main things that annoyed me is, obviously the combat. It is boring, tedious and doesn't seem very inspired, just click, wait for the mouse cursor to change and click some more, this makes the monster contracts somewhat of a chore instead of "Oh boy! A new creature to slay!" At least for me. Probably not a complaint you'll hear often, but I found the dialogue to be at times very strange, and the characters animations while talking can sometimes be very distracting. Now for some positive things about it; The story is very well done, same with the characters. It's got a dynamic weather system if you're into that type of thing, although for me, it seemed to always rain! Made it a drag sometimes, ha. I really enjoyed the poker dice game, probably a couple hours from that alone. I'd say if you're into RPG's The Witcher is something you should at least give a chance, I know I'm glad I did.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												The Witcher is a great rpg based on a series of novels by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. Although some of the gameplay feels a bit clunky and dated, all the rpg elements around it are top notch. The Witcher has a fantastic storyline, great world building, interesting characters, deep lore, and some difficult moral choices.The graphics are great for a 2007 game. It's not the best looking game today but is quite serviceable. The music fits the mood of the game perfectly, feeling very folksy and at home in the Witcher's medieval Europe style world.Gameplay involves questing in each of the 5 chapters. There are many varied quests throughout the game. You'll be slaying monsters, chatting up politicians, romancing ladies, gathering herbs, playing poker, bare knuckle boxing, and more!The game is long, easily over 40 hours long on a first playthrough. If you do absolutely everything it might take you much closer to 80 hours. There's definitely not a lack of content in this game.All in all, I highly recommend it for anyone looking for a meaty rpg with a strong emphasis on story and setting. Also from what I hear you can import your Witcher 1 saved game into the sequel, the Witcher 2, which is reportedly also fantastic. The Witcher 3 is due out next year and looks absolutely beautiful from the screenshots and trailers. Definitely recommend starting with the first one and playing through the entire epic trilogy.

												This is a damn excellent game. The stat system is not mind-boggling, the action is tight and awesome looking, and the graphics are good. What really makes this stand out is the story. You will make many choices in this game, and very rarely will there be any 'right' or 'wrong' choice - they're all in shades of gray, just like in real life. The consequences of your actions aren't always immediate and may have a big impact, so it makes these decisions really hard and involving. Just the story alone is worth shelling out $20 for. This game is worth $50, at least. Definitely recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												I was initially put off by this game. I bought it on sale about a year ago and told it would be worth my money. So I get it running and start playing the prologue. I found the controls clunky and hard to control, the combat system seemed needlessly convoluted and I died multiple times at the first boss, because I was so confused. I didn't have the patience for the game at the time. But here I am writing a positive review. I let it sit in my library for months and started to feel guilty that I spent money on a game I didn't want to play. So I decided to pick it up again and was determined to play it further and finish it whether I liked it or not, I felt that I owed the game a fair play, a game that so many obviously love and I couldn't help but feel that maybe I was missing out on something. I was right.I restarted the game and took the time to play and learn, I still find the combat a bit clunky, but I've learned to manage and succeed playing the game. I've found that The Witcher has a rich story to tell. The music is beautiful and character interactions provide a lot of depth to the world. For each new character you meet, each new beast you fight, and every note or book you find, new story elements are uncovered and added to your journal. It's clear the developers put a lot of time and heart into this game.One of the most intriguing elements of the game that nobody fails to mention is the Alchemy system. You gather various herbs, chemicals, and liquors which are used in alchemical recipes to create useful potions. You should pay attention to what you can use for a recipe because multiple subtitute reagents can be used as many materials contain the same derivative substance. The Witcher is far from perfect, but it has just enough depth to keep me hooked, it's an adventure I'm excited to continue and see to the end.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												First impressions, I love games that have that learn-on-the-job-or-die intro to controls and combat. It really gets that initial thrill of the first few levels of gaming. After reading lots of negative reviews on the combat system and controls, I dunno what they're complaining about: the integrated combat styles, moves and weapons for different enemies gives it more quick thinking when enemies come out of nowhere. The timing of attack combos and chaining is also pretty nifty despite taking abit to work out initially. One downer is that I would have liked that silver sword a little earlier on in the piece, but that's pretty much it. I'm not that far into the game, granted, but another downer is the time it takes to walk/jog everywhere. AND I usually have to wait/meditate until nightfall to actually find something to fight along the way, otherwise it gets painfully boring. BUT! Even set at 'easy' difficulty, it still has that element of supreme power and mettle while in combat if one does it well. Cinematics and dialogue are decent but definitely has room for improvement on the creative side. That said, I've definitely seen worse games in that respect, so it's 'okay'. For what it's worth, price-wise it's okay but it's an old game so if you're after the true Witcher experience, save up and go for Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt or the trilogy for a little extra. Peace.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												If you played Witcher 2/3 and wondering if this game is worth checking out, I say yes if you were big into the stories of those games. I played 2 and 3 first and was very surprised first of all by how ambitious the story of this older game is, but also by how much continuity there is between all three games. If you played 2/3, you probably followed along the story just fine, but you missed more than you think if you haven't played this game. And again, the story of this game is just as ambitious as its successors, even if the game itself is pretty rough around the edges.As far as the gameplay, the combat bears little resemblance to its sequels, while the quest format felt surprisingly similar to Witcher 3. I think Witcher 3 is the game they wished they could have made in 2007, if CDPR had the tech and resources back then. But I must be clear about one thing: "clunky" isn't even a good descriptor for this game's combat system. The combat in this game straight up sucks. It's as idiotic as it is frustrating. However in my view it is worth putting up with if you were a fan of Witcher 2/3's stories or just a fan of story-driven games in general.

Though being dated it's a F***ING blast! Yes the fighting is a bit clunky and a little awkward to handle but the "Group" attack helps! Make sure to pay attention though with Witcher 3 you could get away with tid bits to get the jist but this one makes you listen, you have to remember past conversations! It's a great game I'm lovin' it and can't wait to play Witcher 2 then 3 again and carry my story through to the end!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												I've played several RPGs so far, including some of the best the genre has to offer, like Star Wars: Knights of The Old Republic I and I would say The Witcher is now on my favorite!It has a realistic medieval world, an enthralling story and several unforgetable characters in its cast. Geralt of Rivia is a character I don't think I'll ever forget. His, well your, decisions make an impact on the game and sometimes will have you thinking what's the right thing to do.The combat mechanics aren't really anything much, just a twist to the usual clicky formula, but what DOES make it more interesting is the various potions you can conjure to drink and augment your abilities as well as blade oils and bombs. The potion system is very interesting and necesarry to use in order to succeed in combat. There's also a toxicity meter limiting the use of potions so that you can't abuse them.Overall, it's a great RPG that everyone fan of the genre or of good stories should experience!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Fantastic game. Took about 50 hours to beat the game 100%, so not too long for a RPG. Regardless, excellent story, great graphics for when it came out and for the most part, great voice acting. (Excluding Dandelion...) Fascinating world, and lot's of fun to be had. Plus there are boobies. And monsters that let their wang hang all the way. (You know, if you're into that sort of thing.)Really dark and mature, and slightly depressing. Game does not shy away from adult content/humor. Plus there is so much sex. No really. This game is like Game of Thrones but for video games. Geralt is such a player that it's not funny. At one point you can choose to have an affair that takes up an entire chapter of the game. It's great fun.Fun decision making with real consequences and some cool optional quests. Also very memorable characters... easy to know what you need to do, and the game isn't overly difficult. (That is if you don't mind spending hours and hours grinding your levels)Plus, it has a great cliff hanger leading straight into the sequel...Highly recommended. Especially since Steam sells the definitive Director's Cut for so cheap.Don't think, just buy it. It's the best RPG you'll play on PC until you play the superior sequel.My rating: A+Happy hunting.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												The Witcher is an absolutely immersive experience for RPG gamers, who are drawn to a more serious storyline about finding your path in a wicked world full of monsters, social unrest and political intrigue in a middle ages setting, similar to todays popular TV series, The Game of Thrones. Most of the monsters are built upon medieval folklore.The witcher, as a profession is in common terms a professional monster slayer armed with a steel and silver sword, mutagenic potions and superhuman abilities.Choices have irreversible consequences, which come apparent only chapters later in the game. Everything apart from the combat system - which wasn't implemented the best way - stands out in the genre. It took me about 30 hours to complete all the available sidequests, which can have an impact on the main story.The game starts slow, but eventually picks up pace once in the main city. There was a lot of detail put into the NPC's as well, the folk in the city and the outskirts have a totally different mindset.I would give this game an 8/10 and recommend it to any RPG fan.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
Review from the POV of a long-time avid Witcher book series fan. Be advised. 8/10Pros:- Compelling story. It starts a bit cliche with an Amnesiac Hero but from there quickly becomes quite interesting.- Excellent representation of Witcher book series' atmosphere. Game is full of mature content thanks to the source material.- Interesting NPCs with their own life routines and day/night cycles.- Quests full of tough moral choices and immanent consequences of said choices.- Lore friendly hoarding-free equipment handling and alchemy system.- Great OST that going to reside in your playlist long after you finish the game.Cons:- Combat system is a simple point & rhythmically click routine due in no small part to AI's straightforward approach to engage you. If you'll develop your Geralt right, enemies aren't going to give you any trouble even on highest difficulty level.- Dialogues include quite a few direct quotations from books. For those who familiar with source material it might become quite boring sometimes.Summary:For those PRG fans who don't think that character editor, complex combat system and loot hoarding are absolutely necessary attributes of genre - this game is a must-have. And for Sapkowski readers: it is as well done true to the source transfer of book universe to the interactive media as any fan of other books could only wish for.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												The Witcher. We all know why you're here. To play this game before witcher 2 then 3. You may be hesitating whether to buy this game because the graphics look old, and the dialogues are horrible. And you're right, they are, but once you get past those, the game is pretty fun. There are some sex scenes (which I don't mind), but they're opitional and are just pictures of nude women. The story is average, if not above average. A group of super mercenaries, witchers, gets their mutant secrets stolen by a group of bandits, so Geralt must find them and grab it back. One complaint is that the quests makes you walk back and forth around the map. Receive a quest on the left side of the map, complete it the right side, then talk to someone at the top, go back to the left, then receive reward at the right. The majority of the quests just make you run around until you get sick of the maps.But the major flaw in this game is the glitchy combat system. There will be times when you need to tap to attack, but Geralt acts like an idiot and just stands still. There have been times when I would want to punch my monitor out of how frustrating it was.Overall: 7/10Although the combat and dialogue sucks, the story is indeed worth playing. There is a good sense of lore where you play a medeival fantasy setting. I would recommend this game if you plan on buying the sequels just so you can get a better understanding with the characters.Some tips if you play this game: spend time to make potions. The only other way to heal is sleeping or waiting for your health to regenerate by eating food. Also, if you deciede to play the extra adventure games, "Price of Neutrality" is the only one worth playing imo.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Short version: Great game with good story. Some unique elements that are mildly annoying, but add to realism/immersion. Morally grey decisions that cause game-lasting changes to various elements. 8.5/10Great action RPG with some unique elements that separate it from the rest of it's genre. On the hard difficulty with the Extreme Immersion mod installed (which removes much of the HUD and other elements that make things feel more game-y), it presented a good challenge that never got too frustrating.The combat system is a bit weird, but not bad once you get used to it. Instead of 1 click per attack, you click once and Geralt launched into a combo. Then you click again at the end of the combo to begin the next flurry. Proper timing leads to much better (and cooler looking) attacks. Items/potions that restore chunks of health instantly are rare (I know of one). Instead, everything just makes your natural health regen faster. A bit annoying at times, but it does add a bit more realism to the game.You can't gather alchemy ingredients if you don't know they exist. Again, a bit annoying, but adds realism. If you didn't know that a dog's liver was good for making potions, why would you ever take it out, right?Finally, this is one of those RPGs that forces you to make various moral decisions (many of which will affect the later chapters in the game significantly, so choose wisely). However, unlike many games which hvae clear "good" and "bad" choices, Witcher almost always makes you choose between two equally bad options. For example (spoilers incoming), at one point you decide whether to support a village whose leaders are murderers, rapists, and child traffickers or to support the witch they are trying to lynch, who aided many of those same leaders herself. Both are clearly in the wrong, but you must decide which to kill and which to save. That decision will affect various things for the remainder of the game (my advice: save the witch).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												A trully epic adventure!Argh where to begin!? The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is definatly one of my new favourite games.  The game starts off pretty slow, paired with a not so great combat system it did take me a few attempts to get started with the game. After a few hours (and a few restarts) i got my head around the interesting combat system and by the end of chapter 1 I had fallen in love with it! It adds a layer of depth to the combat, instead of just running around and swinging your sword at anything that moves; but instead you have to learn which enemies are vulnerable to which witcher combat style and then use that to your advantage and this does not only it makes meeting new enemies and fighting bosses that little more interesting, but also keeps you one your feet if you are fighting a large group of enimies.The first chapter can get a little tedious.. well boring really and i ended up taking a break from the witcher becuase of that. But i came back a few months later craving for Witcher and soldiered on through the first chapter. The second and third chapter were really enjoyable but there was alot of running around and go here, talk to this person, go find this person and sadly everynow and then the NPC would not be where he is supposed to be ( I found this can be fixed by just going to a fireplace and meditating for 48hrs). For me however the game felt average at this point and it wasn't really getting truly immersed into the game. By the end of chapter III i was almost at the point of just giving up on the game and moving onto witcher 2, but how glad i am that i stuck with it for just a little longer! Chapter IV was honestly my best experience in any RPG i have ever played. I was finally fully immersed into the game and just could not stop playing. The game picks up quite alot during chapter IV, and as soon as you know it you will be on your way to chapter 5 and finally the Epilogue. The ending was very diffrent than what i thought it would be it was amazing. I will not reveal any details because you must play this game and experience it for yourself! My favoruite part of the game was that your choices that you make throughout the entire game trully matter and can make a huge diffrence to the game and how it is played. I will one day go back an playthrough the game again and choose completely diffrent choices to see how those effect the game and see if the choices i made were even the right ones. I definatly recommend this game to anyone who is keen on a story rich game. I am keen to play The Wither 2 with the save file from Witcher: Enhanced Edition.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												The Witcher is a rich RPG with a deep storyline and an old school styled combat mechanic in the style of KOTOR. I heared great things about this game for years I regret not playing it sooner. Geralt is a mysterious figure who's past is un certain, he's a member of a group of mutants called Witchers. Witchers are former humans who take mutagens to enhance their senses and fighting abilities. A Witcher is essentially a monster hunter who takes contracts to gain money. In the age that the game is set there are only a handful of Witchers left in the world and they are threatend by a force tha wants to destroy their way of life. This game forces you to make tough decisions and pulls ou into a murky world of politics every decision you make could have consequnces for Geralt down the road.

The former is too easy and the latter is too difficult in higher levels, and very annoying. A few CTD's left me banging on my desk shouting out loud.But overall this is a brilliant game. Definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												The Witcher is a great RPG with some pretty big flaws. It makes a great use of the source material (the Witcher books by the Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski) and features a deep story with lots of side quests and many important choices. The main character Geralt and the setting itself are certainly some of the biggest strengths of the game.Unfortunately the game has some pretty big issues too. The game was a hugely ambitious project for a small studio like CD Project Red and it often shows. The heavily modified Aurora Engine (originally developed for Neverwinter Nights by Bioware) was a poor fit for a title with more action-oriented combat and the controls are often extremely clunky as a result.The game is also extremely easy after you get past the prologue and the first chapter. Even on hard most fights are pretty trivial once you get bit further in the game. This is a shame, as I quite enjoyed the early challenging combat that forces you to rely on preparation and consumables.Overall the Witcher is still a great experience just for the story and the characters, as long as you can put up with the flawed combat. It's also the logical entry point into the Witcher game series, as the Witcher 2 picks up soon after the end of this one and some of your decisions will transfer over.I completed the game on hard, picking the Witcher/Neutral path. I was using a couple of graphics and UI mods, but nothing major.The good:- Great main character- Interesting main story and side quests- Lots of choices and consequences- The game deals with some quite mature themes- Interesting crafting system that fits the setting and the main character- Great journal systemThe bad:- Combat is passable but the controls are often very clunky- Way too easy even on Hard difficulty- Romance/Sex is handled in an extremely juvenile manner- The writing and especially the voice-acting are bit uneven- Lots of quests force you to do extensive backtracking, simply padding the length of the game- Inventory managament can be bit of a painThe ugly:- Some quest scripting issues. This is understandable in a game of this complexity, but it's still annoying- Dice poker is a terrible mini-game with cheating opponents and relies way too much on luck- Quicksave always creates a new save, this quickly clogs up the list of save games

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												There's a reason why this game has such great scores everywhere, why people speak well of it, and why I played it for hours and hours, every day.First of all, I have bad news: even though this game is great, don't spend your money if you don't have maturity to play it. I mean, I played it once when I was 14-15, but I could just realise how good this game is by playing it again when I became an adult.The game is full of decisions. Each decision affects the rest of the game. And by the ending of it, you will see that you made some bad decisions - and that allows replayability, which is great. I hardly get interested in the story, but this one is specialThe combat may not respond well sometimes, but considering that the game is a bit old, the flaws are acceptable, and they won't really annoy you.Something I really liked is that you can choose the way you fight: Sword fighting is excelent and strong, using alchemy is highly effective, and magic is awesome. You can fully max one of those, or mix them - both ways are effective too.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												The Witcher Enhanced Edition is a game that you have to spend some time getting into. My first impression was that the game had suppen frame-drops and clunky controls and did not like it at all in the beginning. However, it only took me about 2-3 hours to fall in love with this game. What I liked most about this game was the story. It was one of the reasons I got so addicted to the game. The clunky controls did not bother me, because the story was so interesting and unique. I also really liked the Level system. It had alot of variation, for example upgrading your magic skills, health, making your combat moves look smoother and even make Geralt do backflips!One of the things most people hate the most is the combat. You click on the enemy and look at Geralt do some swings and wait until the sword (mouse pointer) have flames on it and then click again for a 2nd combo. I personally had no problem with this type of combat and actually enjoyed it a lot. But I understand why people dislike it, but it really depends on your style and what you like.The biggest complains I have with this game is the clunky controls and sudden game crashes (which can be really annoying if you don't save the game often). But I've heard that the game auto-saves if you press f5, which I didn't know until after I finished the game and started on The Witcher 2.Overall, I think this a very good RPG game from an amazing franshise that I recommend for those who like dark, sexy and actionpacked RPGs, and  I therefore give this game a strong 8/10.
