content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Personally, I thought this game was amazing and haven't had a game keep me so interested for so long in quite a while. Story was very interesting and was told in a great way - through talking with the characters in the world, reading the many books you will find/purchase and also through the environment itself.I found the combat very enjoyable, using potions, oils, runes and more to improve my weapons based on the creatures I would face in the upcoming area (which can be found out by reading a monster's bestiary entry in your journal) and fighting enemies with the swords. I think that this strategy is the main focus of the combat, along with dodging at the right time and using signs (spells) to your advantage, as the swordplay is comprised of combo-ing enemies by clicking at the correct moment using one of three combat stances.I recommend this game to anyone who wants to invest a lot of time exploring, hunting monsters, completing various side-quests and chasing women.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												This is a marvelous game. The storyline, the twists and turns, the side quests, it is all extraordinarily well done.You are Geralt of Rivia, and you are nothing short of a badass. There are very few games I truly recommend, and even fewer that I am willing to put in the time to review. This game is worth every penny. The combat system is unique, dynamic, and immensely entertaining. The alchemy system is complex, riveting and yet simple enough to understand for even the most casual gamers.The relationships you can build throughout the game are intense, and every bit determined on the paths you choose. The sex scenes are a nice touch, gives it that adult flare without being overtly pornagraphic. The storylines are in-depth, articulate, well organized and progresses the story in a very fluid manner, thoroughly explaining the backstory along the way.The sidequests are entertaining as hell, and get you that much needed relief from the overhwelming sensation of the large monumental tasks that you will have to accomplish to complete the game. The in-game "games" like the dice poker is probably one of my favorite aspects of the game, along with the "fight clubs." You can make quite a few Orens just by freely engaging in combat, or gambling. As it stands, I don't see why everyone shouldn't buy this game. Its not terribly expensive, and you will be engaged for hours.You are Geralt of Rivia, and you ARE a BADASS!That is all.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												The single best thing about playing through The Witcher, for me, was its rich mood and atmosphere. Adam Skorupa and Pawel Blaszczak's work on the score is simply gorgeous. The music and environmental sound design here are vital to creating a strong a sense of place and bringing the world of Temeria to life.Okay, gameplay-wise, combat is a bit ropey honestly. And the character dialogue is laugh-out-loud funny at times. Unintentionally so for the most part. But the comical language just add to the games charm in my opinion. Overall, for all it's flaws, this game will reward you with a memorable adventure. I really loved my time with it. You should too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												8/10The Witcher is a very interesting RPG set in a fantasy world where everything is crap by default. Humans are vehemently racist, elves and dwarves are oppressed to the point of revolt, and you're a superhuman created from childhood to slay monsters for coin. You're also the only sane man in a world filled with insanely homicidal people. Oh and you're also the hottest guy ever for the ladies. Wenches love a good monster slayer.The story is interesting and fairly long, meaning you will dedicate a good 30+ hours to it, also counting many sidequests which help build up the world around you. The game has a pretty good soundtrack which fits the mood at all occasions, and the alchemy system is also nifty yet does not intrude in your enjoyment if you're not the kind of person who wants to focus on making potions (but you should anyway because stats bonuses). The combat is probably the weakest part of the game, being summarized by picking between your "versus human" or "versus monster" swords and clicking your mouse in a rhythm, occasionally using a magic spell if you feel like it. Still the fights are generally fast-paced and don't last enough for it to become tiresome.Definitely recommended for fans of high fantasy and story-driven games, but if you expect combat depth, there is not much to see in The Witcher.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Overall a great game.GRAPHICS - Lack of diverse character models.  Many quest givers all have the exact same face, making distinction difficult.GAMEPLAY - Fun mechanics.  Rather than clicking rapidly, you are forced to play with more finesse, clicking only at the right times to continue/complete combos.It is best to understand the gameplay mechanics before deciding you hate it - a few simple, crucial tips will make all the difference between loving and hating this game (and seeing it through to the end):1. MONEY - Pick up EVERYTHING.  Sell any secondary weapons you find (you'll never use them, and they are worth a lot). Sell all LOW and MEDIUM strength alcohol (keep strong alcohol for alchemy).2. TALENT POINTS - Look through the GOLD point talents and decide on THREE main areas you want to focus on and dump all your talent points into those areas before diversifying.  This will dictate your combat style heavily, but make you much stronger overall. Spreading out your points with a "balanced build" will inherently make you weaker overall and good at nothing. Seriously, decide how you want to kill things and stick with it.3. ALCHEMY - Always have WHITE HONEY (removes toxicity) and WIVE'S TEARS (removes drunkeness) on hand.  Brew a stack of WHITE GULL (a base for other potions) and store all other strong alcohol until you need more WHITE GULL.  Bombs and Blade oils are specific to the Intelligence tree.  If you don't plan on going down that tree, you can sell all bases for them (powder and grease/tallow, respectively).4.  EXPLORATION/QUESTS - Explore all areas of the map at all times of day (namely noon and midnight).  Certain monsters only come out at certain times, and it's the only way to find/kill them for quests.  Do as many side quests as possible for extra xp/levels/talents.  You only get gold talents at higher levels, and they sure are strong.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												I played through this game on easy and just listened in to the story for the most part. Even on easy the game was pretty challenging in parts, but not really due to the difficulty, but due to the very clunky combat system. I felt like I was fighting Geralt's glitchy moves more than I was the monsters at times. However, the game as a whole is pretty good. It's a decently long game and there's a bunch of quests. There's a bit too much backtracking for my tastes, particularly in Chapters 2 and 4 and the quests at times can feel arbitrary (go to person A, find person B, find out person B is dead and then have to talk to A. Go find person C so they can give you xp and orens). I can really only recommend this game if you really don't wanna feel left out for some of the characters in The Witcher 2 and you want to transfer your save file over to the 2nd game a la Mass Effect style. If the game's combat really turns you off that much, I'd honestly just find a wiki summary of the story and read that, though you'd be missing out on the pretty good character interaction.TL;DR: The game is clunky and feels very dated, but the main story is really enthralling and worth the trip if you care about the lore enough.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2013
												In 2007 when I was 14, I was looking at this in a game shop, then an obese Indian woman came up to me with piercing eyes and displeased face and asked "How old are you?!" I said nothing, and slowly backed away round a corner in fear.Five years later I bought this on Steam, at its full price. Then of course a week later it was on sale.Now finally on with the game, The Witcher is a fantasy RPG based on a series of Polish novels I haven't read yet. You play as Geralt, a lady's-man-warrior-witch-bloke, and embark on an epic quest, meeting friends and foes, bandits, possessed children, fiery dogs, mad scientists, squids, gremlins, floating naked chicks and frog mages. The usual.You level up your guy, get upgrades and make potions, as you do. The combat system is good, switching between swords and speeds. It's gritty, with gore and swearing and sex. Reminds me of Game of Thrones, for Eastern European jews or something.It's a great medieval yarn. It just repeats the same characters over and over. I freaking hate that old lady that's everywhere.8/10

												Surprisingly beautiful for a game this old. content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												First impressions, I love games that have that learn-on-the-job-or-die intro to controls and combat. It really gets that initial thrill of the first few levels of gaming. After reading lots of negative reviews on the combat system and controls, I dunno what they're complaining about: the integrated combat styles, moves and weapons for different enemies gives it more quick thinking when enemies come out of nowhere. The timing of attack combos and chaining is also pretty nifty despite taking abit to work out initially. One downer is that I would have liked that silver sword a little earlier on in the piece, but that's pretty much it. I'm not that far into the game, granted, but another downer is the time it takes to walk/jog everywhere. AND I usually have to wait/meditate until nightfall to actually find something to fight along the way, otherwise it gets painfully boring. BUT! Even set at 'easy' difficulty, it still has that element of supreme power and mettle while in combat if one does it well. Cinematics and dialogue are decent but definitely has room for improvement on the creative side. That said, I've definitely seen worse games in that respect, so it's 'okay'. For what it's worth, price-wise it's okay but it's an old game so if you're after the true Witcher experience, save up and go for Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt or the trilogy for a little extra. Peace.

It's not the worst you'll ever see and it has ton of depth and tactic to it, it's just in the game so beautiful(even now it looks really good on max settings), so amazingly written, produced and designed, game with such deep alchemy system that you find yourself lost in planning and minmaxing, you would expect the best of combat and it's just not there. content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												Initially, this was a slow burner for me. At times, the sheer complexity of the available choices you have can be daunting. I played this casually on and off through the first chapter. After getting used to the battle system, and the usefulness of alchemy, I actually really started to get drawn in by the story and the choices that you can make. The size and scope of this game is impressive. Towards the end, I found myself really becoming a fan, and I was looking forward to the ending. Minor gripes are that it can become very tedious completing secondary quests, mainly because travel can take a while across multiple maps. Also, little things like waiting for the transition between battle and explore mode in order to pick up items, etc. can really eat into time when you just want to see what happens next, or fight another monster.Overall though, I was extremely glad to have finished the game, and I'm excited about playing 2 and 3.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												★ ★ ★ ★ ☆ The Witcher is a gigantic, engrossing RPG that will suck you into the world for hours on end, but it may be slightly overambitious. The universe of The Witcher originates from the mind of Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. This particular entry takes place some time after the final book in the series,  The Lady of the Lake.  Fortunately, you won't need to have prior knowledge of these books to enjoy the story CD PROJEKT RED has presented. The story is centered around Geralt of Rivia -- a witcher -- also known as "The White Wolf", who is suffering from amnesia when we first encounter him. This sets Geralt up as a blank slate in which it is up to the player to build up his identity from there. Our tale begins in a keep known as Kaer Morhen where witchers -- mutant monster slayers for hire -- were once trained. Geralt, still slowly recovering from recent injuries, finds himself and his companions under attack by a strange organization known as Salamandra. This criminal group slashes their way through the old keep and steals vital secrets of the witchers. And thus, the amnesiac Geralt and his band of withcers set out across the lands in search of the abducted witcher's mysteries. Your quest has the semblance of simplicity, but as your journey progresses you will come to realize that there is more to your mission than what meets the eye. With what started as a recovery mission soon evolves into fight for what's "right," thrusting Geralt in the middle of politics, a war on equality, and even love affairs. Your decisions matter in The Witcher, with consequences resulting from each choice. While you may not see the result of your actions immediately, each choice you make will come back to haunt you later on. The game offers many paths providing players with a huge amount of replayability to discover what would happen if you chose one person over the other, the elves or the Order, or just staying neutral as all hell. The characters you encounter throughout your journey are each exceptionally written with real depth and their own, realistic motivations. While the voice acting for the characters is far from superb, they get the job done and convey their ideals effectively.  The aesthetic of The Witcher is beautiful and fully realized. The soundtrack is epic and fits each situation perfectly. Whether you are engaging in a battle to the death, wandering the city streets, plundering a cave, or drunkenly meandering throughout the halls of an inn, the soundtrack compliments each situation. Speaking of which, the environments are all immersive, incredibly entertaining and quite detailed. You will lose yourself in this world for hours. Entire days will disappear playing dice poker with local gamblers, reading books, slaying monsters, or just wandering the town. While the story and the world jam-packed with lore are all extremely captivating, the combat is something to be desired. There are three different fighting styles which players must choose depending on the types of enemies one is facing at that time. The strong style deals heavy damage in exhange for slow speed; the quick style allows for fast hits with less-damaging attacks; and the group style which is useful when Geralt is surrounded by enemies. The player can switch between these styles on the fly with the various hotkeys or by taking time to press the combat pause button (the space bar by default) and assessing the battle you are faced with before heading face first into the fray. Witchers are equiped with two main swords -- a steel and silver -- and both have very different styles of combat compared to the rest of his weapons. Both blades serve a distinct purpose: where the steel blade is used to dispatch human enemies and the silver is more effective when battling monsters and beasts.Throughout your journey, you will encounter "Signs", which are essentially spells which can be cast upon your foes, or a shield to cast upon yourself. Each provide new, interesting ways to dispatch of your foes. The problem with the combat stems from it feeling clunky and dated. Controlling Geralt while in combat mode becomes finicky, making certain movements while attempting to maneuver around the enemies just plain awkward. Granted, most enemies are fairly easy to dispatch with a few combos. This problem typically rears its ugly head when fighting tougher, bigger monsters and bosses (lookin' at you,  Jacques de Aldersberg  ). With that said, another essential part of the gameplay involves alchemy. Creating potions is fundamental to your journey, whether you create health regeneration, endurance, or combat potions, each will provide Geralt with assistance. However, using too many potions at one time will build up your toxicity meter. Once this meter completely fills up, Geralt will die. To reduce toxicity, one must craft a special potion or rest at an inn or fireplace. Geralt can gather alchemical ingredients from plants you find in the fields, purchasing from merchants, and harvesting items from monsters. However, you must have knowledge of these monsters and plants before given the ability to harvest said ingredients. One can obtain this knowledge from various books or stories told by random NPCs. While I understand the conceit of Geralt researching the intricacies and ins and outs (literally) of the creatures, it is very irksome when a quest wishes for specific ingredients and you have to scour your current area for a merchant who sells the bestiary entry for your target monster. I do not exactly count this as a knock against the game, because I personally loved researching about the monster's lore, but I must say, it just feels like busy work after awhile.Along with the creation of alchemical potions, you can unlock a tier when leveling which allows for the creation of bombs and oils. The oils augment the damage done by your weapons and bombs can be thrown on the ground during combat, both providing you with an advantage over your foes. During my playthrough, a few technical issues arose. There were a few, inconsistent and unexpected crashes throughout the game: some during combat, and others while moseying through the city streets. Near the end of the game, I experienced a fairly serious crash which completely locked up my computer; I could not even access the Task Manager. Unfortunately, I ended up having to completely restart my computer. Luckily, these issues are few and far between. Be sure to save often just in case. To wrap it all up, The Witcher is a fantastic RPG plagued with minor technical issues and an odd, finicky combat system, but once you get over those humps, underneath is a rich, lively world with an experience one certainly will not forget for quite some time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Overall rating: 4/5Summary: Utterly visionary game, denied a fifth star because its glitches show its age.  We aren't talking about bad voice-overs or unresolved plot lines, we're talking about frequent hard crashes and the occasional game-ruining bug.Pros:-Storyline(s) utterly captivating.  This bullet was almost very long, so I'll put it this simply: You will make choices that will torment you in a good way.  I'm usually really into (approximately) optimizing characters and producing well-thought out builds, but I passed up a few upgrades because I didn't support the choices I needed to make to get them.  Furthermore, many of the choices I made were difficult, with no clearly wrong answers.-This game is aggressively beautiful.  Sometimes you'll be at the height of a major confrontation, and if there's a lull in the battle you'll find yourself playing with the camera just to check out the scenery, the behavior of NPCs, or Geralt's gear - which largely reflects what you equip.-Character levelling paces nicely with the game.  If you're vigilant about quests, then your character will start becoming overpowered towards the final stages - but this feels natural and believable, since you have to be thorough to build a really epic character.  -NPC allies, though weak, feel very believable.  They make mistakes a rookie might, and it makes sense that they should be fragile compared to a witcher mercenary like you!-The resource management system, if you figure it out, is addicting.  You are allowed to carry JUST ENOUGH that you can be super well prepared for a lot of situations, without being able to "hoard" items without being forced to dump things of value.   You're forced to think hard about what you carry around with you.-The game rewards a studious character - most knowledge that is needed to win fights without a lot of agony is available at financial cost, and those costs are greatly diminished if you're pretty diligent about chatting up NPCs.  Things you learn are neatly inventoried, so gaining knowledge never feels like a waste and you don't need to read things that don't pertain to your immediate needs.-The battle system rewards good thinking.  Choosing the right sword style is a piece of cake once you get the hang of it; deciding what spells should compliment what build requires some thought, and there are mechanisms in place to limit any advantage you can imagine.  Cons:-This game crashes........A LOT.  I would give it a top rating if not for the raw quantity of crashes I had to put up with.  The complaints I've heard from others (of which there are a lot) suggest that it's mainly an optimization issue, and mostly affects Mac user. Honestly, it's inexcusable that the makers OFFER this game for whichever platforms are affected to this degree, and are churning out sequels but haven't bothered to patch the original chapter in the series.  I can't understate how annoying the crashes are.  I played the whole game with all optional quality settings at their lowest possible levels.  I still experienced at least one crash every, say, 90 minutes - and sometimes could get a crash in as little as 15-20 minutes.  This game is so good I recommend tolerating and intolerable level of stability issues.  SAVE REALLY OFTEN and lower your settings as much as you need to to minimize crashes - even the lowest settings are mostly quite good.  If you have the hardware to enjoy the upper settings, I imagine they're even better.-Your CPU will run fiery-hot while you play this game.  If you're playing on a Macbook, as I was, you may need to shut down everything else and put a fan on.  If it gets too hot, that's one thing that can cause the game to shut down.-There is moderate sexism in some of the dialogue.  With a male protagonist with mostly male friends in a Middle Ages setting, this isn't the worst or most unbelievable element - but it's a bit hammy.  One major character offers you the advice of several other major characters, mentioning that the one who is female will advice on "x, y and 'female intuition.'  Little stuff like that makes some of the voice acting feel forced, and makes the NPCs seem stupid at times.-Minor con:  There is a room that, if you re-enter it looking for treasure, you may become unable to leave.  An unlocked door behind you simply will not open, and your buddies will eternally wonder WTF happened to you.  If you somehow saved your game after that point and don't have earlier backups, too bad.  This point is near the end of the game, so you can lose a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of valuable progress that way.  Also, some dialogue trees don't acknowledge differences in choices you can make.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												An excellent story, unmatched characterisation and a world brimming with life and character sets this apart from the crowd. Aside from the gripping plot, it's the little things that make the difference. Townsfolk huddling under canopies to shelter from the rain, birds flocking from a bush and you approach to harvest herbs. Features that The Witcher's big-budget peers (The Elder Scrolls, Dragon Age) lack. Round it off with a simple but elegant combat system and more than a few original ideas to shake up the classic RPG progression path and you've got one of the best action RPGs ever made. I implore you to finish this one and it's fantastic sequel before The Witcher 3 storms onto the scene and rocks our world.

												The Good: "The Witcher" has a detailed story, characters and environments, leaving you to explore your way through the game; The soundtrack is spot on and immersive, the artwork is beautiful and the game world feels alive and vibrant. The potion crafting and the minigames are a nice touch too.The Bad: Dull combat and awkward UI/movement interactions. the English voice acting lacks of any kind of enthusiasm.Recommended for fans of "The Witcher" book series, or if you are looking for a mature, slow burn RPG and you're willing to overlook the clumsy fighting system.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2011
												A dark, gothic, action RPG that is neck-deep in story. The action is flashy, however combat controls are obtuse; and when those clunky controls are paired with nearly brain-dead AI the action is underwhelming. The CRPG elements (item hoarding, inventory management, skill upgrades, etc) are very classic in nature - which is a hate-it or love-it affair. Likewise the presentation is something players will either hate or love - being a Central European RPG the story begins in medias res, there is a ton of dialogue, and the supporting characters are mostly ordinary folk with fairly rich back stories (as opposed to typical JRPGs which start "at the beginning" of a story, include minimal dialogue, and include flashy but hollow characters). The only issues holding this game back are the bugs and how poorly it performs (given its fairly dated graphics).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												The Witcher is an absolutely immersive experience for RPG gamers, who are drawn to a more serious storyline about finding your path in a wicked world full of monsters, social unrest and political intrigue in a middle ages setting, similar to todays popular TV series, The Game of Thrones. Most of the monsters are built upon medieval folklore.The witcher, as a profession is in common terms a professional monster slayer armed with a steel and silver sword, mutagenic potions and superhuman abilities.Choices have irreversible consequences, which come apparent only chapters later in the game. Everything apart from the combat system - which wasn't implemented the best way - stands out in the genre. It took me about 30 hours to complete all the available sidequests, which can have an impact on the main story.The game starts slow, but eventually picks up pace once in the main city. There was a lot of detail put into the NPC's as well, the folk in the city and the outskirts have a totally different mindset.I would give this game an 8/10 and recommend it to any RPG fan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												The Witcher is an amazing RPG that features some of the best storytelling and decision making I have ever seen. Everything decision, whether through actions or dialogue, carry weight and actively change the world around you. The game takes around 35-45 hours to complete, depending on how many side quests you do. There is a large amount of content in the game and warrants several playthroughs to see how different decisions change the course of the game. There are only two minor complaints that I have in this wonderful game. The first is the combat, while engaging, tended to be either a bit buggy or laggy, one of the two. The second complaint is a very minor complaint and partially is my fault for I have a short attention span. Some of the areas require a long walk to get from eachother, and you have to go back and forth quite a few times. I started to get bored of the long walks. Overall, the game is a very indepth RPG that defiently warrants several playthroughs. I highly recommend The Witcher to anyone who is a fan of RPGs.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												I wanted to play all the witcher games in order so started here, I had initially tried to get in to the game a while ago and just didn't enjoy it, I decided to give it another shot. It has a pretty slow beginning and there is a lot to learn in terms of all the mechanics of the game. Combat can be clunky but I thought it was okay.For me what made this game so great was how immersive it was, not in the sense of awesome graphics, but just how deep and complex the world is, I loved reading all of the background material and the story has lots of twists and turns which for me is what helped keep me hooked and drive me forward. There are some interesting moral choices and I love that none of your choices are "the right choice" everything is morally grey and its up to you.It has its flaws but its worth it for a glimpse into the dark and mysterious world of the Witcher with plenty of unforgettable characters along the way.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												I never read the books, but if the books are as beautiful as this game is, i shall say, that this is a masterful experience in gaming.This is one of those games that you'll never forget. It has a magnificent story, every decision counts, and of course it has very good looking graphics for being such an old game. Geralt of Rivia is something between a warrior and a wizard, and of course one of the most interesting characters i've ever seen in a Fantasy Novel/Game. Every epic fantasy/RPG/good story lover must play this, and heed my words this is indeed a very good story. Another thing that pops out when you play is the atmosphere at the taverns and inns, the sounds, the music, the people everything is in the right spot. You'll have a good old school feeling when fighting a boss, few games nowadays have this effect on me. Badass character, Amazing story, Great RPG, Inmersive atmosphere, hacking and slashing action here and there...what else do you want! The only thing i missed... Was a dragon.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2013
												In 2007 when I was 14, I was looking at this in a game shop, then an obese Indian woman came up to me with piercing eyes and displeased face and asked "How old are you?!" I said nothing, and slowly backed away round a corner in fear.Five years later I bought this on Steam, at its full price. Then of course a week later it was on sale.Now finally on with the game, The Witcher is a fantasy RPG based on a series of Polish novels I haven't read yet. You play as Geralt, a lady's-man-warrior-witch-bloke, and embark on an epic quest, meeting friends and foes, bandits, possessed children, fiery dogs, mad scientists, squids, gremlins, floating naked chicks and frog mages. The usual.You level up your guy, get upgrades and make potions, as you do. The combat system is good, switching between swords and speeds. It's gritty, with gore and swearing and sex. Reminds me of Game of Thrones, for Eastern European jews or something.It's a great medieval yarn. It just repeats the same characters over and over. I freaking hate that old lady that's everywhere.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												An excellent story, unmatched characterisation and a world brimming with life and character sets this apart from the crowd. Aside from the gripping plot, it's the little things that make the difference. Townsfolk huddling under canopies to shelter from the rain, birds flocking from a bush and you approach to harvest herbs. Features that The Witcher's big-budget peers (The Elder Scrolls, Dragon Age) lack. Round it off with a simple but elegant combat system and more than a few original ideas to shake up the classic RPG progression path and you've got one of the best action RPGs ever made. I implore you to finish this one and it's fantastic sequel before The Witcher 3 storms onto the scene and rocks our world.

The only real issue I had was the Combat system sucks, the swordplay utilizes some kind of timed attack mechanic which will get boring fast and the magic usage is pretty simplistic as well. Also be ready to take about 30 hrs to complete the campaign. Overall, other than the combat it's a very solid game that provides a unique experience that feels different than most other games. Withcer 2 is also a very different experience from the 1st. 7.5/10

												The Witcher is a nice epic-medieval oriented 3rd person RPG game with a very interesting story-line.The graphics are quite awesome for a 2007 game and the effects very nice too.The characters are very well roled, each one has a meaning for his/her existance, good AI.The game also brings the player into positions to make choices that affect the rest of the game which is interesting.The fight system at start is VERY boring till you gain a few levels, there's not much variety on attack styles which migh make the player bored.The main character is very cool, nice voiced, awesomely designed and ingame you can also choose the way of your sexlife (The European version has totally uncencored "se cards") or to have a romance story.I was amazed that a Polish developer team managed to create such a brilliant game.Recommended for the lovers of the kind, specially for those who like interesting story-lines in RPG games.Can't wait to get my hands on Witcher 2.

												Truly a great game, this is far more fun than I imagined it to be!The graphics are great for its age and the play style is simple and easy to adapt to.There are so many different things to consider in combat and yet, somehow you don't become overwhelmed by it all. content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												With the impending launch of TW3, I made the decision to replay TW and TW2. I didn't finish TW my first time around as I loat interest around chapter 3. I had similar geelings the second time around but I was determined to finish it this time.Good point for the game:1. Story is interesting. If you aren't big on stories,  skip this game.2. Level system allows for some customization. I fully upgraded igni and aard for instance.3. Hard is challenging without using alchemy constantly. 4. Choices matter for the storyline.Drawbacks:1. Combat is static. 3 styles and then signs. Once you know which style and swords to use you can cut up just about any enemy.2. Collecting alchemy ingredients is tedious as is running out of inventory for them.3. Side quests are very repetitive.  Kill x of y. Must read some book first. Boring!4. You can't change geralt's hairstyle!!!!5. Not for younger gamers as there is quite a bit of sexual content. Almost unnecessarily at times. I mean, the nurses? Really?6. Storyline in this game is unnecessary to enjoy TW2. Characters met at the beginning are not revisited after the prologue. Looking forward to seeing them in TW3.7. Some failed quests always remain active in your log. Hot potato for one.8. Holy lag starting in Chapter 3. FPS averaged around 30 in the Trade Quarter and sometimes lower at night in the swamp.Though I have more drawbacks than good points, it can still be worth playing if you like the gameplay mechanics, which grew on me I'll admit. For $1.99 on steam sale, why not buy it?

												One of my favorite games of all time- I've played through it three separate times and never fail to find new reasons to love it.  The graphics still hold up, and the combat is fine as long as you know what you're getting into- a Diablo-style click on the bad guy to hit him, then hit him again if he's still alive, and if you REALLY mean business hit him a third, fourth, and (you masochist) fifth time. I've heard the pre-Enchanced Edition was somewhat rough, with longer loading times and only about 4 non-Geralt character skins, so if you played it when it first came out it could be worth reloading and seeing what you've missed.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												This game is generally compared unfavourably to its immediate successor as "dated" and "arcane", "clunky" and "frustrating".Released in September 2008 (7 years ago), you would not blame today's gamers - foisted on to the world of gaming through the generic open-world UbiSoft generic AAA collectathon trash as well as "high-fidelity, linear cinematic experiences" such as COD - to draw hasty conclusions.But draw back a little and remember that those graphics were once revolutionary, and if you can appreciate them for what they were (note: if you are not a millenial this should be easier) and look to the far more elegant design of game mechanics based on story, player autonomy and experimentation...well then, what you have here is a bona-fide RPG classic experience. Well written, clever and witty, with those all-important story impacting choices, character progression and build refinement, I think this is one of the most pleasant games I have played in the last year and easily the most rewarding (I played and got tired of both Bioshock Infinite and The Walking Dead Season 2, but kept coming back to this game).Beautifully done, and with a more gritty mature take on the genre, the game fits in perfectly in the world of Andrzej Sapkowski. A little word of advice - if you plan to read the series then do so first before playing the games or else MAJOR story spoilers will ensue.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												It's pretty rough around the edges (which is understandable given its age and place in CD Projekt Red's catalogue) but quite enjoyable. It is unlike any other RPG I've played in a while. I love the special agent/PI character that is Geralt, it's quite unique for the genre. As is the combat style. Fights (including boss fights) can be surprisingly easy or incredibly difficult based on how much you've paid attention and done your homework. For players of other series, the game has level design and exploration along the lines of Dragon Age, with a combat style that (oddly) reminds me of the Jedi Knight games.The game has many faults, though. Character assets are reused over and over with only a couple dozen unique characters in the game (surprisingly, though, this didn't irritate me as much as it might sound). Voice acting cutscenes are of a mediocre quality; not terrible but they've been surpassed elsewhere (like the subsequent entries in the series). Combat can be incredibly frustrating sometimes. For example, being stunned repeatedly by four wraiths to the point you cannot move or attack is maddening. It also felt that there were too many elements to the game, some of which can be (and ultimately have to be) ignored in favour of others. For example, I didn't get anywhere near maxing out my character (despite doing every quest) and never touched bombs. I also didn't feel all the signs were as useful as they could be; some easily overshadow others. Combat is generally quite easy (with a few exceptions).I very much enjoyed the claustrophobic, urban setting of the first half of the game. When it changed setting in the second half I was, at first, relieved for a change of scenery but the following areas (while containing enjoyable quests) are overly large and it feels like all you're ever doing is walking from point to point (with, surprisingly - compared to earlier areas - few enemies to worry about). The game also has a somewhat awkward, somewhat rewarding epilogue sequence, a huge twist (if you're paying attention) and a cliffhanger ending.Overall, I'd recommend it if you really want to play the entire trilogy. But if you're not that fussed, I'd probably suggest just reading up on what happens in the first game (and about its characters) and moving on to The Witcher 2 (where things improve and change drastically).

Posted: March 29, 2016
												The Witcher, nowadays, could be considered a classic RPG experience. The only problem in describing it this way is that it's not like any other RPG of it's time.The Witcher series has a certain kind of awkward charm to it, likeable characters, clunky mechanics... but everything fits perfectly.If you're interested in a well told, albeit a little "weird", story, I recommend this game.If you're interested in an RPG with basic but fun combat mechanics, I recommend this game.Truly, the Witcher is for anyone with an open mind and a fondness for western RPGs (90s and early 2000s in particular). It's mechanics are fun, it's characters memorable, it's presentation a bit clunky, but everything comes together in a really good game.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												As this is the first entry of Geralt's gaming appearances, and CDProjektRed's first published product, it can at times feel a little janky. Bioware's Aurora2007 engine contributes to that jankiness a bit as well. For anyone that's played Neverwinter Nights (the original, not the f2p mmo), it kind of feels similar to that. The combat system is odd and tends to be a little bit difficult to get used to, but it serves as only a tool to let you indulge in the weird and wonderful world of The Witcher. Like all the other entries of the series, it's filled with great characters and a story that is echelons above most RPGs. All in all, this is a rough gem that exceeds its value by far. Especially when you can get it on sale sometimes for just over a quid.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												With rich lore and a compelling narrative, The Witcher delivers a well-exectuted story that has your choices play a significant role in several outcomes. As you explore the world of The Witcher, you will be slaying monsters, fighting the Salamandra scum and choosing whether to help the people (and werewolves) of Vizima. While the controls get a little getting used to. they get the job done with simple timed-clicks and spell executions. Although, selecting what weapon you use via hotkeys can be confusing and clunky in general. Clicking the weapon you want is by far the easier solution.Alchemy is a large element of the game as it can give tempoary buffs to Geralt during combat or by granting the ability to let you see in the dark. You can also brew oils to increase your weapons' effectiveness and you can also craft bombs. But, these buffs come at a cost. Toxicity. When your toxicity bar becomes at least half full, Geralt starts to become intoxicated. The more the bar is filled (the more potions you drink), the more intoxicated Geralt will become resulting in him being slower, potions having a negative affect or he may just die instantly. However, toxicity can be cured by: meditating or by drinking White Honey.Questing in this game consists of having a few main quest branches, a few side quest branches and miscellaneous monster contracts.The structure of the quests can be confusing as let's say, the main objective is to (no spoilers here, just made up) talk to Triss about the enchanted rose. You do that and this piece of text appears under this quest: "Now that Triss knows about the rose, I should come back after I go and see the Druids." That puts this particular quest on hold for now. Then you get a new objective for a different quest that says: "Find the druids and get more information about the rose." You do that and then this quest goes on hold while you go back to Triss....I think you get my point. It's downright confusing! There are activities in the game such as: fist fights & poker. The fist fights are boring once you learn the right tactics (rigging I mean) but if you want to make quick money, go right ahead. However, the poker is well done in this game. The music gets you into the gambling spirit!Overall, I have enjoyed this game a lot. While the gameplay can feel dated sometimes, plus the occasional crashes, the voice acting is great and the story is compelling. I think it's definitely worth a buy if you're a newcomer to the Witcher series! :)  7.5/10

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												After 44 hours, I must bid farewell to the first game in the Witcher series. Let’s get straight to point: I know that most people start playing and leave the game aside after playing for a few minutes. This is mainly because of the combat system which, at first, may seem complicated and hard to get used to. We've all been there, but trust me, a few hours later into the game and you'll be enjoying both the silver/steel and rock/paper/scissors mechanic, as well as the "well-timed clicking" combat system. You'll get used to it in no time! The only complaints I have regarding the game is that it crashed about 6 o 7 times (in 44 hours, which is not that bad at all) and also that the battle against the Hellhound is the hardest one in the whole game. Yes, I know, I should have improved my Aard sign (a "spell" that fus-ro-dahs enemies) but how was I supposed to know that in the first chapter? Once you get pass this battle, you'll just get better and better and no one will stand a chance against you and your Igni sign (a fire spell), basically the best one in the whole game. In fact, I never really had any reason to use any of the spells besides Igni and Aard, even when playing on the hardest difficulty. I also never used bombs or the additional weapons that Geralt can carry. I’m not even sure what they were for, to be honest. However, I really like how they implemented the alchemy system, and how you really need to make use of it to survive. The fact that potions and food aren't consumed "during menus" but in real time is also a good idea that helps you immerse yourself in the game. I love that it’s often necessary to prepare yourself BEFORE battle if you don’t want to die… but the truth is that you’ll only use the same potions again and again, even though there are a bunch of different ones. Yeah, that reminds me of my eternal search for rebis, the basic ingredient for the regeneration potion (swallow). And well, the story is okay. In my opinion it is definitely not a masterpiece as many would say. I heard so many good things about it that I was already expecting a Mass Effect type of story, but it doesn't even come close to that, yet it's also good in it's own right. Maybe it's just... the way in which it’s told, I don't know. To me, most characters felt kind of bland, and I sometimes just read quickly through the dialogues. The fact that both the translation and voice acting were not the best did not help much either. However, I like how detailed the index is and the music is also worth mentioning, as it was always very fitting and unique. Overall, I enjoyed playing The Witcher and I feel that this is a great classic RPG. You can tell how much effort and dedication the developers have put in making this game. And apart from all this, the Enhanced Edition includes a ton of features like the soundtrack, a comic, wallpapers, making-of videos and keys for a non-DRM copy of the game. I say go for it and give it a try. Just put up with the first hours and you’ll be in for quite a ride. Don’t forget that some decisions, equipment and weapons carry over to the Witcher 2, so you’ll definitely should play this before starting the second if you don’t want to miss anything. Have fun!

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												The Witcher Enhanced Edition is a game that you have to spend some time getting into. My first impression was that the game had suppen frame-drops and clunky controls and did not like it at all in the beginning. However, it only took me about 2-3 hours to fall in love with this game. What I liked most about this game was the story. It was one of the reasons I got so addicted to the game. The clunky controls did not bother me, because the story was so interesting and unique. I also really liked the Level system. It had alot of variation, for example upgrading your magic skills, health, making your combat moves look smoother and even make Geralt do backflips!One of the things most people hate the most is the combat. You click on the enemy and look at Geralt do some swings and wait until the sword (mouse pointer) have flames on it and then click again for a 2nd combo. I personally had no problem with this type of combat and actually enjoyed it a lot. But I understand why people dislike it, but it really depends on your style and what you like.The biggest complains I have with this game is the clunky controls and sudden game crashes (which can be really annoying if you don't save the game often). But I've heard that the game auto-saves if you press f5, which I didn't know until after I finished the game and started on The Witcher 2.Overall, I think this a very good RPG game from an amazing franshise that I recommend for those who like dark, sexy and actionpacked RPGs, and  I therefore give this game a strong 8/10.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												You're Geralt of Rivia,a professional monster slayer (or witcher,mind you), legendary character and grade-A amnesiac. The whole charm of this game consists in the story,since the combat is.....well it's not "Morrowind: Reloaded" but it's there.So,what is this game about?  Besides stopping the evil organisation known as Salamandra,the real story here is finding out about Geralt's past(and of course,meddling in politics and conflicts,cuz Geralt is a bored witcher and if you read the books or listen to the chats with Zoltan and others you find out he's kinda running out of monsters to slay) and modeling him into what you believe Geralt was(or if you read the books bring him back because Geralt is already perfect <3).All in all,the game is pretty bad in some aspects *cough* combat *cough* but excels in other (I managed to beat a king at Poker Dice,so there's that added to the legendary White Wolf) parts like story telling and character development (of unestablished characters in the books). I also recommend reading the books AFTER playing the first two games,since knowing Geralt's story takes away from the first game. I give it a perfect 5/7 like I gave Fight Club,it's a great game and a must buy!

Posted: December 17, 2015
												Lets start with the....NEGATIVES:- The Lack of Fast Travel Hurts my Brainnn!! - Hard to find places to Meditate sometimes.- Most of the times the Mini-map doesn't work- Once any NPC is dead they come back to life after a while (I guess with the age of the game it's alright)?- Convos with NPC's can take a while to begin no ability to skip them with clicking.- Graphics a bit dated (only a bit)POSITIVES:- Amazing Lore (I Love it) - Combat easy to get into once you find out how to play (takes a while)- Really Easy at Medium (Could be a negative; I don't know about hard). This is just a bit too easy but I guess alright at the same time doesn't take out the level of fun it offers.- Great Inventory System. Helps me keep Organized the way I want. Like many RPG's you have to scan through the one thing you want. In this just organize it yourself with a huge pinboard option.- The Game assists you very well, tells you what you can sell or not.- NPC's react very well to environmental changes. Smart NPC's. - The monsters and characters all really fun to interact with.- Autosave is in my opinion NOT broken. Autosaves perfectly even saved my♥♥♥♥♥a couple of time XDOverall: Play this to begin your adventure into the Witcher world. I started by Witcher 2 and stopped as Soon as I saw this was on sale (never play Witcher 2 much anyway just like 2 hours in). My decision to buy this was worth it. I Love Geralt of Rivia now Thankx to this game. I've never read any of the books, However this game tempts me. This Game takes a time to get used to but once you get used to the Gameplay its really addicting. Other than that it does just shut off in the middle if played for long times. Idk if its my computer but yeah. You will absolutely adore it if you are fan of Fantasy RPG Elements.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												The graphics are terrible by today's standards, the narration is very unemotional, the combat is ok, and there was a mass of crashing issues, but I could not stop playing this masterpiece. This was CDPR's first game ever, I even heard that they didn't know how to make a game when they decided to start this process, but somehow they nailed almost every aspect of the game. This game will probably seem crappy to those who came here from The Witcher 3, but as many have said, over the course of this franchise, the games have improved in almost every aspect. There is plenty of stuff to do in this game. You are introduced to new sections of the world after you complete a chapter, but sadly you cannot go back during the next chapter of the game. I thought I would just slash away like in Skyrim, but CDPR made combat very smart and it requires thinking. You have potions, bombs, armor, signs, and many weapons to get you through the story. The main and side quests dont feel like the 'go here and kill this for some $$$' type of quests they have stories and rewards and they are engaging. I wasn't distracted by the graphics because the atmosphere of the game was so great. You are a witcher and people hate you, but they will pay you to do their bidding. The standards have been raised a lot since this game was released 9 years ago, but if you can, play this masterpiece before the Witcher 2 and 3, and you will love it.(if you go to the game location, you can find all the soundtracks, vlogs of making the movie world maps, etc)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												I was initially put off by this game. I bought it on sale about a year ago and told it would be worth my money. So I get it running and start playing the prologue. I found the controls clunky and hard to control, the combat system seemed needlessly convoluted and I died multiple times at the first boss, because I was so confused. I didn't have the patience for the game at the time. But here I am writing a positive review. I let it sit in my library for months and started to feel guilty that I spent money on a game I didn't want to play. So I decided to pick it up again and was determined to play it further and finish it whether I liked it or not, I felt that I owed the game a fair play, a game that so many obviously love and I couldn't help but feel that maybe I was missing out on something. I was right.I restarted the game and took the time to play and learn, I still find the combat a bit clunky, but I've learned to manage and succeed playing the game. I've found that The Witcher has a rich story to tell. The music is beautiful and character interactions provide a lot of depth to the world. For each new character you meet, each new beast you fight, and every note or book you find, new story elements are uncovered and added to your journal. It's clear the developers put a lot of time and heart into this game.One of the most intriguing elements of the game that nobody fails to mention is the Alchemy system. You gather various herbs, chemicals, and liquors which are used in alchemical recipes to create useful potions. You should pay attention to what you can use for a recipe because multiple subtitute reagents can be used as many materials contain the same derivative substance. The Witcher is far from perfect, but it has just enough depth to keep me hooked, it's an adventure I'm excited to continue and see to the end.

												Personally, I thought this game was amazing and haven't had a game keep me so interested for so long in quite a while. Story was very interesting and was told in a great way - through talking with the characters in the world, reading the many books you will find/purchase and also through the environment itself.I found the combat very enjoyable, using potions, oils, runes and more to improve my weapons based on the creatures I would face in the upcoming area (which can be found out by reading a monster's bestiary entry in your journal) and fighting enemies with the swords. I think that this strategy is the main focus of the combat, along with dodging at the right time and using signs (spells) to your advantage, as the swordplay is comprised of combo-ing enemies by clicking at the correct moment using one of three combat stances.I recommend this game to anyone who wants to invest a lot of time exploring, hunting monsters, completing various side-quests and chasing women.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												One of the finest RPGs, with a distinctly European feel. Geralt is a classic hero, a humane man trying to do his best in a conflicted situation. He has no need for cartoon brooding or snappy one-liners. Geralt's sex life has drawn so much attention that it must be mentioned here too. It is true that Geralt has sex for fun and to relieve stress, but he is not an addict by any means. One of my favorite scenes sees Geralt developing serious feelings towards his love interest. Like any reasonable man, he gets completely drunk with his friends to think things through. The world feels believable as well, with many memorable characters, both well-written and well-voiced. The story has an epic sweep, but is much closer to normal fantasy RPGs than many other things. Combat system is a bit counter-intuitive but can be overcome. Witcher 2 surpasses this but does not make it redundant, at all. I would actually recommend buying the GOG.com version instead, since the Steam version forces you to install many gigabytes of Collectors Edition bonuses.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												The Witcher is a great rpg based on a series of novels by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. Although some of the gameplay feels a bit clunky and dated, all the rpg elements around it are top notch. The Witcher has a fantastic storyline, great world building, interesting characters, deep lore, and some difficult moral choices.The graphics are great for a 2007 game. It's not the best looking game today but is quite serviceable. The music fits the mood of the game perfectly, feeling very folksy and at home in the Witcher's medieval Europe style world.Gameplay involves questing in each of the 5 chapters. There are many varied quests throughout the game. You'll be slaying monsters, chatting up politicians, romancing ladies, gathering herbs, playing poker, bare knuckle boxing, and more!The game is long, easily over 40 hours long on a first playthrough. If you do absolutely everything it might take you much closer to 80 hours. There's definitely not a lack of content in this game.All in all, I highly recommend it for anyone looking for a meaty rpg with a strong emphasis on story and setting. Also from what I hear you can import your Witcher 1 saved game into the sequel, the Witcher 2, which is reportedly also fantastic. The Witcher 3 is due out next year and looks absolutely beautiful from the screenshots and trailers. Definitely recommend starting with the first one and playing through the entire epic trilogy.

Posted: June 13, 2016
												the Witcher: Enhanced Edition is a great role-playing game. Developer CD Projekt has corrected almost all of the problems that made the original something of a flawed gem. Butchered English dialogue has been rewritten and expanded upon, removing the nonsensical lines that made the plot something of a guessing game last year. Engine performance has been dramatically improved across the board, so the game runs smoother on moderate systems, and you no longer have time to read a magazine while waiting for levels to load. Character models have been dramatically enhanced, removing a fair number of the unrealistic features that made the original game come off as somewhat cartoonish in spots. A pair of new stand-alone adventures has been added to bulk up gameplay outside of the main storyline. by 8.5 out 10 its a great to play!

												Initially, this was a slow burner for me. At times, the sheer complexity of the available choices you have can be daunting. I played this casually on and off through the first chapter. After getting used to the battle system, and the usefulness of alchemy, I actually really started to get drawn in by the story and the choices that you can make. The size and scope of this game is impressive. Towards the end, I found myself really becoming a fan, and I was looking forward to the ending. Minor gripes are that it can become very tedious completing secondary quests, mainly because travel can take a while across multiple maps. Also, little things like waiting for the transition between battle and explore mode in order to pick up items, etc. can really eat into time when you just want to see what happens next, or fight another monster.Overall though, I was extremely glad to have finished the game, and I'm excited about playing 2 and 3.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Overall a great game.GRAPHICS - Lack of diverse character models.  Many quest givers all have the exact same face, making distinction difficult.GAMEPLAY - Fun mechanics.  Rather than clicking rapidly, you are forced to play with more finesse, clicking only at the right times to continue/complete combos.It is best to understand the gameplay mechanics before deciding you hate it - a few simple, crucial tips will make all the difference between loving and hating this game (and seeing it through to the end):1. MONEY - Pick up EVERYTHING.  Sell any secondary weapons you find (you'll never use them, and they are worth a lot). Sell all LOW and MEDIUM strength alcohol (keep strong alcohol for alchemy).2. TALENT POINTS - Look through the GOLD point talents and decide on THREE main areas you want to focus on and dump all your talent points into those areas before diversifying.  This will dictate your combat style heavily, but make you much stronger overall. Spreading out your points with a "balanced build" will inherently make you weaker overall and good at nothing. Seriously, decide how you want to kill things and stick with it.3. ALCHEMY - Always have WHITE HONEY (removes toxicity) and WIVE'S TEARS (removes drunkeness) on hand.  Brew a stack of WHITE GULL (a base for other potions) and store all other strong alcohol until you need more WHITE GULL.  Bombs and Blade oils are specific to the Intelligence tree.  If you don't plan on going down that tree, you can sell all bases for them (powder and grease/tallow, respectively).4.  EXPLORATION/QUESTS - Explore all areas of the map at all times of day (namely noon and midnight).  Certain monsters only come out at certain times, and it's the only way to find/kill them for quests.  Do as many side quests as possible for extra xp/levels/talents.  You only get gold talents at higher levels, and they sure are strong.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												An excellent story, unmatched characterisation and a world brimming with life and character sets this apart from the crowd. Aside from the gripping plot, it's the little things that make the difference. Townsfolk huddling under canopies to shelter from the rain, birds flocking from a bush and you approach to harvest herbs. Features that The Witcher's big-budget peers (The Elder Scrolls, Dragon Age) lack. Round it off with a simple but elegant combat system and more than a few original ideas to shake up the classic RPG progression path and you've got one of the best action RPGs ever made. I implore you to finish this one and it's fantastic sequel before The Witcher 3 storms onto the scene and rocks our world.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												TLDR: Fantastic game; Combat is not very good but story is absolutely amazing. Graphics great for 2007, obviously lackluster for 2015. Not open world. Play on hardest difficulty, because after chapter 1 game is a cakewalk. Although not needed, (really at all) the story in this game serves to clarify references in the later games and creates a bigger sense of immersion in the game world. 8.5/10 because of combat and lack of challenge.This is my Witcher story. I bought Witcher 3 because I wanted a new RPG to play; it was absolutely amazing. I only got through the first chapter and realized that I didn't want the experience to end so quickly so I decided to buy the first one and work my way through that and once done with that play through the second and then eventually move on to finish the third. That's how good this series is, if you're a fan of action RPG's with good stories like me, get the trilogy pack instead of this because if you can bear the combat/graphics (both of which are not THAT bad) of Witcher 1 you will definitely want to play the second and third. You will also enjoy them moreso because you have the background info of the first one. So I loaded up Witcher 1 for the low cost of $9.99. First thing I noticed when I started playing the Witcher was the graphics, although extraordinary for 2007, after overclocking my GPU to play the third I was a little disappointed, but you can't ask for much when you backtrack to a game that came out 8 years ago!The next thing I noticed was that this game's story is awesome. Cheesily enough, you start off with amnesia. However Geralt's lack of memory serves to push the story forward; Alongside the main conflict in the story, you are trying to find out about Geralt's past through quests and former friends. The best part about the story is that you actually can't wait to find out what happens next. This is the only rpg where I actually read the extra books and lore things you find in the game world because they serve the story so well.  Where most RPG's push for progression by enticing you with new pieces of armor or weapons down the road, the Witcher puts you in a position where you actually want to find out what happens next and you don't really care about much else. However, at times, much of the story is told just by running back and forth and talking to various npcs - there gets to be a point when you want to just go out and smash some monster face. That leads me into one of the only two fair cons to find in this game (because you can't count the graphics of this game as a real con due to its age.) My problems with this game are the combat and the lack of challenge. The fights remind me of "Test Your Might" challenges from Mortal Kombat. You just wait until your sword turns yellow and then click, thats it. The whole combat system is click, wait a second or two, click, repeat. there's no real challenge or engagement to it. If you can't kill a monster you just reload and drink more buff potions. When I say there is no challenge to this game, I mean it. I always play games on their hardest difficulty just to feel like I really did beat the game. Even on the most difficult setting, I only had a few times where I struggled at all, and only one time I actually had any real difficulty. Chapter 1's boss fight is the only time I ever found myself struggling. Other than the boring combat and lack of challenge I don't have anything else to really gripe about. I mean the inventory system could have been better and there could have been more applications for alchemy but all in all this is a fantastic game. Sorry for the long winded review.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												Having played this game multiple times through, I can 100% recommend this game to anyone interested in the Witcher story.It should be noted that anyone looking to purchase and play this game must understand that it differs immensely from its successors in many ways. The voice acting, character animations, and combat can be a little rough for some, but ultimately the game itself presents an excellent story and really pulls you in to assume the role of a witcher. You'll memorize what combat styles and Signs are useful for each monsters, learn the appearance and usage of herbs throughout the world, and you'll read and learn the lore of the Witcher.The game presents choices throughout the game, some of which affect the story later. It is up to you decide whether Geralt will take sides or maintain his neutrality as a witcher.Ultimately, if you intend to play the Witcher 2 or Witcher 3, I recommend you play the full trilogy for the full experience.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												tl;dr 8/10 Good game, Very good story, Confusing mechanics but you will learn to love it. Pro+ awesome story+ awesome quests+ awesome world+ awesome sex with hot babeCon- game mechanics- combat gameplay- lot of walking around Full review  First game in The Witcher series from CD project red. You will play as Garelt, an amnesia-return-from-the-dead-witcher. who try to regain his memory while on his quest to get the bad guy.As a witcher you are a monster slayer, a human who train since a child with drug use until become a superhuman to slay monster (and laid girls). Too bad Geralt get amnesia and forget all his fighting skill, magic and knowledge.The witcher is RPG game with lot of things to do and learn,Story is so good it’s a pure sex, literally.Every quest have story in it.You will have to make a choice, take side, spare or kill which will impact the story later on.There is also many interesting things to do. Play dice poker, Fist fight, Hunt monster, Help random people and collect romance cards AKA getting laid. You want to have threesome with nurse? Orgy with vempires? Passionate love with sorcerer? This game have it all!!Graphic is quite good, for old game. The atmosphere and graphic fit the wolrd of witcher nicely. Music are very good too especially boss fight.Gameplay is fun. Combat? Not so much. When you attack Garelt will perform one set of sword move. When the move end cursor will change and you have to click attack again to make combo. If you click attack before or too late the move will stop. It's not that bad actually after you get used to and quite fun later in the game when you are strong but overall combat feel clunky, unresponsive and can be frustrated.Gameplay is fun and addictive but you will found yourself walking around the map doing quest. Go there, do that kinda thing. No fast travel in this game too. While I find myself enjoy the world and love exploring it. Walking around across the map many times can be boring.Game mechanics take awhile to get used to. Especially alchemy and crafting.There is a steel sword for fight human and silver sword to fight monster. There is 3 different fighting style for different enemies. There is potions, blade oils, bombs with different effect which you can make and use if you get ingredients. You will have to buy books or find information about each monster and herb to be able to collect it. And many other little thing.It will feel annoying at first but it will be a lot of fun after you get used to it. Too bad that I start to feel fun in the last chapters of the game.The witcher may have boring start with it gameplay and story especially if you have play other witcher games before. Give it a try for a few hour first before you decide to uninstaling it. Conclusion  The Witcher overall is a very fun RPG. Rich in story and charecter. Combat might not be the best and game mechanics might be confusing but worth to play and I'm sure you won't regret it.If you interesting in the witcher series from CDPR DO NOT skip this one.ps: sorry for my english.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												My first Witcher experience was The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt. After my first 60 hours in what is the finest masterpiece of a game I have ever played, I realized I wanted to stop and go back to the beginning of the series. The Witcher 1 is still a great game in 2016. The graphics have aged nicely. The voice acting hasn't, so be prepared to laugh at some of the characters' dialogue (I think Kalkenstein must have escaped some pocket of hell to possess an ape that then dressed as a human and lost weight).The combat is fun after you understand it. It requires semi-precise timing, patience, and does what I think the devs set out to do; give the feel of a real witcher in combat. Geralt dances around his enemies, changes between two swords, three combat styles for each sword, and delivers a cycle of blows to keep them from hitting him. The rhythm to the combat controls adds to the "dance" feel of the combat. Geralt also must prepare potions manually, and earn gold by completing side quests. At several points I found myself a few hundered orens short of an item that I NEEDED to purchase for the main quest. I can't recall many games that did this. Most games give you the items that are required for quests, and give you gold to optionally upgrade your stats. Instead, the Witcher is a true role playing experience. You will need to earn gold to progress at certain points, which is part of the lore of being a Witcher; they are monster hunters FOR HIRE. This is their job, and they need to make a living.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												I am not sure how to review a game like this. I enjoyed it, but it has flaws. Reminds me a lot of STALKER in that way. Good story, and level design made me play this game to the end, but quite a few of mechanics are not polished. I am hoping the sequels address these issues.For me, the highlights of this game are characters, environment, story and music. I thoroughly enjoyed the setting, and the music is perfect. For those alone, this game deserves to be played. It is a true classic in my opinion, right up there with Deus Ex. I have not played any of the other games in the series yet, but this game has set an excellent platform for future games.The world is fairly well built. The game involves you revisiting some locations, after they have transformed quite a bit, and I think the art team has done a great job showing this transformation. There are certain levels I did not like, but that's a personal perference.The story is well told, and they do a good job of keeping the player invested. I was genuinely interested in knowing how my choices are going to impact the end game.I am now going to talk about the things I did not like about this game. Controls takes some getting used to. This game is somewhat like Mass Effect; there is no jump, or crouch, but unlike Mass Effect, the movement is very stiff. I never felt I had full control over the character actions. During combat this lack of control will get you killed a few times, especially because Geralt puts his sword away at the beginning of most cutscenes before battle, and as soon as the cutscene is over, a number of enemies will jump at you, and the delay in drawing out the sword will drain some precious health. Who thought this was a good idea? They had to have done this intentionally. One wonders what their rationale was for a silly mechanic like this.Boss battles can be extremely annoying. Just about every boss battle follows the same formula. A cutscene, followed by some dialogue and then combat begins by trapping you in the area in some manner. This may not sound bad, but considering it is not possible to save the game when you are in combat, dying would mean having to go through all the cutscene and dialogue each time. The lack of quick save and quick load only adds to the pain. This is bad game design in my opinion.Health system is needlessly convoluted. As I understand it, health regenerates automatically at a very slow rate. Eating food should accelerate the rate of regeneration, but its hardly helpful in a combat situation. Geralt has to stop in his tracks and consume food, and this will most likely get you killed. Same goes for health potions. Why the character cannot be in motion while consuming food or potions, I do not know.The dialogue and voice acting can range from excellent to goofy. Same character models are used all over the game, to the point where, you can have four NPC characters talking to each other that look identical.Alchemy is another mechanic that was not fully fleshed out. It is possible to craft a lot of potions, but the ones I used most frequently are for regenerating health faster, and then a potion to reduce the toxicity caused by using these health potions. This never made any sense to me. Why would health potions have toxic properties? Either way, I felt like Alchemy was a wasted opportunity in terms of affecting gameplay. The fact that all potions increase toxicity, meant that I had no real to use them, unless absolutely necessary.I still maintain that this game, in-spite of its flaws, is a lot of fun and it is worth playing. I am contemplating installing Witcher 2 right now to pick up where I left off.Verdict - Must play
