content:
Posted: February 4
 A FLAWED CLASSIC This is an adult, fantasy story full of beauty, darkness and complexity. There is a lot of European mythology, lots of political subjects and lots of magic. There is a ton of lore within the game, so it's wise to read the books, talk to the NPC's and go through the game a second time to get every bit out of this game. One thing this game does very well is make you question every choice you made in the game because it's never clear that you are fighting for the better cause. To put it short: I did my best throughout my playthrough to be a good person. This game does a great job at investing you within it's story and world.  PROS  Beautiful world to explore with tones of lore Story is amazing Soundtrack fits this game perfectly  Graphics are great and the FPS is smooth Choices matter and make you think Great ending CONS  The voice acting can be god awful at times Not the easiest game for anyone to get into Tons of fetch quests Combat is clunky Clumsy interface Most of the items you collect are pointless unless you play it on hard BRO POINTS  You can have sex with women to collect cards like Pokemon! Geralt is a BOSS! An adult game! FINAL THOUGHTS It has a lot of short comings, but the story and setting is so rich that it overcomes all of that and then some.This a game for true RPG fans. If you already played through your favorite RPG's and are looking for a new series to get lost into.. This is the one. Like any great gaming trilogy.. Play the first one to truely get the real enjoyment out of it.Plus it's ALWAYS on SALE!!! No excuse to miss out.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												So, I just finished this game after spending 86 hours. I like it very much and I recommend it to everyone looking to pick up an RPG game.Pros:- Story is very good. There's a lot of lore that you can explore.- Lots of quests that you can do so you will never get bored. Personally, I even did many side quests which is why I took so long to finish this game and yet, I still missed some of them.- There are three types of fighting styles you can use. You can choose whether you want to exclusively use sword skills (easiest) or signs (hardest) to fight enemies throughout the entire game or you can also use a combination of both sword skills and signs (balanced)- This is a "choice matters" game which means every choice you make throughout the game affects the story. There are three story paths you can take: the Order (Knights/Humans), the Scoia'tael (Elves/Non-Humans), or Neutral (Witcher).- Due to this game having three story paths, it has a pretty decent replay value.- SEX. Many girls that you can sleep with. You get a card showing all their goods after sex scenes (there are no actual sex scenes). Cons:- The game game gives you an error that says you don't meet the minimumum specs when you first launch it requireing you to use the"-dontforceminreqs" launch command even though you have the hardware to run this game. Many people complain about this even to this day.- Due to using the "-dontforceminreqs" command, texture quality is set to low and is disabled in-game making graphics look ugly. This requires you to download a mod (search the discussions section of this game for said mod or use Google).- The game has crashed multiple times on me. Usually this isn't a problem for me but when multiple crashes happen one after the other, then it becomes a problem. Not to mention that on some crashes the game stays on a black screen with audio still playing but I can't alt-tab out of the game which requires me to switch to another user account and end the game process on that account. Luckily, I've made it a habit to save often in games where you can create manual saves or I would have lost plenty of progress throughout my playthrough. - No native controller support. Given that this game is pretty old, I can't really complain about this. It would be nice if this game had controller support though. Yes, I am aware that there are programs out there that I can use to map keyboard keys to controller buttons but that requires a lot of work.- Combat system seems a bit slow. Also, sometimes, Geralt attacks another enemy when I am clicking on another enemy.- This is a linear game so exploring is limited. Speaking of which, if you pick up quest, make sure you finish that quest on the chapter you picked it up at because you may not be able to access the area or talk to the people you need to complete said quest due to being relocated to another place when you progress to the next chapter.Overall: Despite this game's flaws, it's still a pretty solid game. If you're looking for a game you can sink many hours into, then this game is for you. It has lots of content and the story is very good. I highly recommend this game. Rating:Story; 9/10Graphics: 8/10Gameplay: 7.5/10Enjoyment: 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												I'm writing this shortly after entering Chapter V. The reason I'm doing it now, is that the game's so intense and its world so prone to change that I fear I might not be able to have a clear mind on what I went through in the first 4 chapters after what is likely going to be a groundbreaking final chapter.I think few would disagree with the following statement: You'll both love and hate this game. At times you'll find yourself half asleep with your finger passively laying on the W key, and the only enthusiasm you might have left will be barely enough to head to the main menu and quit the game. Why is that? Because like Geralt loves saying, the game's "so full of♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;.  Back-and-forth is going to take almost all of your gametime from amidst chapter 1 until the end of chapter 4, although it will progressively decrease from the beginning of chapter III onwards. I'd want to invest more time to let all my frustration for Chapter II and III out, but it would make the following considerations futile to the reader.Another thing worth mentioning is the combat. It is odd, and you'll nourish a deep hatred against it, but you'll eventually end up liking it - for the most part. I think the stances, the various disarm/stun/pain bonuses and the talents related to them are really interesting. So, regardless how bad and unfamiliar the combat moves myl feel, understanding how it works actually makes it better than click-spamming like a dumbass to strike enemies without reasoning (no reference to Assassins of Kings of course!). This pretty much sums up the game mechanics. "Wow, really? What's your rationale for recommending the game then? You basically said it's all about walking and getting over the clunky combat system." I recommend it because the story is truly fascinating and if you managed to read this boring review on its entirety you'll likely get past the hours of tedious walking and enjoy the amazing plot this game has to offer. I wish I'd played the first game before AoK, to some extent. Come back to this review and leave a comment, if you've managed to finish the Witcher without falling in love with its characters, its twists, its grey morality and the amazing narration from Geralt. Frankly, there's one thing I didn't find immersive at all: the landscapes. Because of the constant walking you'll probably start hating many of the places this game includes, one at a time.Lastly, we all refrain from being over-emotional when it comes to fictional stuff, but the first Witcher really gifted me with some good memories - sort as if it was a book - hence I guess the developers really inspired themselves to Sapkowski's work.11,06,15 EDITI've finally completed the game, and I feel I must give a few advices: don't rush it avoiding all secondary quests, unless you've picked the easy difficulty. Besides that, remember to spend some time doing alchemy: gather ingredients, read the scrolls you collect during the story. Lastly, go get the Raven's armour even if you don't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about it. I'm saying this, because you'll find it really hard to beat the bosses in chapter V and the epilogue (except for a couple which can be defeated through some exploits in the stupid AI). Taking down the Zeugl was exceptionally frustrating, and I had to load a savefile from 4-5 hours back in order to gather all the necessary to take it down.Ideally, you should enter the Old Manor at level 27 or above. If you want a further challenge without going hard mode ignore this, but I fathom you might have a bit of save reloading to get along with.What is a bit ridiculous is that whilst the Zeugl and the Koshchey, that are neither mentioned nor relevant during the story, are somewhat hard to beat; bosses like Javed and the true arch enemy (which I won't mention for your own sake) are relatively easy to kill.

content:
Posted: April 25
												I really want to play The Witcher 3 but I felt the need to play The Witcher 1 and 2 first. I am about 30 hours into The Witcher 1 but I have completely lost my self in this game! I can't get enough of it. The decisions you have to make in the game are hard ones. I find myself stressing about what sides to take. I feel like a lot of people dislike the combat that is in the game, and at first I wasn't a fan. But you will be doing more role playing then fighting in this game, and after the first chapter I really found that I was starting to enjoy the combat. This game is definitely old, and you definitely have to get over that to play it. I installed some mods when I first started playing but I found playing with out them was more enjoyable. I would say I enjoy The Witcher 1 more then any AAA game that I have played in the past 3 years. Play The Witcher 1 you'll probably enjoy The Witcher 2 and 3 more if you do.

content:
Posted: January 31
												Meh. It's alright.The game has a fairly interesting world (credit going to the book's author there, less than the game itself), the plot has a few cool ideas here and there, and there's some good humour now and again.But the combat is a tedious mess, half the game involves running around between quest points (especially the first chapter, Outskirts of Vizima - what an awful bunch of fetching and grocery shopping), the dialog is wooden, and the lighting is atrocious. Half the time during in-game cinematics, the lighting is so bad I can barely see the characters' faces - and that's when the camera isn't inexplicably staring at their shoulders or chest instead of their face.I played this so that I could have a save to import into The Witcher 2 and then 3, and as far as that goes, success. But I doubt I would have stuck with it otherwise - I abandoned it years ago, and only came back now because its sequels are getting such acclaim. So... play if it you're a completionist for the whole Witcher series, I guess.

Posted: October 13, 2012
												The Witcher is one of the greatest western RPGs. As you travel along as a Geralt you face many monsters, persons, fights, magic and problems. What is great about Witcher, is the possibility to choose from options how to make the plot go on. I wish I could stop the time and start it all over, just to see what other fates I could have faced. Talent-tree keeps playing interesting and let's players choose what kind of gameplay they prefer. Some problems still bug Witcher and one of them is limited amount of character models. It's not a big problem, but might get annoying for some if the same npc-face in different clothes isn't making sense. Another thing is that Mac version is quite bad port, so the game does crash from time to time and isn't working as it should. Still the game was playable and didn't stop me from enjoying this spectacular piece of pure art. Definitely one of my all-time-favorites.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Many poeple complaints about the combat system of Witcher 1, but i think the most oustanding part of this game is the combat system and its relevant supporting system -  portions and the dialogue of monsters. The game requies you "think' and change the attack mode rapidly to deal with diiferent emenies - humans and monsters.Two swords and three attack  modes; strong, quick and group mode, you have to chose which attack mode is the most suitable for the foes and the situation. Different emeny may requires you using different strategy to deal with. Somtimes you have to use different potions  on your sword to enhance the damage to particular type of emeny. And sometimes you have to fortify your resistance or mana and health regeneration. Before each mission, you have to prepare certain potions to  unforeseen situation later. You also have to gather the books  of the monster (which gives you weakness of the monster) and the formula of the potions in the game to preparation. All the above mentioned featues make the combat system unique, complex and really worth spend time in the exploration. Althoug the story may not be so epic for me and certain main quest requires you travel  forward and backward of same road many times (it really♥♥♥♥♥♥off me), if you want to learn more about the story of Geralt and Triss, I think this game give you quite amount of information and worth you to play.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2013
												 The Witcher is based on bookk series of author Andrzej Sapkowski. The game provides you the story of Geralt of Rivia, the beast slayer, deep into the medieval dark fantasy, discover the Salamander plan, conflict between species. Every moments and quest plots are really polished and reasonable decisions. With strong and complex RPG elements and point-and-click combat style (Combat styles, parry, dodge, signs, and alchemy), it reminded your old school feeling and very enjoyable. As enhanced edition, most of scripts and plots are rearranged to be more outstanding. In addition, the soundtracks are really great and well-fit.The clipping issue during combat which cause Garalt's animation to be delayed and some glitch of inventory and quest tracker annoy me a little. However, they're just minor issues that I had encountered along the game, compared to overall execution. I have no doubt to say it's one of my RPG masterpiece all the time :)

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Witcher is probably the best RPG series out there yet. It rivals both Elder Scrolls and Dragon Age with ease, despite their longer game play. Witcher is a story rich game. Even the side quests in witcher have some kind of a story associated with them. You do have your typical go to a point, fetch something and return type of side quests but they can be easily completed while progressing through the story. It also has a balanced combat system. You do need to make use of alchemy if you're to survive. If you fail at first, you need to try a different approach. Simple brute force will only get you half way. The other important thing to notice here is that the witcher is not your typical patogonist. Unlike most other heroes, he's not the sole savior of the world or the chosen one. He's a simple monster slayer who is driven by ideals or personal matters or the code of witchers depending on the choices you make. He is sometimes a necessary evil.There are no character classes so to speak. Geralt is a swrodsman and a good one at it. He uses two swords. A steel swrod for humans and a silver swrod for monsters. If you're one of those people who prefer mages over warriors, this may not be the game for you. BUT Geralt has his witcher signs. They are kind of similar to spells. So you can develop your character focusing on those but his main tools of trade will always be swrods.You can get about 50 hours of game play for one play through and there are three main different paths you can take. You can, of course, use an older save file and make a different choice if you don't want to start from the beginning. One down side is that one save file ranges from 15-30 MB. I have about 6 GB worth of save files just because I tend to save too often just in case things get ugly. Also, there is no fast travel function except for couple of teleporters in chapters 2 and 3. So be prepared to run around a lot. But if you plan ahead, you can minimize the amount of running around. I've played both witcher 1 and 2 and I just bought them again on steam recently. Trust me, it's worth your every penny.Also, Geralt of Rivia, the famed witcher, cannot keep it in his pants!

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												If you're looking for a reason to buy this game please read the following,This game has nicely done storytelling through quest note, NPC dialogue or cutscenes, however, the game pretends to be something it cannot, for it plays like an MMORPG with fetch quests and kill x creature, but perhaps you might find interesting that it has a quite good crafting system, you go out, get some drops, harvest some plants, get an alcohol base for your potion, but that's not enough, you need to buy a book which describes how to make said potion (though, not in depth, mind you, it's just a few words then you close the book, done, you know the recipe).So far I've told you about its crafting, storytelling and quests, however, you should know that, the game is rather short if you stick to the main quests of each chapter, as many can't stomach the length of every chapter when they try to do every sidequest it has to offer.What I found very enjoyable was leveling up, because, as you level up, you earn talents (skill points) you can spend on useful perks, mostly passive, and also, you can't become OP early in the game, since talents are divided in three groups, bronze, silver and golden talents, tied to a certain range of levels, limiting you to useful, yet not groundbreaking skills, except for the magic signs you use, as a witcher, they're just magic spells, wind, fire, trap, shield and brainwash (I guess?), you also level up those with talent points and the same rule applies to them, however, the wind sign might prove more useful than you may think (I recommend you level this first, as you'll be ambushed early in the game by multiple monsters).I greatly disliked the combat, though, because you have to switch between three types of attack and two weapons, I don't remember the name of them, but it goes like this, strong, fast and group attack, the first is used against large enemies, the second, for agile ones, and the last, used when ambushed. then, your weapons, a silver weapon used against monsters and a steel one, which is used against humans.Would I suggest you buy this game? Only if you want to get into The Witcher games and want to start with the first one, or you could read the books.

Posted: September 5, 2014
												This game was kind of tough to push through.  The first 5-7 hours are quite "fetch-questy" and slow (lots of mindless running).  However by the end of chapter 2 the story really gets going and I got into it.  But even then I'm not sure if the average gamer would like this game. I chose to play it because I loved The Witcher 2 so much but I soon realized how big of an improvement The Witcher 2 was in game design.  The Witcher controls are VERY PC which threw me off at first until I embraced the mouse and keyboard controls, normally with RPGs I like to sit back on the couch and relax with a gamepad. The graphics hold up for the most part and its quest and map systems work great.Overall its a good game but takes some commitment to push through the first 1/3 of the game. I see why it was so highly acclaimed back in 2007 but I also see why it wasnt a mainstream hit.  I would only recommend it to someone who really wants to experience the whole story before The Witcher 3 comes out...and even then I'm not so sure.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
A masterpiece!The Witcher is the result of when a team of doctors work together to develop a video game. I will go on record saying that this is one of the absolute best games ever made. I've done 4 playthroughs total of this game and have not gotten bored. Witcher 1 has one of the most well written storylines of any RPG ever. A lot of RPG games trap themselves with moral decisions by making them purely good or evil choices. There's no black or white extremes in The Witcher though. Almost all characters in the entire world of the game have done good and bad things. It's this important difference that sets The Witcher apart so well. Some of the moral decisions and choices you have to make in the game will really cause you to stop for a moment and reflect on the situation. It's a game that has such powerful choices that it will literally make you reflect on your own morality. When does the means justify the ends? Where does somebody draw the line? Can bad things be jusitfied for a higher cause? These are a few of several questions you will ask yourself by the end of this masterpiece. The characters of the game are also unforgettable. Geralt the protagonist is a badass who you definitely can't help, but be a fan of. NPC's in the game are wonderful too and you can have discussions with them that add more to the world and story of The Witcher. Beyond the story, the gameplay is great too. The combat system is a fun timing based system where you click at the right times to do combo attacks. In addition, you get signs which can knock down enemies, set up instant kills, light enemies on fire or trap them etc. Defeating enemies grants you EXP along with completing quests. You then level up after accumulating enough EXP and can distribute talent points into Geralt's abilities. Witcher's leveling system for increasing Geralt's strength is incredible. The amount of choices and possibilties are wonderful and every playthrough I always found myself trying out different builds. Witcher 1's combat is incredibly fun, but I won't lie it's far from a amazing combat system or one that will appeal to everyone. Some may just not like the timing nature of the combat system. It's not for everyone and you have been warned about this. Also, I mentioned quests. Witcher does have them.They are found in the main story and sidequests. You can track quests to figure out where to go and it works very well. Witcher's sidequests are excellent though and a standard that RPG's should look up to. Almost every sidequest has a great story to it that upon completing it allows you to learn more about characters, the world and the story of the game itself. A sign of a well made sidequest is when the player doesn't just do it for a great reward in the game, but also for the content of the quest itself. That's another aspect Witcher excels in. There's as I mentioned a main story consisting of a prologue, epilogue and 5 chapters inbetween those two. Each chapter you go through in the game is drastically different. In one you explore a village and help the residents there, but come to learn of some of the atrocities the residents have committed there. It ultimately reaches a climax where you must judge the villagers and decide their fates. In another chapter you go to meetings with nobles and powerful polticians where you form strong alliances with powerful people. Then there's a chapter in the game where you have to cooperate with a detective to figure out who committed a murder. The chapter has several different outcomes depending on the choices you make. Different events, dialogue and fights happen all depending on what choices you make. Ultimately, the game's story reaches it's climax in the epilogue and final chapter of the game Chapter 5. Chapter 5 is one of the most epic parts I've ever played in a RPG. Afterward, in the epilogue you confront the final antagonist of the game whom makes references to all the decisions you made throughout the game. Even me doing a sidequest in Chapter 1 was mentioned in the final confrontation of the game. Talk about a game truly changing even by doing small things. The replay value is immense.In Witcher 1 there are three paths through the game. I won't spoil the three sides, but each one has different scenes, dialogues, locations and fights you experience in them. I'm no fanboy either though and will admit the game doesn't drastically change depending on your decisions. It does change a little, but you're not gonna see half of the entire game change because you aligned yourself with a different side in a future playthrough of the game. Still, the replay value is great and it's the choices making these little changes that make this wonderful game all the more satisfiying to play through. Last, the music.The music of Witcher 1 is excellent. I'm not much of a fan of orchestrated music, but The Witcher really caught my attention with it's jaw droppingly good soundtrack. Some of the songs in the game such as The River of Life or several others really impressed me. In terms of voice acting, the game can be a mixed bag. Some voice acting is good, but some are not so good. Overall though, The Witcher is a masterpiece and one of my all time favorite games. I think that the world and story of the game are among the very best in any game ever. Beyond that, the combat is very fun, but admittedly is not going to be for everyone and is far from one of the most amazing battle systems ever. Last, the game has a great soundtrack and immense replay value with how choices impact the game. Any RPG fan owes it to themselves to experience this masterpiece of a game. I've finished 4 playthroughs of it and I will definitely play it more times through.TLDR Version:Pros:+One of the best stories and worlds in any RPG ever.+Great characters who are incredibly well developed.+Choices that affect how the game plays. Three main sides to choose from in the game each one giving the player a different experience.+Fun combat system that while not amazing or super great is still awesome.+Incredible amount of customization upon leveling.+Excellent soundtrack.+Extremely well done sidequests that players will want to do because the content of the sidequests adds more to the world and story of the game.+The developers CD Projeckt Red are a role model in a industry that screws gamers over. They give out DLC free and all updates or changes they make to their games are free. Also, they make all their games DRM free.Cons:-Outdated graphics even for the time.-Reused character models for NPC's.-Combat system isn't absolutely incredible and won't appeal to everyone, but it's a lot better then most games out there.-Main plot goes in too many directions and some of the directions it goes in are left as loose ends and never wrapped up by the end of the game. In other words, a little too ambitious for it's own good at times.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Score 90/100The Witcher has many virtues and the sentence "arguably one of the best RPGs ever made" summarizes it.When I first played this I found it buggy as it was the first version, but then the Enhanced Edition came and I could finally enjoy the game. It's a real modern RPG, with choices that matter, a well-realized world, great characters, great graphics and sound. It's very unique too, with its intriguing combat, cool alchemy system, solid novel-like story and main character *real* dark fantasy world with a vivid Middle Ages tone, entertaining dialogs and people, knights, princes, monsters and everything in between.So I can't think of a reason why hardcore RPG fans wouldn't like this game. In this final enhanced edition, bugs and performance issues are virtually non existent.Finally I'd like to add that even at full price this is a fantastic game which could easily see you spend 80+ hours on.BackstoryYour name is Geralt of Rivia and you are a witcher, that means you kill monsters for a living. You were given special training to be the best at what you do and your body has been enhanced with potent elixirs to help you do it.Suffering from amnesia you remember nothing of your past. Kaer Morhen, the last remaining keep of the witchers, was attacked by a mysterious organization, just as you were starting to lick your wounds there. The battle is won but the secret recipe for the mutagen, a substance required to create more of your kind, has been stolen. The surviving witchers set out to find and reclaim it and punish everyone involved. Memory loss or not, you are one of them.Set in a dark fantasy world with a unique medieval, yet somewhat modern, feel to it, The Witcher isn't just another fantasy RPG. With a deep story, complex characters, and tough choices that actually matter, this game will keep you glued to your monitor for days.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												So, you'll all have heard of the Witcher series by now and you're wondering: "should I play the first game in order to play the rest?" Simple answer: no, you don't. Nonetheless, I heartily recommend it. I, too, heard the Witcher 3 was an awesome game, and thought about playing the first two games first. I won't ever regret that decision.So let's cut to the chase: what's good, what's bad, why do I recommend it? For a start, this game is already nine years old. Don't expect any of the visual quality we have nowadays. That being said, through the visual style, the developers put you in an incredibly immersive world which has a very particular and authentic feeling to it, which I've never seen before in a game. The atmosphere in this game is one of a kind and I'll always associate certain feelings with it. Furthermore, the Witcher series renowns itself for it's great storylines, starting in the first game and not getting any worse up to the second DLC of the last game (B&W). But it all started here. The characters are well-defined and real humans with motive and reason. Everyone has a purpose. Combine these last two points to have a very good reason to play this game.Now why do people tell you you can skip it? Well, simply because the story isn't continuous. While there is a bigger overarching story, it is not prominent in any of the games because each one has its own story which begins and ends within the game. Another reason is that is a tedious game. You move slowly, can barely fast travel and there are no means to speed up. The main story took me about 30-35 hours, of which I spend at least 40% traveling between the objectives. There are mods that increase your movement speed, but I didn't use one. Next up is combat. Combat in the Witcher is very unique. It is click-based, where you have to time your click just right in order to not get stabbed, or to chain hits and do more damage. There are also different attack styles: fast, strong and group, each of which should be used against different types of foes. Some people love this system, some hate it and of course some don't care. In reality, I think everyone should be able to adapt to it, as long as you're motivated to uncover the story.So, do I recommend it? Heartily. The unique atmosphere this game sets was one in a kind and unforgettable. Do you need to play it? Definitely not, but please do it!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												So, the question: Should you buy The Witcher: Enhanced Edition? Well, if you had put off playing The Witcher, there's no better time to start. For the price, the TW:EE pack has a tremendous amount of value and the sort of extras usually only found in a Collector's Edition. It's still a marvelous game, and everything included fixes most of the nagging flaws that were initially present. If, on the other hand, you do have The Witcher, then don't bother — not because it isn't worth it, but because absolutely every part of TW:EE is free to download online from the official Web site. All of it: the guide, the map, the making-of videos, the adventures and the new translation. If you don't have a speedy, unlimited Internet connection, or if you want physical copies, then you may of course wish to purchase the boxed version, but it's fantastic for fans of the game that they've been rewarded in such a way.If you didn't buy The Witcher before, then you've got little excuse now. And if you did, then The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is the perfect opportunity for a second playthrough

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												Based on Andrzej Sapkowski's character and world, The Witcher is a finely crafted Dark (with a capital D) fantasy adventure that any fan of RPG's should play. Be aware though that this game is very mature and should not be played by kids. Sure there's the sex scenes but more importantly, it deals with mature themes that require a little world experience to fully comprehend and thus, I only recommend this game for adults.The game features a Witcher, Geralt of Rivia, who travels to the city of Vizima to investigate an attack on The Witcher's home castle. Witchers are a dying race of humans subjected to experiments and magic in order to make them into the perfect monster hunters. Despite being necessary in their monster-infested world, Witchers are treated with disdain by most people and tolerated only by those requiring their services. Geralt of Rivia has had many adventures already throughout Sapkowski's five novels and numerous short stories featuring the character. Unfortunately for us foreigners, the books were never translated until after this game was released. Because of this, the game utilizes an amensia story that, while never fully realized, is a huge help to those of us who are just now being introduced to the character. There are some references to the stories that are undoubtedly more meaningful to those who've read them but I never felt lost despite having no prior knowledge of the series.While the combat is fun and requires a unique sense of timing and preperation to master, the storyline is really the biggest draw to this game. Many previous games have attempted to capture the meaningful sense of choice and impact upon the storyline but few are as successful as The Witcher, primarily because it isn't about good versus evil. Some choices will clearly have a moral facet to them but even those aren't clear cut, even if you usually play games a certain way. A decision that you will need to make throughout the game involves the conflict between the Scoia'tel and the humans in charge. It's clear from the beginning that non-humans are consistently abused and oppressed by the human-dominated society and the Scoia'tel want to change this through violence not always targeting their direct aggressors. Most players will sympathise with the non-human's plight but it is hard to get behind the murders they commonly commit. While their tactics may be reprehensible, are you really willing to side with the religious extremists who want to wipe the non-humans out completely?Choices like this permeate the game and your decisions will always come back to you later. At the time, almost all are about choosing the lesser of two evils. Sometimes, these choices can come back to help you later but most don't ever allow you the satisfaction of knowing you made the right choice. Instead, it's simply about making choices and living with the consequences. In the dark world of The Witcher, these choices make for some memorable experiences.The gameplay is based on a heavily edited version of the Aurora engine used by BioWare so RPG elements should be readily familiar to most fans. The combat is rather unique though in that success is based on preparation and proper timing. Geralt is equipped with two blades, the silver blade and the steel blade. Silver is for monsters, steel is for humans. Each blade has three fighting stances: strong, fast and group. Fighting enemies means being able to switch, on the fly, to adapt to whatever situation you find yourself in. If you are fighting a group of wraiths, you should use Silver Group, but some situations involve you fighting more ambiguous groups of enemies, such as humans aided by mutant dogs. Figuring out the best option is key but you must always keep your cool. Attacks are done by simply clicking the left mouse button but to keep a combo going, you must click in rhythm with Geralts attacks. Clicking too soon or too late will leave you open to attack.You also have several magic abilities to assist you but they are not your typical options. More often than not, your magic will be supplementary, requiring strategy to actually help you in any way. For example, you can stick with Igni, your fire spells, to cause some direct damage to your enemies but it may be better to Hex a strong foe and have them fight on your behalf against the rest of the enemies, wiping out the party completely without you needing to get your hands dirty. This strategy plays into the preperation aspect of the game as well. If you play on easy, you won't need to worry about potions and oils but if you plan on playing at a higher level, mastering alchemy and predicting what enemies you will be facing off against is key to your success. Potions will help boost your abilities and oils will help you target specific types of enemies and can make the difference between death and success, even against basic encounters. This focus on strategy may turn off gamers more interested in fast paced hacking and slashing but for those of you looking for a more strategic level in your RPG's, look no further.The game isn't perfect, however, as glitches often muddy your experience. While I never had the game crash completely on me, graphical glitches were common and sometimes NPC's did some very strange things. At one point, I had a cow that would appear by my side whenever I traveled to a new area or meditated at a camp. Otherwise, it would stay perfectly still. While it was exciting to see my cow companion backing me up in conversations, it didn't do much for the atmosphere. The game can get bogged down by filler quests too. Act II is a problem offender and will likely be where most players quit playing the game. I urge you to power through this section of the game as the rest of the game sets a much higher bar.For those of us who haven't been introduced to the world of Geralt of Rivia yet, The Witcher is a masterpiece of dark fantasy fiction. While it's not as outwardly gory as, say, Game of Thrones, it deals with many of the same mature themes. If you appreciate a little philosophical soul-searching in your RPG's, The Witcher is one of the best games you'll find.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Initially bought The Witcher: Enhanced Edition Director's Cut to get to know the lore of the franchise a little better and build some hype for The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt.The Witcher is a game with focus on combat and dialogue.The way you build your relations with the characters can change how your story will develop. Additionally, depending on some of your choices, some events on the 2nd game can happen or not.The game has a pretty simple story when compared to the other 2, but that doesn't make it a bad game.In combat, Geralt focuses in a single enemy and you have to click in the correct time for him to perform a successful attack. At first, it's kind of wonky, but you get used to it eventually.The alchemy system is very intriguing, because it actually makes you wander around the woods to collect herbs. Also, since Geralt initially doesn't have any knowledge in alchemy, you also have to buy books and learn about the variety of plants in the game. So far, this has been the only Witcher game in which I actually had to brew a bunch of potions to actually survive in battles.In my opinion, there are only 5 likeable characters in the game that actually stick around with you,  Triss, Jaskier, Zoltan, Alvin and Siegfried. It's quite old, the graphics aren't really pretty nor ugly for its age. (Around 8 years old.)I didn't go through any glitches or bugs during my playthrough.The soundtrack is pretty alright.I have only one complaint,  and it is the boss in Chapter 1. I'm not sure if it's supposed to be hard like that or if I'm just bad at games. I highly recommend this game to anyone wanting to dive into the world of the witcher and get to know its characters and lore a little better before jumping into The Witcher 3. *You might have a cooler experience if you've read the books before playing the franchise! 8)

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Score 90/100The Witcher has many virtues and the sentence "arguably one of the best RPGs ever made" summarizes it.When I first played this I found it buggy as it was the first version, but then the Enhanced Edition came and I could finally enjoy the game. It's a real modern RPG, with choices that matter, a well-realized world, great characters, great graphics and sound. It's very unique too, with its intriguing combat, cool alchemy system, solid novel-like story and main character *real* dark fantasy world with a vivid Middle Ages tone, entertaining dialogs and people, knights, princes, monsters and everything in between.So I can't think of a reason why hardcore RPG fans wouldn't like this game. In this final enhanced edition, bugs and performance issues are virtually non existent.Finally I'd like to add that even at full price this is a fantastic game which could easily see you spend 80+ hours on.BackstoryYour name is Geralt of Rivia and you are a witcher, that means you kill monsters for a living. You were given special training to be the best at what you do and your body has been enhanced with potent elixirs to help you do it.Suffering from amnesia you remember nothing of your past. Kaer Morhen, the last remaining keep of the witchers, was attacked by a mysterious organization, just as you were starting to lick your wounds there. The battle is won but the secret recipe for the mutagen, a substance required to create more of your kind, has been stolen. The surviving witchers set out to find and reclaim it and punish everyone involved. Memory loss or not, you are one of them.Set in a dark fantasy world with a unique medieval, yet somewhat modern, feel to it, The Witcher isn't just another fantasy RPG. With a deep story, complex characters, and tough choices that actually matter, this game will keep you glued to your monitor for days.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												If you're looking for a reason to buy this game please read the following,This game has nicely done storytelling through quest note, NPC dialogue or cutscenes, however, the game pretends to be something it cannot, for it plays like an MMORPG with fetch quests and kill x creature, but perhaps you might find interesting that it has a quite good crafting system, you go out, get some drops, harvest some plants, get an alcohol base for your potion, but that's not enough, you need to buy a book which describes how to make said potion (though, not in depth, mind you, it's just a few words then you close the book, done, you know the recipe).So far I've told you about its crafting, storytelling and quests, however, you should know that, the game is rather short if you stick to the main quests of each chapter, as many can't stomach the length of every chapter when they try to do every sidequest it has to offer.What I found very enjoyable was leveling up, because, as you level up, you earn talents (skill points) you can spend on useful perks, mostly passive, and also, you can't become OP early in the game, since talents are divided in three groups, bronze, silver and golden talents, tied to a certain range of levels, limiting you to useful, yet not groundbreaking skills, except for the magic signs you use, as a witcher, they're just magic spells, wind, fire, trap, shield and brainwash (I guess?), you also level up those with talent points and the same rule applies to them, however, the wind sign might prove more useful than you may think (I recommend you level this first, as you'll be ambushed early in the game by multiple monsters).I greatly disliked the combat, though, because you have to switch between three types of attack and two weapons, I don't remember the name of them, but it goes like this, strong, fast and group attack, the first is used against large enemies, the second, for agile ones, and the last, used when ambushed. then, your weapons, a silver weapon used against monsters and a steel one, which is used against humans.Would I suggest you buy this game? Only if you want to get into The Witcher games and want to start with the first one, or you could read the books.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Firstly, I'd just like to say that the number of hours that my profile shows isn't an accurate representation of my playtime with this game - I may have played over 20 hours of The Witcher, but that has been over multiple different laptops and different save files; in reality I've never gotten any farther in the story than Chapter 2, and have had to restart the game numerous times in an attempt to actually finish it.But for me that makes this game even more special. Sure, it might take me a few weeks, maybe a month, from when my save files are lost/deleted (for some reason, through no fault of the game I almost always manage to have to restart my save about halfway through the second chapter through computer crashes and laptop switches or whatever reason) but I will, at some point or another, will come back to playing this game.You might ask why. Why this game and not another, maybe something like Skyrim that has the popularity factor as well as everything else, not to mention it being a helluva lot more accessable/better looking/gameplay/longer life - actually that point might be debatable, given that with Skyrim you actively want to do everything, whereas it could take roughly the same amount of time just to complete the main story of The Witcher purely because there is SO much backtracking (this is probably my only real true negative towards the game to be fair)!Anyway, my point is that this game is incredibly immersive and has a mature, dark storyline that is a breath of fresh air from the staple norm that you would find in more recent RPGs (Skyrim included). Whilst the combat may take some time to get used to - so different, almost weird! - the game itself, from the story to the graphics to level progression to monster slaying is all pretty badass!What's more, CD Project Red are top developers, good at what they do, and they LISTEN to their fans! Now come on, tell the truth - how many companies can you say that about at this present moment? I'd bet that right now you just thought of either EA and/or Battlefield, OR Activision and/or COD, and how both of their games are original and unique and absolutely full to the bursting point with a compelling campaign mode and many prestigious multiplayer modes that are fun to play and never have 8 year old boys screaming down the mic at you......That doesn't happen in this game guys, that I can assure you of.Plus this game is the perfect introduction to The Witcher 2 if you have that, and the Witcher franchise as a whole - I already have the second Witcher game and am eagerly anticipating the third installment, but I know I won't play either now before finishing this game. Not because the combat is SO brilliant (it isn't) or because the graphics are SO pretty (really? This game came out in 2008 - more than 5 YEARS ago), or even because the game makes you feel like a badass when you play (which, to be fair, it does). But I know that if I miss out on this game by skipping it, I will miss crucial information about the franchise and also the experiences that this game has to offer. Because whilst this game will make you feel like a badass, what it does even better than that is that it makes you feel like a Witcher. No, not even A Witcher - you feel like THE Witcher, and that is just a whole 'nother level of awesome.So yes, it may not be the perfect RPG for everyone - definitely not perfect for me anyway! - or even a good RPG for everyone, but if you're part of that gaming crowd that loves your storys full of intrigue, conspiracies, magic and just a smidgin of naughty rumpy-pumpy, then this is the game for you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This is probably one of the best RPGs that are based on fiction media out there. Despite the fact that you can't create your own character, playing as Geralt of Rivia well makes up for it. Along with Geralt you get to explore many pastoral, beautifully drawn,  and masterfully designed locations and areas; interact with many different characters; and make a variety of tough choices that will affect you and your friends/acquintances/enemies in the game. The main story doesn't have too many plot-branches, but it's lengthy and very captivating. The graphics is extremely colorful and vibrant even despite the fact that this game was based on first NWN-enighine (!) and you're likely to find yourself starting at various landscapes and surroundings. The combat system may seem a bit awkward at first and perhaps takes some time getting used to (especially combining fighting styles and signs); but in the end it creates a number of different and stylish ways to deal with monsters and enemies.In addition to that, game has a really cool scavenging/gathering system; as a true witcher, you get to brew your own battle potions, oils, poisons/antidotes, etc.; among other things.In short, highly recommended. Try it out!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												I bought all three Witchers on sale.  With some effort, I limited myself to starting this, the first one.  I tend to like games that let you play as less human characters- lizzard men, dragons, cat folk and the like are great examples, honestly, even though Geralt, the main player character is a mutant, he is still very humanoid in appearance.  Have to like his slitted eyes and silver hair though. That aside, this game is deep, I'm getting addicted and I've barely scratched the surface of the first one.  The game supports Nvidia's DSR mode very well, giving edges a nice crisp look, though the textures are often blurred even at the games highest setting.  Considering this is an older game now, that's not suprising.  Story plots are pretty deep.  In fact, I'm involved in an investigation right now fit for a sluth.  The game has a time of day system where events happen and people are only presant at locations at certain times of day.  All the mechanics show a lot of consideration.  Witchers potions provide benifits, while have an accumulative poisioning effect that acts as a limiter, preventing you from brewing and downing too many at once.  Monsters tend to show up more at night than during the day.  Conversations with folk should be taken seriously, lest you say something that turns them off from talking to you at all for a while.  Swordplay is impressive, and once you understand the mechanics, is quite enjoyable.All in all, the game is well designed and thought out, and at this point, With all three games, I'm going to be spending several hours with it.

												Firstly, I'd just like to say that the number of hours that my profile shows isn't an accurate representation of my playtime with this game - I may have played over 20 hours of The Witcher, but that has been over multiple different laptops and different save files; in reality I've never gotten any farther in the story than Chapter 2, and have had to restart the game numerous times in an attempt to actually finish it.But for me that makes this game even more special. Sure, it might take me a few weeks, maybe a month, from when my save files are lost/deleted (for some reason, through no fault of the game I almost always manage to have to restart my save about halfway through the second chapter through computer crashes and laptop switches or whatever reason) but I will, at some point or another, will come back to playing this game.You might ask why. Why this game and not another, maybe something like Skyrim that has the popularity factor as well as everything else, not to mention it being a helluva lot more accessable/better looking/gameplay/longer life - actually that point might be debatable, given that with Skyrim you actively want to do everything, whereas it could take roughly the same amount of time just to complete the main story of The Witcher purely because there is SO much backtracking (this is probably my only real true negative towards the game to be fair)!Anyway, my point is that this game is incredibly immersive and has a mature, dark storyline that is a breath of fresh air from the staple norm that you would find in more recent RPGs (Skyrim included). Whilst the combat may take some time to get used to - so different, almost weird! - the game itself, from the story to the graphics to level progression to monster slaying is all pretty badass!What's more, CD Project Red are top developers, good at what they do, and they LISTEN to their fans! Now come on, tell the truth - how many companies can you say that about at this present moment? I'd bet that right now you just thought of either EA and/or Battlefield, OR Activision and/or COD, and how both of their games are original and unique and absolutely full to the bursting point with a compelling campaign mode and many prestigious multiplayer modes that are fun to play and never have 8 year old boys screaming down the mic at you......That doesn't happen in this game guys, that I can assure you of.Plus this game is the perfect introduction to The Witcher 2 if you have that, and the Witcher franchise as a whole - I already have the second Witcher game and am eagerly anticipating the third installment, but I know I won't play either now before finishing this game. Not because the combat is SO brilliant (it isn't) or because the graphics are SO pretty (really? This game came out in 2008 - more than 5 YEARS ago), or even because the game makes you feel like a badass when you play (which, to be fair, it does). But I know that if I miss out on this game by skipping it, I will miss crucial information about the franchise and also the experiences that this game has to offer. Because whilst this game will make you feel like a badass, what it does even better than that is that it makes you feel like a Witcher. No, not even A Witcher - you feel like THE Witcher, and that is just a whole 'nother level of awesome.So yes, it may not be the perfect RPG for everyone - definitely not perfect for me anyway! - or even a good RPG for everyone, but if you're part of that gaming crowd that loves your storys full of intrigue, conspiracies, magic and just a smidgin of naughty rumpy-pumpy, then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This is probably one of the best RPGs that are based on fiction media out there. Despite the fact that you can't create your own character, playing as Geralt of Rivia well makes up for it. Along with Geralt you get to explore many pastoral, beautifully drawn,  and masterfully designed locations and areas; interact with many different characters; and make a variety of tough choices that will affect you and your friends/acquintances/enemies in the game. The main story doesn't have too many plot-branches, but it's lengthy and very captivating. The graphics is extremely colorful and vibrant even despite the fact that this game was based on first NWN-enighine (!) and you're likely to find yourself starting at various landscapes and surroundings. The combat system may seem a bit awkward at first and perhaps takes some time getting used to (especially combining fighting styles and signs); but in the end it creates a number of different and stylish ways to deal with monsters and enemies.In addition to that, game has a really cool scavenging/gathering system; as a true witcher, you get to brew your own battle potions, oils, poisons/antidotes, etc.; among other things.In short, highly recommended. Try it out!

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												The Witcher was, indeed, a great surprise in many ways. Though lacking in visuals by today's standards, it still portrayed the sun-lit meadows, beautiful lakesides and foggy swamps as best as it could, all the while being quite atmospheric. The story follows Geralt, a professional monster slayer, need I tell more? Yes. Although Geralt might seem a two dimensional character, this well trained and mutagen enhanced, whirlwind of swords and magic can at times be more philosophical, empathic and/or cruel than you first thought, of course, only if you want to. At your disposal: weapons, magic and alchemy - the best friends of witchers (or any other RPG protagonist's). The fights may be a bit clunky at times, but they're still quite solid, though mostly combat includes timed clicks (basically click to kill everyone stupid enough to stand near you)Expect no great branching storylines, but mediocre choices that affect the world and how NPC's react to you.All in all, The Witcher is a good RPG with a good potential for real choice and consequence gameplay, no good/evil or paragon/renegade meter, just your own moral compass and real consequences of your actions.7/10

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												So, you'll all have heard of the Witcher series by now and you're wondering: "should I play the first game in order to play the rest?" Simple answer: no, you don't. Nonetheless, I heartily recommend it. I, too, heard the Witcher 3 was an awesome game, and thought about playing the first two games first. I won't ever regret that decision.So let's cut to the chase: what's good, what's bad, why do I recommend it? For a start, this game is already nine years old. Don't expect any of the visual quality we have nowadays. That being said, through the visual style, the developers put you in an incredibly immersive world which has a very particular and authentic feeling to it, which I've never seen before in a game. The atmosphere in this game is one of a kind and I'll always associate certain feelings with it. Furthermore, the Witcher series renowns itself for it's great storylines, starting in the first game and not getting any worse up to the second DLC of the last game (B&W). But it all started here. The characters are well-defined and real humans with motive and reason. Everyone has a purpose. Combine these last two points to have a very good reason to play this game.Now why do people tell you you can skip it? Well, simply because the story isn't continuous. While there is a bigger overarching story, it is not prominent in any of the games because each one has its own story which begins and ends within the game. Another reason is that is a tedious game. You move slowly, can barely fast travel and there are no means to speed up. The main story took me about 30-35 hours, of which I spend at least 40% traveling between the objectives. There are mods that increase your movement speed, but I didn't use one. Next up is combat. Combat in the Witcher is very unique. It is click-based, where you have to time your click just right in order to not get stabbed, or to chain hits and do more damage. There are also different attack styles: fast, strong and group, each of which should be used against different types of foes. Some people love this system, some hate it and of course some don't care. In reality, I think everyone should be able to adapt to it, as long as you're motivated to uncover the story.So, do I recommend it? Heartily. The unique atmosphere this game sets was one in a kind and unforgettable. Do you need to play it? Definitely not, but please do it!

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												I bought all three Witchers on sale.  With some effort, I limited myself to starting this, the first one.  I tend to like games that let you play as less human characters- lizzard men, dragons, cat folk and the like are great examples, honestly, even though Geralt, the main player character is a mutant, he is still very humanoid in appearance.  Have to like his slitted eyes and silver hair though. That aside, this game is deep, I'm getting addicted and I've barely scratched the surface of the first one.  The game supports Nvidia's DSR mode very well, giving edges a nice crisp look, though the textures are often blurred even at the games highest setting.  Considering this is an older game now, that's not suprising.  Story plots are pretty deep.  In fact, I'm involved in an investigation right now fit for a sluth.  The game has a time of day system where events happen and people are only presant at locations at certain times of day.  All the mechanics show a lot of consideration.  Witchers potions provide benifits, while have an accumulative poisioning effect that acts as a limiter, preventing you from brewing and downing too many at once.  Monsters tend to show up more at night than during the day.  Conversations with folk should be taken seriously, lest you say something that turns them off from talking to you at all for a while.  Swordplay is impressive, and once you understand the mechanics, is quite enjoyable.All in all, the game is well designed and thought out, and at this point, With all three games, I'm going to be spending several hours with it.

												Confession: when I first played this game, I dropped it after the Prologue because I found the combat tedious and lacking. However, I wanted to play this game before the other witchers, so I decided to try it one more time with an open mind. I'm glad I did because after the first chapter, my Geralt realized the joys of snuu snuu and gambling, and became part of an endless cycle of: getting laid -> losing all myMoney -> gambling to make ends meet -> losing everything -> sadness -> repeat. I have no regretsIn all seriousness, this game is phenomenal. -Combat is tedious, but once you get the hang of it, it actually becomes quite enjoyable.-This game excels in how it deals with choices and decisions. When your faced with an important decision, there is no clear right or wrong answer, and they do have lasting consequences-The story is engrossing, and while the pacing may be quite inconsistent, theres never a dull moment! Overall I'd recommend it to anyone who is looking for a immersive RPG, and a well thought out story.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												Compelling writting.This is how can I best describe my experience. The Witcher universe was created by one of the best Fantasy writers I know of. So this provided the developers a strong and credible background to work with. Many RPGs have problems with World Building, this is creating a whole reality where the main lore is happening. But not this game, here you can find that the "background" lore is even more interesting than the main one. The amount of posible sequels and prequels based on that is huge. So it is very improbable that this franchise will become the next Assassins Creed (A clear example on weak World Building) or something like that.Contraty to what many say, I loved the combat. You can read about its pros and cons all over the internet but I invite you to ignore all that and try it yourself for at least 3 hours. Of course I will do another playthrough with the Combat Rebalanced Mod soon, since it adds a layer of complexity.Speaking of wich: PLAY THIS GAME ON HARD, NO MATTER HOW BAD YOU ARE FOR VIDEOGAMES, DO IT. Ignore the easy and medium settings. Hard is where this game shines. This gamemode forces you to utilize every element at your disposal and by that, increasing and improving the gameplay. Yes, you will suffer killing the freaking Beast, and you will suffer at the swamp, but after that, the game becomes so easy, once you dominate the art of alchemy. As for graphics, if you feel this game looks too old, there are mods that revamp all the textures and you can inject some DLLs to improve another graphical aspects. If you are new to the franchise, play it on hard mode with vanilla combat and texture mods. After that I bet you will want to read the Witcher books before even starting to play the second game.Buy it no matter the price, it is worth it.

content:
Posted: February 4
												Total Score:  75  (B - More Drowners, Please!) Graphics and Art:  7Sound and Music:  7Story and Plot:  8Controls:  7Creativity and Uniqueness:  9Mood and Immersion:  9Length, Content, and Replayability:  8Functionality:  5Character Choice and Customization:  7Challenge:  8Click...wait...wait...wait...click...wait...wait...wait...wait...wait....click, your way to victory!  The Witcher is a game about all of the important things in life:  drinking beer, eating donuts, drinking "potions", having bar fights, drinking wine, fighting monsters and cutting off their monster parts, drinking spirits, and, of course, screwing everything that moves.  Witcher really does have it all!  The front screen might or might not work right, and you'll have a CTD here and there, but it mostly works.  And, sometimes your characters does what you tell him...sometimes, sort of.  I mean, like, you can, in theory dodge in this game, but you never will.  That said, the fighting, though a bit clunky, is fun.  What makes this game good, however, is the story which is grimdark and cynical and is set in a unique world where you'll wonder why anyone even bothers but still keeps you interested.  In fact, the game makes you feel like an idiot for trying to make well-considered mortal choices!  No good dead is left unpunished - just like in real life!  It is a genuinely fun game, and the use of player-crafted potions gives it some depth and gives you some challenges to overcome in the realm of tactics.  Play this game on the hardest mode, by the way, so that you'll actually have to think about what potions to use and when to use them!  Play every game on the hardest mode, actually, except the COD series...screw that noise.  Actually, just don't play the COD series.  Wait, where was I?  Oh, right.  Everyone needs to play the Witcher.  You get collector cards for screwing random chicks.  I mean, that right there basically decides it, right?

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												I do recommend this game, but with some caveats.I'll start with the positives. This game is very indepth, with lots of different tasks to do in both exploration and combat. The chapters (with one exception) are very varied and complex and allows you to craft your own style of play. The main storyline itself isn't particularly special, but works very well as a backdrop to give context to your actions but you'll find the best gems in the little everyday encounters and choices you makes. There's substantial consequence to your actions, so most quests aren't meaningless.Combat itself is average; basically being a rhythm game. The game itself isn't particularly difficult as even the most basic understanding of how combos work will carry you through most of the game. Graphically, the game looks very good for the time it was released albeit with some minor glitches here and there. The soundtrack was mostly forgettable as even after playing this game for most of the week I can't really think of a single track that I can remember. Leveling up is almost mostly automatic as you should earn more than enough level ups than you'll need at first. This means that almost every character will have the same bronze(low) level upgrades regardless of what you choose to do. The real big questions in terms of character progression are where you specialize in with your silver and gold level talents, as they ar far more sparse on a normal playthrough. As for the bad, this game does a pretty poor job of explaining itself. Without consulting some of the Steam guides I was totally lost on some of the statistics and potion making was pretty intimidating at first. For example, you'll acquire things like "Dodge +10%" and "Parry +20%" but there was no explanation ingame as to what those actually do. Making your potions was also something that doesn't really encourage experimentation as you'll basically be letting the game auto-make potions for you because you don't understand the value of the secondary substances. There's also a number of banal quests that essentially ask you to go out and hunt 10 bear asses or something similar, but thankfully they are optional and can be skipped.Overall though, this is a very entertaining game but you have to be willing to invest into it as this is a very long and complex game. A worthy addition to any RPG player's library, but only a cautionary recommendation to players looking for more core action/strategy styles.
